Pretty but touristy. There is no doubting that this is a very pretty square. It is however full of places aimed at tourists and numerous people trying to sell you things.Definitely worth a visit but don't expect a quiet wonder around, as without doubt you will be hassled at some point!
Heart of Cusco. City square surrounded by touristy restaurants aimed at foreigners (KFC, McDonalds, Starbucks). Also within walking distance to the Qorikancha and churches.
The Centre Point. A beautiful square to stroll around surrounded by many restuarents St. Pedros market a few minutes walk where you could buy fresh fruits, food, local cheese and drinks.

Chill out and take pics. this is a perfect place to take pictures. I like it cos it's visible from Loki Cusco and there's a story about it from Colonial times. In general this is a nice place to be and chill out and this is the place of choice for all public events!

A great place to go, people watch, shop, eat, visit the market and anything else you can think of.. Another Plaza de Armas location but this time in Cuzco. This is also a huge plaza surrounded by churches, shops, restaurants, etc....

Nice stop. Do not miss this site on your stay in Cusco. The architecture, culture and history are well worth the trip. If lucky, you can witness local events in the square. Just watch out for the local peddlers, they are quite relentless and great in number.

Excellent Place to Reflect. Despite the number of people who want to sell you things in the plaza, you can still take in the surroundings of the beauty of the plaza. Absorb the structures of the churches and park. These are things you won't see anywhere else. People watch. View the tourist and locals inter-act. Watch the locals sit and enjoy their plaza.
One of the nicest Plaza de Armas in Peru. Very nice architecture, great place to walk arround, have coffee or dinner. Spend some time just on a bench just to enjoy the atmosphere

People Watching at the Gold Statue.. Get a really good look at that gold statue...and find out what makes it so interesting. A great place to sit and watch people. Careful with your stuff and don't flash any money in the square. It is safe, just don't advertise where you have your travel money.

Every day a different parade or event. Old Cusco lives through this plaza which is a must see. It is surrounded by the historic cathedral, convent and basilica and at its center is the colorful fountain with its statute of the 9th Incan Emperor. It seemed to us to have a daily parade of fantastic musicians and dancers with amazing costumes. The locals are passionate about preserving their culture and traditions, which is evident in this epicenter. It is a great place to sit, people watch, gather your thoughts for your next foray. At night, it is the happening place - there were many weddings when we were there which was delightful to watch. The roads are old river stones and cobblestone and crowded with shoppers, and beautifully dressed older women with a lamb or llama happy to take a picture for a sole. The downside was the many art hawkers who would constantly come up to you with their lovely art, but it becomes a stress to be constantly pressured to look at the art and be begged to purchase it. While we were aware of the many warning regarding pickpockets, thankfully we did not experience this.

The center of Cusco. An evening visit to the plaza is a must . Very peaceful and all lit up with benches to sit on . Of course you will want to tour the Cathedral and visit some of the other Cusco sights , but after a nice dinner in the one of the many nearby restaurants, this is a good place to end the day.
The Plaza. The true center of Cusco,the parade we saw was fun but it was on the evening twilight ,it is like you are in the movies.

Historic plaza with a beautiful fountain and lot's of benches. Beautiful place to stop and rest, the only issue is the # of painting vendors. It is surrounded by many historical buildings and museums. There are also quite a few restaurants to choose from and some have fantastic views from their second floor tables.

Scenic and beautiful.. Absolutely beautiful, true to its Spaniard roots. There are two churches at the plaza, one of them being the main cathedral, and I'm unsure which one was the other, there so many churches in town. I don't recommend being there past 23:00, there's police presence, but also a few hooligans.

Fairytale Plaza. This is a gorgeous plaza. It is very well kept. The building around the plaza are very charming with their wooden balconies. Around the plaza there are many artists who paint and make the plaza very colorful.

beautiful spot, take your time. Of course everybody who goes to Cusco should have seen this once - after all, it's *the* main square.Lots of restaurants and cafes around it, so grab a coffee or tee and enjoy the view. Apparently they just recently started to make it a pedestrian zone, which is great because now even lots of locals go here for a lazy afternoon or evening. There are lots of people here who try to sell you tours, massages, arts or crafts or make you have lunch/dinner in their restaurants. But a polite "no, gracias" and they will leave you alone.One won't find any restaurants here to get a lunch menu for local prices, but within 60 seconds of walking there are plenty of choices where one can get a 3 course lunch for 7 to 10 Soles. Though, compared to Lima, the prices in the touristy restaurants ain't this bad - for 60 Soles/person one gets amazing food that will feed one for a day.
Where It's At in Cusco. Has everything -- Spanish architecture, Incan ruins, a McDonald's. Very close to good restaurants and clubs, too.

Heart of Peru. We experienced Cusco over the Christmas holidays. On Christmas Eve the Andean villagers come to Cusco to celebrate Santuranticuy & Chocolatadas. Selling Nativities scene, silver, wool wraps, boots, rugs etc. Cusco is the oldest city in the Americas, 3000 years old. Surrounding the square is Cathedral Basilica Assumption of the Virgin which took a 100 years to construct completed in 1654. Cusco is a must walk through history.

Amazing location to start your tour of Cuzco.. Awesome historical location in the El Centro de Cuszo. Can be quiet expensive since the Asians and Europeans found about Machu Picchu and the massive amounts of historical sites. The Plaza is very neat and interesting however as with most of Peru don't let your sites off your valuables.. My wife almost learned the hard way right there... There is a ton of good restaurants and shops around. The central market is a short walk away and youll find better deals there... Starbucks, KFC and McDonalds in the center so what else could a gringo want:)

Central to Cusco. Central point of the original Cusco. During the evening three sides are closed to auto traffic making this a very nice place to stroll and get a feel for the city and, at least, its Spanish era history.

This IS Cuzco!. Everything is around this square. All the shopping, restaurants, bars, museums, churches, etc... It is the place you want to be. We saw school kids doing presentations, parades, etc.. It seems to be the place where people gather. It has great photo opportunities as well.

Plaza de Armas is the symbol of Cusco. This is an amazing plaza with so much to do and see with so much history. During our 1 week stay in Cusco, we came to this plaza everyday, except for one day because we went to Machu Picchu.

Really cute at night.. Really cute at night. Although we have to pay in every place, including the churches! It's amazing to see the modern world (like starbucks and Mc Donalds adapted to the antique buildings.

Culture, History, and Shopping. Gorgeous. That's all. There's churches, flowers, restaurants, and shops, and I loved it. I went to both churches, which are both must-sees; it's a very interesting fusion of Incan and Catholic culture. The restaurants in the plaza are, of course, amazing (but also pricey). And shopping- it has all the best shops you could want for alpaca merchandise, jewelry, and souvenirs. I spent hours and hours wandering the plaza and didn't even notice until it was dark :)

Lovely colonial plaza. The main plaza is a must-see for visitors, and several key Cusco tourist destinations, including several churches, are located on or near the plaza. The architecture is beautiful, and you will be surrounded by history (Inca and colonial) dating back many centuries. The one annoying thing is the number of people who will approach you trying to sell items (sunglasses, art, jewelry, souvenirs), so be prepared.

Wonderful Public Square. Plaza De Armas is a wonderful public square in Cusco. On a recent hiking trip to Machu Picchu and other areas around Cusco, we enjoyed the square several afternoons and evenings. There is always something interesting going on and there are terrific restaurants around the periphery.

Beautiful, day or night!. Absolutely beautiful plaza. Lots of site-seeing, restaurants and shopping. Great place to sit and relax ... and lots of people watching. Day or night ... absolutely beautiful.

The heart of Cusco Central. Charming central plaza in Cusco where locals and tourist alike gather. Surrounded by a variety of restaurant options - both for the value driven travel and the foodie alike. Lots of options for shopping around for tours of the Sacred Valley and Machu Piccuhu. If your travel schedule allows, and you haven't booked an excursion in advance - take the time to shop around. And definitely negotiate the cost of your tour! Lose yourself exploring the side streets where you'll find churches, fountains, small cafes, tiendas and tourist/souvenir shops. Reminded me of some of the small villages I've visited in Southern Europe. Lots of charm.

Loved Plaza de Armas. It's breathtaking, literally takes your breath away walking around here at 10,000 feet.. One of the most beautiful and clean old world Plazas we've been to in the World. Literally takes your breath away.

OK if passing through. The Plaza is a nice place to explore and sit out. It has a few stand out buildings but when compared to other architecture in Europe built at the same time, it doesn't really compare.I imagine most people will be stopping off in Cusco on the way to Machu Pichu, in which case it is a pleasant place to see for a short while. However I certainly wouldn't want to come here as a destination in itself.

The center of beautiful Cusco. Cusco is great! The Plaza de Armas has an impressive statue of the Inca and is filled with flowers. There are shops, restaurants, and sight-seeing all around. I recommend the side street (Loreto) on the northeast corner which has a perfect Inca stone wall as well as a market on the right where alcapas and llamas can be photographed. Calle Triunfo on the right side of the cathedral also has a lot to see and some great shopping

Beautiful Plaza lots of vendors. The plaza is very nice the large statue in the fountain in the middle is worth seeing as R the Cathedral and the other colonial buildings surrounding the square the one downside is the vendor's continually trying to sell you something if you can get past that and you really have very little choice in that matter it's a required stop in Cusco

The heart of Cusco!. The Plaza de Armas is surely the epicentre of Cusco and is always buzzing with people and is a great place to just sit and relax, to eat or to shop.Do take note that the plaza and surrounding area is very commercialised and 'touristy' but still it manages to keep a charming character.Definitely a must see and visit when in Cusco and try to visit both at day and night...it's a beautiful plaza!

Perfect in nice weather.. We had two days in Cusco of lovely weather, and passed through this plaza many times. Is a wonderful place to relax and people watch. Grab a lunch from a restaurant overlooking the plaza.

Beautiful!. The plaza de armas in the center of Cuzco is absolutely beautiful. It makes for a stunning center to the city. We enjoyed strolling through the plaza both during the busy hours of the day when it was crowded with people and at night when it was lit up and a bit quieter.
You will cross this many times while in Cusco. An open Square with the Cathedral dominating the view. Benches and flowers, Colonial arcades with restaurants and shops on two sides.

The Best Place to Start Your Cusco Visit. There is really only one lace to start a visit to Cusco and that's the Plaza de Armas. The place to stay. To eat. To shop. To explore. Walking the plaza and its immediate surroundings is clean, safe, friendly and engaging.

Markets. Theres everything here including a maccas. Be sure to wander the streets for the hidden markets and dont be afraid to negotiate with the people. Dont buy anything once you first see it as chances are you will see it again for a cheaper price!
Plaza de Armas. It is nice to stay taking some sun and see people coming and gong. Very beautifull and with well preserved history

The Plaza. Another WONDER of the world. Beautiful Plaza. Knowledgable guide from GATE 1. So much history of this country from 700 years ago to now. Very clean city. very ecology minded. Good food too. Hotels were all 5 *

Eclectic City Center. This historic center of Cuzco is certainly a great place to sit and relax as you adjust to the elevation (11,000 feet!). The square has beautiful architecture, particularly the university and the cathedral. You can visit the cathedral's interior for only a few soles. There are lots of grassy areas as well as many places to sit and take in the views. Plentiful restaurants and shops encircle the square, so there's something for everyone to enjoy. Be prepared for lots of vendors trying to sell you their wares, and some won't take "no" for an answer right away.
Visit at night, it has a special ambience. Such a nice square to see at night after or before a great dinner at one of the local eateries.Another must see.

Center of Cusco. This is the main square in Cusco and everyone is here. The area is pedestrian only in the day time and early evening but the cars zip around the edges. The square has the cathedral on one side and businesses and restaurants on two sides. Lots of good places to eat while looking out at the square. Good way to rest while getting used to 11000 feet!

Lovely resting spot. Green lawns and sunny skies in the dry season make this a nice spot to sit and relax in the morning and evening. A great location marker for touring the city. There are several of nearby restaurants and bars in the area, and the plaza is surrounded by beautiful churches.

Don't miss Cusco's historic center.... This is the historic center of Cusco. The Plaza is surrounded by magnificent architecture and history. Visit the Convento de Santo Domingo (Qorikancha) for the price of 10 soles.
beautiful. Capital of the empire! It is a beautiful city especially the main square, churches have a spectacular design, most of the buildings are impressive ...
Sitting on a bench. Spent some time sitting on a bench in the warm sun. A bit annoying though that they keep bothering you to buy souvenirs.

City Center full of life. When you are in Cusco you will spend most of your time in the plaza or around the plaza. In fact, besides all the historical sites outside of town there really is no reason to go anywhere else. The only negative is the constant street vendors and they don't take no for an answer. The best tact is to just ignore them.

Nice place to take a breather. I came here on my last night in Cusco, before starting my journey back to Seattle. It was a perfect evening. The Plaza is a great place for a stroll anytime of the day (though it gets chilly at night - think mountain climate). There are quite a few restaurants and the lights on the cathedrals are magnificent at night. Swing by in the afternoon and you might get to hold a baby goat!

Beatiful Plaza ,Churches and dances in the Plaza. Beatiful Plaza, everything around is so colonial ,you like to explore - but when it comes to the Church (es) that surround the Plaza ; be prepared to be kicked out if you are NOT there prefered christian, they did exactly that to us when we tried to enter either one of the 2 churches that surround the plaza. No $oles no entry - there is a fee to come - and they mean it.

Historic site. Wonderful plaza, with a statue (I think it is Atahualpa) in the center. It is amazing to walk around and think of the history and the fall of the greatest empire the New World ever saw. Stores with all manner of goods ring the square, along with many restaurants offering typical food. Want to try roasted guinea pig or grilled alpaca? There are plenty of places for that.
lots to see. We were there during a school festival, lots to see, many stores and markets. Found that there are too many people selling their wears, lots the same, so where is it made

Plaza de Armas in Cusco. This city is a very charming and charismatic city. Plaza de Armas is the main square of the city, surrounded with good restaurants and shops. Try to get a hotel within a walking distance to this area. It is a very safe and fun area.
Nice hangout. Very beautiful especially during the night. The lights, shopping, restaurants and all are just perfect.
Cute central plaza.. It's a cute plaza that has shops, cafes, restaurants, dominated by a big centuries old cathedral. Great place to hang out.

Good place for tourist. Although it is a very good place to visit, the atmosphere was too touristic.You can exchange money, however, you should be careful not to get counterfeit. When I exchange 50 USD to peruvian Sol, one of three peruvian 50 sol bills was counterfeit

Typical City Square. This square is the heart of Cusco and a must visit. It is surrounded by lovely restaurants, cafes, bars and shops. There were lots of celebrations while we were there so there was always something going on in the square.

Loved the plaza at night . Very nice atmosphere in the evening esp with shining dots of lights on the surrounding hills like twinkling stars. A lot of shops and restaurants as well. But souvenirs tend to be expensive around the plaza.
Just sit and watch the show. There is always something going on in the Plaza. Sometimes it is protesters, sometimes a parade of singing school children. Lots of activity day or night!

Classic Square. I bring student groups to Cusco every year, and we always reserve a hotel close to the Plaza so we can soak in the ambiance. The architecture is stunning, the vistas are grand, and shopping and restaurants are everywhere.

Gorgeous Place !. This place is truly gorgeous and so is Cusco city centre! There is so much unity in the colonial architecture that is so well preserved! You truly go back in time! I loved everything about Cusco and would love to go back.

Perfect starting point for a walking tour of Cusco. This highly attractive square faces two churches and has much charm. Nice restaurants, including the highest altitude Irish pub in the world ring the square.

WOW!. The Plaza de Armas was an amazing vantage point to explore all of the amazing history, culture, and architecture of Cusco. There are also many stores and local artisans selling street crafts. Highly recommended.
First impression of Cusco!. The plaza anchors the city with this touristic but pretty plaza. Can't go to Cusco with checking it out!

Nice Area to Spend The Day Roaming. The Plaza de Armas, Cusco is a nice area to spend the day. You can see numerous locals and tourists meeting up and hanging out. This plaza is filled with many restaurants and touristy shops. It is also quite close to a number of museums of interest.

A must stop place on any tour of Cusco!!!. The heart of the city, all things radiate out from this busy square. Surrounded by streets lined with shops, the square is a great place to stop, grab a bite to eat, and people watch! Day or night (I would visit it during both), the Square is a hive of activity. Not to fear, it is safe at all times (subject to the common sense advice not to flash money or carry your wallet/cell phone where it is easily accessible by pick pockets).
Beautiful. Such a beautiful place to hang out after our meal. We were there on a sunny day but take care it gets cold when the sun goes down.
Pretty and historic city center. The plaza is a nice place to relax and visit some of the historic churches. It is also a very useful landmark when navigating around the city.
A great place to people watch, and admire some of the buildings.. Nice to sit here and watch the Cuscanian people go about their daily lives. Lots of benches, grass and flowers, well looked after.

The center of Cusco. The Plaza de Armas in the best place to center your visit to Cusco. Most every local attraction is within blocks of the Plaza on all sides. We went there at sunset and it was an amazing time to take beaufiful pictures. If you have the time take a guided tour of the local cathedral. It's just as amazing as any leading cathedral in Europe.
nice little place for a break. A beautiful place to visit for a break when you're shopping up a storm in town. It's picturesque, full of flowers and there's plenty of people watching to do.
Perfect Plaza!. Soo much fun hanging around this plaza. Lots of restaurants and shops. Great place to relax and people watch!
Do yourself a favor. Go to Cusco!. The Plaza de Armas is one of the most beautiful city centers in the world. It is so vibrant and so rich in history. It is a must see. We love it.

very south american and quaint. beautifully lit up at night.
great spot to people watch.
plethora of restaurants to choose from
anything that you could possible need you can find in this plaza

Experience the Beauty of old architecture. Central part of city, presents beauty from every angle. The old architecture in particular fascinates you. The little girls with the tribal dress and a lamb in hand are very cute-they invite you to have a photo with them. you can't resist the temptation.
The place to be in Cusco. Every Sunday seems to be a parade with thousands of schoolkids, marching bands and uniformed old men all having a good time. Great restaurants and shopping around.

Quick Visit is all That's Needed. This was the only historical part of Cusco I visited. The buildings were beautiful and the architecture was interesting. The area isn't that large and you can walk around the square in less than an hour. It was extremely touristy. The shops were all set up for tourists. We enjoyed looking at the buildings, walking into the main church, and enjoyed a delicious lunch! As far as getting a better Peruvian flavor and shopping, I highly recommend walking a few blocks away and visit the authentic market place!

A captivating little town. My Peruvian friends have constantly been recommending Cusco, not only because it was on the way to Machu Picchu but because it was a wonder in itself. Boy, they've been right all this time! We arrived during a hot summer day in Cusco and had the chance to wander the marvelous town of San Blas and its markets for most of the afternoon. But it wasn't until the evening when we witnessed just how impressive the place was. The Plaza de Armas is a gorgeous site, a centerpiece to a provincial but bustling tonw, and from there one can see the rest of the Cusco twinkling in incandescent radiance. It felt like something out of a movie, but palpably real. It was just nice sitting by the square with my friends.
Beautiful place . Nice place to visit with great scenery. very close to museum's and church's. There is alot of restuaurants and shoppong nearby

Great feeling!. Being there feels great, almost everyone are tourists so you even if you travel alone you won't feel alone. There are many restaurants around, so you can eat any type of food you want.

The staging point for most activities in Cusco.. Great place to walk around and take in the architecture. Walking tours readily available from the fountain. The shops near by are tourist traps so bargain aggressively if you plan to buy something.

beautiful area. We were there over peruvian independence day so there was a lot going on all the time, with parades and tents and events. There was a starbucks in the city centre and after getting sick off local food, was a nice treat. Lots of cute shops around, but fairly expensive. Ended up sitting for a few hours on the stairs and playing cards, in which we gathered a crowd of locals curious to learn the game. Only thing we didn't like about sitting in the centre was all the locals trying to sell us paintings and jewelry as we sat.

Historic square with lots going on.. We strolled through the square on a late afternoon and were treated to the local kids dancing. The were learning different dances and we enjoyed watching them. We stopped for drinks and sushi at Limo's which has a great view overlooking the square!

Great central place to decide what's next.. This is the central plaza of Cuzco. You can plan the rest of your travel from here, go to the fresh food markets, explore the beautiful cobblestone streets or sit quietly with a coffee and people watch over the plaza as of the sun sets.

Primo Plaza. Great for people watching and strolling about. Numerous shops and restaurants. Although frequently approached with offers to buy various souvenirs, get a massage, go on a tour, etc., a polite 'no gracias' was typically met with a smile and a shrug and no further hounding (unlike many other places in the world).
Center of Cusco, Beautiful. This is where you start once in Cusco. Central park where you find the Cathedral, shops, restaurants, and many tour operators. Its a beautiful place for pictures.

Heart of the city. The plaza is definitely the heart of the city. I was there over the Peruvian independence week and it featured parades, marching bands, food vendors and people selling special items. The plaza is home to higher priced, more touristy food options so if you're looking for a cheap meal it's better to try a different part of the city. The buildings are gorgeous and the gardens within the plaza are meticulously kept up. If you're looking for a place to people watch or you're trying to get the feel of the city, check out the plaza.
Interesting architectures and good food.. The plaza surrounded with beautiful old churches, you can visit them, while you are choosing from the lots of good restaurants around.

Beautiful, good people watching. Wish more American cities had places where people gathered and just hung out. Beautiful architecture on all sides. Surrounded by mountains. Great photos when the skies are blue, which they always are.

Very beautiful . It's a very beautiful plaza. The only thing that bothered me as in many highly touristic areas are all the people trying to sell tours or products. Makes it harder to enjoy. But overall a nice magical spot.
Canter of Cusco. Plaza de Armas in Cusco is the center of the city ....very well preserved , close to car , so pedestrian can walk free ...A lot of shops ...cafes ....restaurants

Wonderful gathering place. Beautiful place! I could literally sit there all day and enjoy the wonderful town square. There are people walking by with souveneirs and art if you want, if not simply sit there and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. They have professional photographers with yellow vests who do not harrass you , we actually went up to them and they take amazing family photos with different backroungs. We took 3 pictures and we love them all. They print them out right then and there and they are each only 5 soles (about $1.50 US).

The life of Cusco. Vibrant centre of the historic city of Cusco! Even if you don't enter any of the cathedrals, it's a great place to people-watch, either from the square or from one of the balconies of the many cafes and restaurants around.
Delicious place. Delicious op lace to sit and take pictures. It is very busy though, surrounded by restaurants and bars.
Festival Time!. Great square with a wonderful parade. We were there for the Solstice celebration. It was crowded - but with an air of excitement.

Great people watching!. So much good people watching here. But watch out. The street vendors will hound you until you want to go crazy. The best way to deal with them, if you are not interested, is to ignore them. It seems cruel, but they won't leave you alone if you don't. This is a beautiful area in the city...a must see!
Do not miss it!. Have a "mate de coca" (infusion based on coca leafs, completely legal and healthy) on one of the balconies facing this square. Try the one at Hotel Plaza de Armas.

Always something going on. This always something going on in this busy area. We saw inca presentations, art shows, local bands, independence celebrations, weddings - plant yourself in one of the many first floor bars with a view and watch the world go by, time well spent!!!
It's a must do.. Touristy but worth the trip. I love all the alleyways leading off the square. The cathedral is beautiful.
Most beautiful Plaza de Armas in Peru. Surrounded by two impressive cathedrals and colonial mansions, you will be stunned by the view of this square. Get your camera ready.

Nice Town Square....But Lots of People Trying to Sell. Nice town square filled with lots of tourists. If you are out walking around this is great place to help you keep you centered (I sometimes have difficulty with directions). There are many beautiful buildings, lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. Some of the things that I did not care for so much is that almost all of the restaurants have someone outside begging you to come in and there are many vendors sitting on the narrow sidewalks or walking around trying to sell you stuff. I have a soft heart so it is hard for me to say no.
Fun place to visit.... Wonderful place to stop and relax and people watch. Great restaurants all around. The views of the ountains are spectacular!

Centre of Cusco. This is the place to be in Cusco. Everything you might want is all around you. Shops, travel agents, restaurants, hotels, bars, massage, tattoo parlours, promoters. It's clean and had some performers in the evenings. Very nice to just relax in the Sun and watch the world go by.
Gorgeous. This is a beautiful plaza and it is even prettier at night when they light up all the balconies and the streets. It is packed with restaurants and coffee shops.

An Exciting Place to Visit. We walked around the plaza for days. We shopped and ate and watched interesting people walk by. I even held a baby lamb (for a price!) It is clean and there is an energy as one explores.

City centre. So much to do, its the city centre surrounded by restaurants churches and shopping. I recommend sitting near the fountain and just taking in the whole ambiance. Must check out the restaurants which have a balcony on the upper level that surround the plaza as well as the salsa club to get yr groove on

Good place to hang around. This is the main square of the city. It's beautiful, well tended to and contains all that you could expect: lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, activities and, of course, lots of turists as well.
Great place to hang out. Plaza's by their very nature are places where people like to hang out and enjoy the day, Plaza de Armas is no exception.

A nice place, nice garden, and in the center of the city. The city center! Many of the good restaurants are located around this place. The old buildings are very nice. If you have bought the "touristic boletos", you have to know that the visit of the cathedral is nont included in this ticket

Tourist area. This is the main tourist square area in the city. A lot of shops and restaurants surround it. There are also several churches at the square that are beautiful. There a re a lot of street vendors trying to sell you something. Most will leave you alone if you say you are not interested. But some can be more aggressive and actually will follow you around.

Very lively around Inti Raymi. We were lucky that our ur visit to Cusco coincided with the Inti Raymi festival. The area was largely pedestrian and one could observe different groups perform their acts every day. On the eve of the big festival they had several bands perform along with parades and dances. I'm sure that even at other times the big plaza will be full of life as it houses not only the cathedral, various shops and restaurants but it is also a meeting point for locals and a place for tourists to unwind.
Spend some time here. Nice square, a lot of families walking around, kids playing, awesome scenery, there is no direction that you can turn where you don't have an amazing view, day or night.

What a relaxed atmosphere!. The plaza de armas is definitely a jewel in an already gorgeous city. Enjoy your lunch with a view on the plaza in one of the restaurants offering balconies. Beware the shoe cleaning boys: make sure to settle for a price before you get your shoes cleaned.

Cuzco is the heartland of the old Incan civilization. This certainly was the hub of Cuzco, with the statue in the center and the historical churches built on the foundations of the Incan buildings surrounding it. You are at about 9,000 feet elevation, so take it easy

Beautiful main square. The main square so hard to miss. We were there during the annual celebration of the founding of Cuzco so very different than other times. Grreat dancing, live bands and an awesome fireworks display one night. Felt totally safe here amidst the crowds of young people. A great experience!

Where the things happend. Main square is the center of Cusco but also the center of all tourism. There you can find Tours to anywhere in Cusco (try to buy tourist packages in agencies that has a fisical location, not the ones who are walking in the streets) also the best restaurants are around main square. By night main square turns into center of night life ( it's very safe to walk around plaza de Armas at any time) the best discos, bars and clubs are surrounding main square.

Romantic Cusco. Alone, couples, and families alike can enjoy this little wonder. By day there are amazing cathedrals and restaurants. By night there is music, lights, markets, LIFE! Our hostel was so close, we were here at least 10 times in our visit. I posed for baby Llama pictures as well. Ahhhh, the plaza. Always something new!
The heart of the city. The heart of the historical centre from Cusco. Save some time to just sit there and enjoy the place.

Pretty, but annoying….. Get used to saying " no, gracias"…the sellers of trinkets and massages don't give up…its actually sad and ridiculous…some are actually rude…its the worst part of a beautiful square.
Great Old Square. Beautiful square, not only for sites but for people watching. Lots of food and shopping as well. Bring your camera.
Beautiful place. The best park that I have seen here in cusco. A must see in my opinion. It is worth to spend some time sitting in there.

Interesting plaza with lots to do. The plaza, boasts a grand church (The Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption of the Virgin), and a smaller cathedral (Templo de la Compañia de Jesus). There are restaurants on one side of the square with the carved balconies unique to this part of the world. In the middle is a nice park with flowers and colorful flags - the Cusco flag is a rainbow of vertical stripes.In the center stands a status of the Inca, and because of the proximity to the sun festival, his plinth was getting a makeover in grand Inca style with paper mache rocks and a staircase with a red carpet. It was under construction for a few days, then being painted, and when complete was quite a sight to behold.Also because of the sun festival, children and older students would come at night and practice their native dances in the streets of the plaza, accompanied by a lone drum or flute. Part of the times, the entire streets were blocked off so the dancers had more room.The plaza is surrounded by straight, steep, stone streets which were very narrow. Tiny doorways cluttered with brightly colored handicrafts led into small single-room shops that offered:- textiles woven from wool or alpaca- paintings in two varieties - brightly colored landscapes, or religious art- tooled leather goods- carved and painted gourds- silver jewelry- knotted bracelets.In addition to the shops, people on foot were selling the same assortment of goods on every street corner, down every lane, and all over the square. It seemed like everyone in Cusco wants to sell you something.
Nice Colonial view in Cuzco. walking around Cusco center is like we are in spain, many Colonial houses and churches are there, it has a beautiful view from different points for exploring Cusco

Possibly my favorite part of Cusco. An absolutely beautiful square, my husband and I loved just walking around and sitting on a bench to people watch. It's incredibly clean and beautifully kept. I wish we could have spent more time here!

Vacations at Cusco. Excellent and beautiful place to learn about the history of the Inca and the Spaniards interaction since the early dates. The ambiance is a relax and the people from Cusco is very friendly.

Probably one of the nicest plaza in south america!. Very well preserved, clean and quite - despite the traffic. Beautiful from each corners and if you take a coffee break from any of the coffee houses along the plaza you are promised to get gorgeous view!

Festive Plaza. The Plaza de Armas is home to Cusco's best festivals, a lively atmosphere, restaurants that boast balconies looking over the abundant community feel. Beware the attack of massage-peddling ladies and shoe shiners. DO bargain for a chullo...everyone is wearing them!

fun, colorful. There was a festival going on when we visited in May, so we spent a couple of hours at this plaza watching the colorful parade and dancing. A nice way to spend time, seeing local culture, watching both locals and other tourists.

Fun place to people watch.. If you can handle being asked to get your shoes shined... over and over, then you'll definitely love this place. When we were there July 2015 there were activities and parades every day. Lots of places to eat and drink. In the evening, we would come to the plaza where restaurateurs would compete for our business. It was pretty fun.

Exquisite cathedral. Elaborate carvings, gilded altars of gold & silver. cedar carved choir seats eye opening massive pulpit made of solid cedar wood, beautifully carved. no photos permitted was the downturn of the tour of the cathedral
Good people watching!. Excellent place to come up with a game plan! Sit watch the sun cruise across the sky, relax, enjoy the company of a little stray dog buddy.

A fun place to hang out. A great place to people watch....surrounded by a gorgeous cathedral and a church, great restaurants and shops selling gorgeous alpaca sweaters...with a statue of Pachacutec in the middle.

It is the center of Cusco. The churches are amazing beautiful. There are parades and dancing of students (elementary, middle school, high school, colleges) in the 2nd and 3rd week of June. They celebrate the Winter Solstice (June 21st) for the whole week.

Cusco's Heart and Welcoming place for visitors. This is where it all begins in Cusco and where you can find pretty much all you need within a few blocks. At its heart it is a charming plaza that attracts a wide range of locals and visitors and a few weirdos to boot. As others have said it is a wonderful place to watch people and get connected to the city. There are benches and walkways, fountains and wonderful views of the cathedrals that flank the square. Lots of great cafes and restaurants, especially those that offer second-floor views of the plaza. There are museums on and near the square, high end shops for silver and gold and wonderful textiles. Places to change money at good rates but shop around for the best rates. Within a few streets you can get outfitted for the trail, find hostels and hotels, book tours, get provisioned and maybe even propositioned. Even get the massage of your choice if that is the kind of adventure that you desire. There are a few hawkers and street vendors but that is now being controlled to keep it reasonable. This year the streets on two sides of the square had been closed to traffic to create a broad pedestrian mall that makes it easier and safer to negotiate. One day we were there we found armed riot police sheltered under on of the protocolsas it was a day of protest in in Cusco. Despite that the plaza was full of people and shopping continued uninterrupted. The police themselves were very relaxed and good natured and essentially on hand just in case this got out of hand. Cusco has invested heavily in Tourism Police in recent years to keep visitors safe, traffic moving and everything in good order. This has worked well as it is a safe and enjoyable place to spend some time and to use a base for further adventure.

Beautiful central plaza. Plaza de Armas is a beautiful square that is worth spending some time in to people watch and to visit some of the nearby cathedrals. We particularly enjoyed walking through the Basilica at the end of the square.

A touristy square that is nothing amazing.. This is just a small square in the tourist area of Cusco. It is pretty but very touristy. Watch out for the people selling "art work" that is really just printed images. Fun to check out but nothing too impressive. There are lots of good restaurants around the square and it is a great place to use as a marker when wandering around town.

Great walkable area with something for everyone.. Plaza de Armas became the central location that we used to venture around Cuzco and not get lost. Plenty to see and do within close proximity. The plaza was within walking distance of our hotel and provided something for everyone. Photo ops w locals and baby llamas. Lunch at one of the many local restaurant options in one of the historic balconies that line the plaza. What a great view! Historic Catherdral, Pachacuted monument, shops some alpaca items (Tip: Buy alpaca items in Cuzco much better quality than in Lima) enjoyed some sweets at a bakery. A great time was had by all without over exerting ourselves due to the altitude.

People Watching Wonder. A wonderful people watching heaven, with the extra values of shopping, restaurants and museums. Every thing is close by and you hardly need to leave the plaza, BUT DO as there are terrific lane ways and arcades that lead you through the most interesting of stalls and markets and therefor bargains to be found. Several historic buildings with typical spanish balconies are beautiful if you lift your gaze to the first floor around the Plaza. The cathedral id also well worth a tour and shelter from the elements.
Awesome . Very nice place to be in! Very calm! You even find a McDonald's and a KFC near. But everything is also more expensive here.

Beautiful Square. One of the most beautiful town squares, with statues, churches, colorful flowers and people, many great restaurants and fun balconies for people watching and beer drinking. A fun departure point city for the Maachu Pichu trip.
fun square. Lots of fun! Great temples, churches, restaurants etc, the only bad is the aggressiveness of the locals trying to sell their wares, or draw you into their restaurants

Get ready to be offered something for sale. My second favorite place in Cusco to read my book and enjoy the scenery (first being the deck at Hostal Wara Wara). Always activity going on and surrounded by amazing beauty and history. Just be prepared to say "No Gracias" every 2 minutes.

Great plaza to sit in the sun. Great plaza that is well taken care of. Nice to sit in the sun and people watch or read a book. Be wary of lots of people targeting travellers to buy goods. Lots of tourists in this area, but a great spot to chill out. There are some nicer restaurants and cafe around the area also that gives you a view of the plaza.

Central hub of Cusco. There are numerous shops and restaurants along the porticos surrounding the plaza. And in the middle a grassy area with benches to sit. During late-June, they had daily parades of school groups and dance groups doing traditional dress and dances that circulate from side streets and through the plaza.

Good place to walk around. You should definitely spend some time walking around the Plaza de Armas and getting a feel for the central part of Cusco. My friend and I didn't sign up for any tours of the Plaza or surrounding plazas, but it's worth checking out.

Beautiful. We enjoyed sitting in the plaza and enjoying the people. We found the plaza to be very clean and welcoming. There is lots of restaurants and shopping close to the plaza. the buildings surrounding the plaza are beautiful.

Perfect to sit and people watch.. Super nice, large plaza. Beautiful and well maintained. I also liked that there were no hawkers in the main part of the plaza (though they were on the outskirts/perimeter). Lots of benches around to sit though many people did sit on stairs and some grassy areas. Really nice area to spend a few minutes.

The center of town. This is the center of the old town, where you will find restaurants, the information center (inside the bank), tour operators and much more. Many of the free city tours start here but its important to find the right one that will actually give you a real tour of the town and not a sales pitch. On weekends or special days many of the events happen in this Plaza.

Inviting Public Space. It's pretty. There are plenty of police patrolling at all times, so you feel safe in the evening. Nice shops around the square. American food for those who need it. Hawkers and peddlers everywhere, but that's to be expected. You can see the whole thing from Sacsayhuaman, and that's even prettier.

Enjoyable walk, safe, and clean. As a single female, I was a little nervous about walking from San Blas to the Plaza. I felt safe and even went at night. There are so many things to discover from the small museums to the amazing cathedral. I walked here a few times a day to shop, dine, and hit the San Pedro market for fresh produce and more. I enjoyed the Sunday church gathering and all the rituals from the Starbucks (yay). I even went into the cathedral during mass and was amazed by the lovely art and architecture.

Beautiful and Entertaining. We were here during several festival days. The plaza was alive with entertainment, which we enjoyed with visiting and local friends in wide age range. Knowing what I know now, I'd recommend not booking a hotel near the plaza if you don't want to listen to the same music allll through a long night.

Beautiful cathedrals!. Well kept plaza, many vendors but very restpectfull; if you tell them you are not interested they will leave you alone. Also they sell silver and is way cheaper than the stores!

Shopping, history, and more shopping. Right off the bat I found a Starbucks. Armed with caffeine and English speaking baristas I explored. Up and down little pedestrian streets filled with alpaca shops and fabulous locally made embroidery shoes, with some photo posing llamas along the way. I was happy. You can shop forever and spend next to nothing. Everyone is friendly and gracious and there is very little panhandling (though some). The nearby cathedrals and Inka museum can be easily explored and are totally worthwhile. And it's impossible to get lost as the streets all reach out from the one main plaza where intermittant ceremonial parades entertain.
plaza de Armas. We were lucky as it was thr corpus christi celebration at the plaza was filled with people dressed in costumes,bands, marcheseven the Army Band was here, it was colourful
Sun Soaked Stones. Beautiful and open, Plaza de Armas is the perfect spot to take a break and hunt some local food vendors.

Everything is here.. This is the main square in Cusco and has everything from banks with ATMs, souvenir shops, tour companies, churches and great restaurants. General meeting place with central fountain and rocks of a night. Don't miss original Inca street next to church.

Sun Festival made it awesome. We arrived just before the sun festival so we got to see a giant free concert in the plaza as well as many groups performing traditional folk dances. It was a very cool plaza and if you can visit the week of June 24th then I would highly recommend it!

The Center of the City. Beautiful old buildings, including a basilica, and a lovely public place. Lots of restaurants surrounding it. Some issues with people trying to sell you their arts, crafts, etc. but not too persistent.

A great place to start your adventure. This square is full of history and charm. You can stroll through or sit on a bench and enjoy the surrounds. Head from here in any direction and you'll find restaurants, shopping, and sights.

Lovely gathering place. A nice place to hang out while you're visiting the Cusco sites, the Plaza de Armas is surrounded by a majority of the typical tourist sites. Peaceful enough to just sit on one of the park benches and watch the world go by. Lots of restaurants overlooking the square as well, although as you'd expect the location jacks the price. Plenty of less expensive alternatives just off the square.
Must See!. Surrounded by churches, restaurants and shops. One of the central tourist Plazas within the city. A must see...

Beautiful, historic and plenty to do. We had a wonderful time walking around the Plaza. It was close to the winter solstice and thus there were festivities and parades. Historic churches to see and shop at the many boutique stores. Plenty of eateries to chose from and different styles. It felt safe and comfortable.

People watching at its best. Central to the town, the plaza is surrounded by cafes, shops and restaurants. There is activity from sun up to sun up. The Cusquenos don't ever seem to sleep. Find time to sit and sip a coca tea or a local beer at one of the establishments with a 2nd floor balcony and watch the show - musicians, dancers, artists...It's a beautiful way to enjoy the scenery and the culture in between visiting ruins. Oh, and look up to the Andes. Make sure you see "El Blanco Cristo" keeping watch over the city!
Hotel stay. Stayed at Plaza de Armas Hotel right on the square. Fantastic location, great breakfast & awesome roof top patio

Busy area but lots to see. There is lots of traffic in this area but also some wonderful sites as well. We were here recently while they were doing their celebrations with all the statues and it was very neat. The views from the main plaza are unique.

The best placa in Cusco. That's the main place in Cusco. Enjoy to take pictures, walk around or just observe. So many good restaurants are around. The architecture is very interisting. The local citizens are very friendly. I recommend you to walk a little bit more to the Municipal market were you can find local fruits and souvenirs with a better price.

Visit at night. This is the center of Inca life and night life. The plaza is beautiful at night as it is illuminated with light. It makes the old buildings and cathedrals appear more grand and majestic. There is lots to see and do, so plan on a minimum of two hours to walk around the plaza and it's surroundings streets.

Spanish Colonial Grandeur. It was a beautiful spot, with everything from fine dining, to McDonald's. Lots of shopping for souvenirs, and clean & safe.Despite the commercialism, you can still easily imagine what it was like, centuries ago.

Plaza de Armas. They had events every night with coustom parades. People will dress up on their typical dresses they wear. It was June ehen they celebrate the city of Cusco. Our hotel was just a few steps from the Plaza. Great location. Loved it.
Lovely. When we arrived at the Plaza de Armas it was just getting dark so it was lovely to see the lights coming on around the square.

Spanish architecture. This is a nice wide open plaza fronting historical buildings with Spanish influenced architecture. You can find buses and tours operating on the plaza where hawkers hand out brochures, and take you to a nearby office if you choose to take a tour. You are also likely to see elderly women in national dress carrying baby alpacas - available for a photograph (be prepared to pay about 50 cents). Don't be afraid, but be wary...mother and youngster teams are actively being pickpockets.

We absolutely loved Cusco!. Cusco is a wonderful city to visit. There are so many fabulous restaurants to choose from. We ate at a different place every night. There are many types of accommodations as well. Prices start around $25 USD per night for hostels. We stayed in a boutique hotel for $60 per night. We were not disappointed. The shopping in Cusco is the best in Peru. There is a nice selection of Alpaca available at very reasonable prices. Make sure your Alpaca has a tag saying it is 100%. Cusco is also the best place to buy silver jewelry.The Plaza de Armas is at the center of Cusco. It is surrounded by restaurants and shops. It is the perfect place shop, eat, and people-watch.

The gathering place. Individuals from all walks of life wander and intermingle in the Plaza. While we were there the native people were protesting the commercialization of Machu Picchu and that they were not receiving any of the tourist money that is spent there. We spent some time in the Starbucks over looking the Plaza, and in Paddy's Pub, the highest 100% Irish owned pub, at 11156 feet above sea level. There are some shops that we found interesting.
great for pictures. great place to be during the celebration of the week of June 24th. Place was very safe, lots of police and clean area.
Gorgeous . Have a coca-leaf tea at one of the cafés with the balconies overlooking the square. Sit outside, get acclimated, enjoy the gorgeous view.

Significance and Synchronicity. Significance acquired over centuries. A good place to rest and observe all kinds of people and goings-on. For me, it was a good place for chance encounters with people I'd already met elsewhere.
Beautiful plaza. The plaza is very beautful with the churches and the wooden balconies with the cusco flag flying in the wind. Be prepared to be bombarded by people trying to sell you things.
Excellent for people watching. Great place to walk around and hang out. In May and June numerous fantastic parades end here. Go inside the cathedral

Relax and People Watch. The square in the old town is very picturesque. There are a number of cafes and restaurants lining the square on the 2nd floor of the colonnaded buildings which are great for people watching.

Cusco is a Charming Town. The Plaza is the lively center of town for sure in Cusco, and therefore definitely worth seeing. There are many stores selling alpaca sweaters and scarves, pottery pieces and locally made woven scarves, jackets, table runners and more. There are also many very good restaurants to enjoy in the Plaza. Don't miss visiting the Cathedral. The architecture is stunning and the inside evokes the history of the city beautifully.

The heart of Cusco. During our visit the Plaza de Armas was packed each day with parades of colorful dancers and marching bands celebrating the city of Cusco, the capital of the Inca empire. The Plaza, which is impeccably maintained, is also the home to the Catholic Cathedral. Streets full of shops radiate out from the Plaza and all around it. Great restaurants look onto the Plaza and make for scenic dining.

Great place to relax and people watch. This Central Park in Cuzco is a beautiful place to sit and relax and catch your breath after a morning of walking up and down the streets of Cuzco. Fronting the cathedral and another church, it is surrounded by beautiful restored buildings transporting you to another era. Locals and tourists mingle in this busy square. This place should not be missed

The Heart of Cusco. Plaza de Armas is the epicenter of Cusco ---- its heart. It is the picture of Cusco that you always see. The plaza is dominated by the Cathedral and by the Jesuit Church. It is surrounded by the lovely two story buildings that house shops, restaurants and hotels. Almost daily there is some activity, either demonstrations, dancers or some sort of fiestas. We were there during the Feast of Corpus Christi -- what excitement -- colorful costumed paraders, bands and floats. Reminded me of St. Paddy's parade in NYC.

Always something going on!. This is a very nice traditional plaza anchored by not one, but two major churches. There seems to always be something going on in the plaza. When we were there, there were parades leading up to a big summer celebration.

Great People Watching. This Plaza was a great place to see some of the great churches on Cusco, but it's really great for people watching and experiencing Cusco. When we were there in Cusco many of the locals were practicing dance routines in the plaza in anticipation of their independence day celebration the week after. Every time we walked through the plaza we saw groups rehearsing. During the day we saw a number of school groups practicing and at night we saw a number of university groups rehearsing. It was so much fun to see and definitely a memorable experience. You will find the usual folks trying to sell you trinkets and other cheap souvenirs here, but you'll find that anywhere. Take a seat on one of the benches, take it all in and just say no to those guys if they approach you. You definitely need to take in the atmosphere of Cusco in the Plaza de Armas while here. Oh, and grab some great food at one of the nearby restaurants - there are so many great ones to choose from.

Playa de Armas. This is local public and tourist central in Cusco. If there is a celebration in Cusco, there will be festivity in the playa. Dancing, parades, speeches, etc. are all focused here, with few exceptions.

A must in Cusco. The main square in the center of Cusco is beautiful,busy and buzzing with energy.It is a great place for people watching however can be a bit tiring with people trying to clean your shoes and try to sell you anything from maps to lama and alpaca toys.It is not boring and we really enjoyed spending time there and chatting with the locals.

A few days in Peru . Great place the culture was on full display.A great spot in the world were it seems magical, yes it's a bit busy, loud, colorful, but I have to say the street vendors was a bit overwhelming to me. I loved seeing the history in the buildings, the culture in the people. But maybe because I stuck out like a thorn while I was there, I was asked to buy from artist with the same artwork, jewelry vendors with the same pieces, children with things like hats, pictures donations. Overall it's a beautiful location in the world and everyone should pass time in

Main Plaza of Cusco - Full of Energy. If you find yourself ever bored in Cusco - just walk to the main plaza and there is always to be some sort of activity going on. The square is beautifully lined with historic buildings, and many shops and restaurants to explore. There are multiple plazas in Cusco - this is the main one. Fun to sit and just people watch. You will be surprised at all the activity at night.
Bustling main square of Cusco. Always something going on in this square. The day we visited there was a citywide school dance competition with the children dressed and doing traditional dances.

What a site at Corpus Christi celebration. Excellent plaza, large with cathedral, church and portico'd buildings around. Pity the churches aren't floodlit at night. Gorgeous and of course the centre of activity with restaurants, travel agencies banks for ATM’s etc. Taxis tour the area and are very cheap by international standards, just agree a price first. We were there for a number of days including Corpus Christi. This was when the plaza was totally packed, and what a stunning interesting day. Fifteen saints and virgins, organized in processions arriving from different locations in the city to the cathedral of Cusco. Some of these are large and obviously heavy with dozens of men straining to carry them. Wow.

Lots to Do. We stayed near the Plaza and were able to visit several times. There were daily performance by school kids in the area that was lots of fun to see. There are so many shops to visit for all kinds of goodies.
A wander about Plaza de Armas. A beautiful plaza in the centre of Cusco. Wonderful historical buildings, great restaurants, and fun pubs.
Typical Small Town Square. This is the heart of Cusco with tons of great restaurants and markets. They have a huge celebration every Sunday, so it's crowded but worth it for the energy!

Beautiful! One of the best. Gorgeous and centrally-located, lots of restaurants, travel agencies, and hotels nearby. Easy place to get cash if you need an ATM, and nice place to sit down. Lots of tourists and a good meeting place if you're looking for one. There are lots of taxis and people who will ask you to look at their art/jewelry to buy, but they are usually polite and will go away if you tell them no thank you.

Where it is all happening.... Nice place to hangout and watch the world go by. There are often marches, military parades, music and dancing. Also a good place to pick up some local art work from the artists themselves, selling them around the plaza.
Beautiful. Loved this place!!! Any hotel near here will work. We were here 3 days and spent most of our time in this area.

nice place to visit. We were very lucky to be there during their Easter celebrations. It included local parades in their native dress and cultural aspects. There are several nice restaurants and shops also in the center of this town! Also, there is a starbucks. Interesting colonial town in peru!

Touristy as all. This is a beautiful square and you are likely to pass through it whether or not you try to. In the week I visited there were several parades and groups of children dancing. I love that, but you can't sit here for 5 minutes without "Pablo Picasso" trying to sell you art, kids asking for money, and others hounding you for a massage or a tour or to eat in their restaurant. Everyone is trying to make a buck here. I would also avoid most of the restaurants around here- go back a couple of blocks for better food.

Wonderful Plaza. By day or night, this plaza is stunning! Fun shopping, eating and incredible architecture all together. Be sure to chat with some of the locals as well. They have great stories and advice if you just ask around.

Historic!. The Plaza is a site not to be missed. The vendors are. Crowded and full of live, the place offers a fantastic view into the Incan and Spanish conquistador past. I consider it to be a must see.

Lively, beautiful plaza. Spend a whole day here people-watching on a bench in the center of the plaza, or from above in one of the several cafes around the square. There is always something going on. Parades, festivals, and it is simply fun to watch local people and tourists mingle

The Hub of Cuzco . There was always something happening in and around the Plaza. Maybe we just had great luck, I'm not sure. The Corpus Christi festival was in full swing day after day. There was also local food & hand craft markets and a political rally one day. It seemed to be always full of noise & colour.
The center of action in Cusco. Multiple great restaurants and great sites to see. Shopping, drinks, lunch/dinner, coffee shops, local crafts all kinds of interesting things to do and see.
A Must When You Visit Cusco. This is the center of the old town. Very picturesque with old cathedrals and a beautiful square . Surrounded by restaurants and shops.

Typical colonial looking square. very pretty and surrounded by quaint cafes on the outside. the cathedral is worth going into as are the other churces and the convent that frame the square. lots of people advertising walking tours here which are a good way to see the city! sometimes cut off from traffic which is good but keep an eye out for the common riots!

Captivating !!!. June is a very nice time to travel to Cusco.This place is very captivating with architecture.Nice to browse ,the people are not aggressive and you can feel safe .Lots of shops and restaurants .Truly loved being in cusco ,I enjoyed everything about this place .Artisans all displaying their products and culture at its very best!

Beautiful Town Center. Lots of colonial architecture in pristine condition. This is very typical of Latin American Town/City centers, but it is the cleanest most preserved I have seen in Peru or six other countries.

Great place to stroll about.. Cathedrals, museums and tons of restaurants, as well as a great place to people watch. Just don't take pictures of the women dressed in traditional Peruvian dress with baby alpacas. They will harangue you to give them money and $1 is not enough.
Action central. So much goes on in Plaza de Armas. Being there in June, we saw many parades, protests and general socializing. Don't walk on the grass!

Winter Solstice. Beginning in May and through June 21, there are important processions here on Sundays. Regional Groups from all around come and parade around the square all day chanting and dancing. A warm up to Winter Solstice. It was a lot of fun and very festive.
Nice place to relax°. The plaza is beautiful during the day and night, the shops and restaurants are all around. One of the amazing squares in the colonial old cities.

Visiting Cusco Square. This is right in the center of the city, the main square. Lots of restaurants and shops surrounding the square and nearby areas. Some type of activity or ceremony normally takes place during the weekend. While we were there, there was a military band and parade to promote mother's day and non violence ag women.

Enjoy people watching from the Balcony. Grabbed a decent meal (twice) above the MacDonalds, with a view from their balcony. Great for people watching, Pizza, Lomo Soltado,
and Happy Hour.

Beautiful place!. I just loved the old buildings located in this plaza and surrounding it. It's a great place to stroll around for a few hours. There are shops and restaurants as well. We happened to be there on a day where there were school children performing dances. That was too adorable! I would highly recommend stopping here.

Very active plaza. If you're in Cusco, you'll end up here for sure. And chances are there will be something going on. A festival, a parade, a party, a celebration, but even if not, it's a beautiful plaza with a nice fountain. A few peddlers, and mostly touristy shops surround but the plaza is very enjoyable.

Central plaza with intersting shops, restuarants and historical places.. The plaza attracts tourists and locals and was always busy.
The police presence made the plaza area very safe
beautifull. liked everything about the Plaza, beautiful during day and night with interesting shops and restaurants all around.

Main hub of activity. All the shops, restuaruants, and activity. It was beautiful and provided great insight into the culture.
Just don't go when its Corpus Christi - about 50,000 people flooded the area.
Sunny Day. Plaza de Armas is a delightful square situated among the mountains. It's a great spot to just relax and catch your breath for a few minutes...
A nice place to visit. A nice square surrounded by cathedrals. Great place to be photographed. We were lucky enough to see some traditional Peruvian dance.

Great attraction. This is the heart of cusco. not to mention the history of the square itself. From the square, you can see lots of beautiful churches and cathedrals. Up and down little alley ways from this plaza are little shops, big shops, hotels, hostels and delicious food. One thing I did notice is that there are dogs everywhere.
Nice place to relax and people watch. I loved this plaza. It is a great place to people watch. There are many restaurants and shops surrounding this plaza, so it is a great jumping off point.
Too Many Vendors. There were too many selling things. It became very frustrating to have people approach you constantly. It was clean. There were officers trying to control this but it was difficult.

Great place to watch the world go by. This is a really busy plaza, with lots of restaurants and shops, sitting in the park watching people was a lovely way to chill for a few hours. The worst thing is the number of hawkers trying to sell you everything from paintings to massages.

Cool spot!. Very cool places where tons of Peruvians and tourist come together. Shopping, food, entertainment etc... Just be careful to not fully believe anything the locals say. Its in there culture to for them to tell you what you want to hear. They basically agree with whatever you say.
Hub of the City. A bustling area of town where all your walking tours can start. Shopping and restaurants are abundant. A must to visit if you are in Cusco.

What an absolutely delightful square!. Plaza de Armas is steeped in history, religion and symbolism. While it was the centre of inca palaces, it also became the symbol of the history of conquistadors and the establishment of the catholic church (cathedral). It has a bloodied history with many a inca rebels being executed here.Today it is a perfect blend of some remnants of inca architecture but mostly colonial architecture with the white and yellow buildings with balconies. Plaza de arms is also adorned by two big churches on two of it's sides, representing the majority of catholic population in the country now.Being the centre of the 'Puma' from the incan Cuscio, it continues to the the centre of Modern Cusco and is an ABSOLUTELY MUST VIST site!

One of the most beautiful plazas in South America. Beautiful plaza, safe, and always something to see (mostly matches, dances, or singing). Right next to churches and (pricier) restaurants. Be sure to check out nortons or patty's pub and sit on the balcony facing the plaza.

Beautiful city square. The plaza must be seen during and day and if possible as dusk into the evening. Beautiful architecture, lots of lovely restaurants and it has still retained its Peruvian charm. A definite must see.

Mothers day visit. What a day to visit full of Families, but as I see lots of flowers and nice Spanish Architecture in one corner of the Plaza is a fountain. Still nice to walk in between folks and watching how Mothers were taken care off. Mothers day a big day in Peru.

Certainly a "must-see". It would be difficult to avoid this Plaza when visiting Cusco.So many attractions are found on and around it.Much, of course, is offered with the tourists in mind, but that is to be expected in a town as important to history as Cusco is.Bars, restaurants, stores in large numbers - good also for window-shopping.A pleasant experience.

When in Cusco, start here.. It's always a good idea to start at the main square when visiting any Latin city. Lots of restaurants and hotels are located here. There seemed to be some kind of parade or celebration every day!
Very busy and trafficy.. A great place to watch people and the commotion of the plaza from the second floors bars while having a beer.
Nice place!. Nice place to visit, walk, take pictures, shop, eat, there is night life bars too. You can also "shop" around for tours.

picturesque day or nite. This was the hub from which we learned the locations of all the key sites. The square in the morning is particularly beautiful- blue skies, the area has few people, and the church is lovely against the backdrop of the mountains. Great place to chill or regroup or meet your guide- and good eats around it (Limo) abound.

Center. Time spent at this square is very rewarding in terms of being able to see and experience the local lifestyle but one of the major factors that diminish the effects are the pestering vendors who can get a bit hard to neglect but apart from that I found this plaza rich in activity and pretty colorful too. One of the main views around here is the church and the statue. There are lots of restaurants ranging from star bucks to local cafes.
Awesome Sites. Purchased some artwork from an art student who ended up giving us an awesome tour of the city! We saw Sacsayhuaman and a few other sites and didn't pay a dime.

Great people watching. Great to people watch and enjoy the ambiance of Cusco. You get a really good feel for the history of the town here and it really is the most beautiful plaza to relax and meet fellow tourists and locals alike.

Scenic. This is the main square in Cusco. I assume that all tourist in Cusco will make there way down to the square. It's flanked on two sides with a stately cathedral and church. It seems to be a point of convergence for locals, tourists, and artisans/students. Only draw back are the numerous individuals trying to hawk their goods. One will get approached half a dozen times or more to buy knickknacks, paintings and other trinkets. Politely saying "no gracias" once did the trick most of the time.

Sit and watch. Another busy plaza in Peru surrounded by beautiful buildings. Sit in the sun and you will be approached by many people selling their wares and the young girls in national dress with their lambs.

Great sense of Cuzco. Cuzquenos love a parade or an event and they all start or go by here. Nice place to see the locals, and is well touristed, but less so than big European plazas. The locals still show up here to enjoy the sun and socialize. You will be badgered by trinket sellers. Good restos around the square, including the ever present Starbucks. Lots of shopping, from the high-end baby alpaca garments in the reputable stores to the maybe alpaca garments in the cheap shops, and there are lot oft those. Grant cathedrals in the peak of rococo style. To see the more local Cuzco walk 10 blocks west past Plaza San Francisco to the Mercado San Pedro on Saturday.
Great for people watching and sight seeing. I didn't like constantly being asked if I wanted a massage or buy a painting. Aside from that, the Plaza is the meeting place for tours, sights and dining.

The heart of Cusco. We stayed at the El Virrey hotel right on the square, so we experienced the plaza every time we walked outside. The cathedrals are great and the park is nice. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because of all the very high pressure street salesmen trying to sell trinkets, art, massages, etc. They don't take no for an answer and will follow you down the street. Other than that, the plaza is great.

Interesting Place to see the locals. It was so interesting to see demonstrations on May 1st, at the steps to the closed Cathedral, and also the local people sitting and enjoying the sun and good air, the faces and the people that want to sell you anything from fake wool scarfs or hats...to just people having an ice cream this is the Real Cusco.

Grab a bench and enjoy. Plaza de Armas is a very lively and pretty plaza in Cusco, and also the biggest. It is worth finding yourself a bench and kicking back and enjoy the scenery and the locals. Yes, there will be some locals that try and sell you stuff, but a simple no will send them away. You will find this in any city you travel too, so it is nothing different. There are a lot of little shops and restaurants around the plaza. If you are looking for some American food, there is an Irish pub nearby.

Cusco Plaza de Armas. Every city in Peru has a Plaza de Armas, this one was nicer than some of the others I visited. The water fountain seemed to be an attraction that most people wanted to have a picture in front of. There are some great restaurants just down the street, as well as good shopping and inexpensive relaxation massage in close proximity to Plaza de Armas.

Great exchange rate at the Casas de Cambio. You'll be accosted for shoeshines and trinkets but the plaza is the heart of the city, and it's a great place to get a sense of Cusco. Skip the bank for currency exchange. Just go to any Casa de Cambio around the plaza - no passport needed and the rates are good. Visit La Catedral, browse the alpaca sweater stores, and enjoy a meal at any number of restaurants. Chez Maggy a few blocks up has great pizza.

Good time spent. Went to several museums within easy access of the plaza. They had many shops, high end and low end to view. There are money exchanges.. best is Casa de Cambia. Can walk a little more down Sol Street (?) to the banks. Great exchange rates there. Lots of people peddling their wares, but they are not intrusive.

Now a pedestrian plaza. When we first arrived there were cars in this plaza, kind of scary to try to get across a street and when our driver was driving through it I admit I was terrified. The very last night we were there the Mayor had declared this to be a pedestrian plaza or I should add a dog plaza as well because feral dogs are everywhere.

I really hoped to like this place, but. ... because of the tons of locals badgering you to buy trinkets or avail of their services really takes away from the whole experience. I wanted to sit and take in the sights but the constant (and I mean constant!) badgering really put me off. But it really is beautiful: with the cafes and churches around you. it is especially beautiful at night with all the street lights on.

Lively & Likable!. Plaza de Armas is the heart of Cusco for both architecture and tourism. It is presided over by two magnificent churches and surrounded by arcades and lovely houses with ornate carved wood balconies and terra cotta roofs. In the center of the square is a large statue of Pachacutec, an Inca warrior. There are plenty of locals gathering, attending church and partaking in various activities. Vendor activity is a constant, but is easily dismissed. This is a great place to look for souvenirs, grab a bite to eat or just people watch. Many craft shops and stalls as well as restaurants are on nearby streets.

Great tourist spot to visit and enjoy. The Central Plaza in Cuzco is well laid out with plenty of entertainment, restaurants and up market shops for strolling past of for shopping. Liked the bustle of the place. Just had to be aware of pickpockets... Be alert at all times. Liked the entertainment I outside the cathedral.
Beautiful at night. Very pretty square with churches and cafe balconies to watch people. The constant badgering by locals to buy something though takes away from the experience.
beautiful. beautiful place, is the center of cusco and inca culture. You can sit there for hour and you wom't get tired or bored.
Nice place to relax. Our hostel is near to this Plaza. The day view is beautiful and relaxing. It gives us a nice feeling of Latin America!

Beautiful Space. On Good Friday we arrived to action aplenty in the Plaza. Ceremony involving armed services, marching band, flag raising and spectacular gun salutes. It was amazing. The following Saturday we were treated to village dance demonstration that were a lively spectacle. It was such a privilege to see the Peruvian culture so alive.

Nice place for an evening stroll. Pretty much the heart of Cusco, with the Cathedral at one side of the square, it is a popular place to stroll or sit in the sun during the day, and there are many restaurants around the square for dinner or lunch.

A Hive of Activity. Busy, thriving location anchored by a central fountain. Stores, cafes and travel places are around this plaza. On one side is the imposing Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption of the Virgin completed in 1654. On this day there was a cultural festival with dancers and performers from all areas of Peru. There are usually many persistent vendors selling handmade clothing, jewellery and handicrafts. If you are not interested, simply say no gracias...
