There is a tourist police presence around the square so the place feel safe even at night.
Exploring the square. After the "official" tour, liked wandering on our own to check out the square and restaurants. Found a great little sweater shop to make my last purchase.

big, beautiful, and full of life.. plaza de armas is for sure the center of cusco. lots going on, historic churches, great shopping, food, coffee, beverages all around. a very large, open plaza, plenty of room to wander and photograph.

The center. The center of town.. beautiful.. never gets old... Just walk around and take it all in.. Lots of stores, hotels. tours, $ money exchange offices.. everything is here and you should stay close to it..

Beautiful central square. This is a great place to spend some time people watching and just strolling around. High concentration of shops and restaurants all around the area. Two large cathedrals dominate the square and make for great picture backdrops. The downside of the plaza de armas is that it has a lot of traffic and is crowded most of the day.
Hang around. The plaza was so beautiful I had to sit around and spend some time. The cathedrals nearby completes the area. I loved hanging around the benches!

Well justified UNESCO world heritage status. This atmospheric square has two grand churches and well preserved buildings all around in a stunning setting. Although Starbucks and KFC are to be found in the square you will not be able to find their logos. It is possible to spend a very pleasant time enjoying a local beer in one of the many cafes with balconies overlooking the plaza.
Cool old plaza. Amazing old buildings. Check out Paddy's pub for a safe tourist haven. Don't mind the harassing locals trying to shine your shoes and sell you a massage

Great people watching plaza. Fun shops surrounding the plaza for browsing and souvenir purchases. Clean, nicely landscaped plaza with beautiful fountain and benches for relaxing. Disliked locals constantly pestering us to buy their wares. Concerned about the welfare of the friendly, sweet dogs running loose and napping in the plaza.

beautiful square with colonnades, at the center of the city. It is the center of the activities of the city. It is surrounded by arcades and by the cathedral. At night, the square is lit up in a pretty way.

(literally Weapons Square, but better translated as Parade Square or parade ground). The Plaza de Armas is a busy city park bounded by a cathedral and a church, several great restaurants (Limo, Inka Grill, La Estancia Andina ), a juice shop ( Yajuu ), the Perurail Agency office, tour service agencies, and shops selling alpaca clothing, jewelry, and hiking gear. There is also a currency exchange and even a Western Union Office. Peruvian children and adults dressed in colorful traditional Peruvian costume and usually holding a baby llama politely suggest for you to have your photo taken them. If you do, remember to give them a few sols for the honor. Artists walk around the Plaza offering sell their work, one man showed me every painting he had for sale, the ones that I liked had spiritual colors; He explained that he had consumed Ayahuasca (a tropical vine native to the Amazon region, noted for its hallucinogenic properties) and that it had inspired him to paint. I chose to eat around 3:30-4:00 pm to avoid the rush hour. I sat by a window facing the park filled with locals and tourists and along with a fine meal I enjoyed the people watching opportunity. On a street named Triunfo, you will find Peruvian women offering massage therapy, if you chose to partake request a 30 minute massage to see if they have the skill or they are just amateurs; if you enjoy their energy and skill you can request a longer session. I chose a woman outside of 338 Triunfo, her name is Vilma, she massaged me at 9:30 am for an hour ( 75 sols about $24 USD ) Her studio is on the second floor, Vilma is a young Peruvian woman, she enjoyed my company and I relaxed to her touch. Before leaving, I booked an hour Inca massage for 5:00 pm ( I gave her 25 sols to hold the reservation).The Inca massage is 100.00 sols for one hour; She used coca cream and baby oil to massage me. A pot of hot water with eucalyptus and muna leaves was placed below the massage table to provide a kind of aromatherapy. She also used hot stones to accompany the massage. The morning and late afternoon massage was exactly what my mind and body needed after the 4 day trek on the Inca Trail to Machu Pichu.
Don't miss. Lovely and interesting plaza with lots to see and several great restaurants. Our tour of the cathedral was fascinating. It is a beautiful cathedral with spectacular gold altars.
Really nice. One of the most vibrant squares in the colonial old cities in latin america. Book time to simply hang around on it.

A Must See. This was one of my favorite things about Cusco. It is very lively, often with local events going on. There is surprisingly ( or not surprisingly) a Starbucks and an irish pub ( who thought lol) and there are tons of vendors that will try to sell you stuff but its a fun place to go and a must see if you are in the area. Always something to see/do and its pretty!
plaza de armas. I saw it at night and it was beautiful. We enjoyed the cool of the evening and there were not so many people around.

Practice 'no gracias' before you go!. OK - first impressions are mixed. Irish pub...local touts...Starbucks. Not what you expect when you first arrive. The restaurant on the square we got drawn into was awful (Papillon). But having been to the square a few times now it gets under your skin and you can't help but being impressed by the colonial architecture. Almost equally impressive are the lady traffic cops at rush hour!
Lively. A lively square, full of restaurants, both local and international. Many celebrations - parades on 2 of 4 days we spent in Cusco. Very fun and easily accessible.

Center of Activity. When we were there a dance competition among various local groups was going on. Very colourful and entertaining. There are many shops, restaurants and vendors in and around this square

You'll Be Here, it's Inevitable. If you come to do anything in Cusco, most likely you'll walk through this plaza. It's a pedestrian zone which is really lovely. Lots of shops, restaurants and sights line the 4 sides and there always seemed to be something going on. On the multiple occasions we wandered through the plaza we saw all sorts of things-- groups practicing dancing, musicians, etc.

A pleasant, bustling plaza. At night it's even better, when all is quiet and mostly empty! It's a place you can go and spend a couple of days at because so many of the museums and cathedrals are right off the plaza. It's flanked by crap like KFC and Starbucks, but they are housed in beautiful colonial buildings so it doesn't really matter. A very impressive place to imagine what things were like before the Spanish, especially as most buildings are built from Inca made stone.

More Pros than Cons. As mentioned, there are lots of street vendors buzzing in your face constantly, but they aren't overly aggressive and will leave you alone when you say no. But just as quickly there will be another that you will have to brush off. The plaza is a bit of a tourist trap, but at least it's safe. Otherwise, those are the few cons we saw. The pros are that it feels safe and it's a beautiful location for photos day AND night. If you crave familiarity, you'll find that here in the shape of the reliable McDs, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Starbucks in just the prettiest buildings ever! Our guide told us that just two weeks before our arrival, the city had decided to officially close off the plaza to all vehicles. It was a heated controversy among the locals, but in the end, our tour guide even said it was a good decision. You can now freely cross the streets in the plaza and it feels safe. Although the sense of safety could also be because there are extra guards on duty, not just for the churches but to also make sure that locals are not demonstrating against the street closures.

Center of Everything. This plaza is Cusco's center. It is lively with vendors, performers, people watchers. If you're planning on buying from the vendors remember to bargain with them -- but gently. Bargaining is part of their culture but their poverty is extreme so provide dignity along with the enjoyment of negotiation. It'll be a win-win for you both.

Beautiful days and nights. The centre of everything a traveler needs even though there're too many sellers trying to sell souvenirs. However, the plaza is beautiful especially at night when you can see shining yellow lights from houses uphill, look like stars. Standing at the fountain in the middle and looking around offers you a beautiful Cuzco skyline. You can go up the Compania de Jesus Cathedral for the bird-eye's view of the plaza
Beautiful. It is the center square. There are 2 beautiful churches you must see. There are shops and plenty of places to eat. It's safe to walk around even at night. I saw plenty of cops in the area.

Nice place and very touristic. The Plaza de Armas is the heart of Cusco city center. The center of the square is a nice place to rest on the benches, soak up the gardens, and admire the fountain in the center. The area is also very lively and beautiful at night lit up with spotlights. have pently of Hostels and restaurants around.

Too many sellers. It is a nice square but don't expect to be able to stand and enjoy and certainly not sit and enjoy. My spouse and I tried to sit on a park bench in the middle of the square and in less than 5 minutes we had a least 5 people come up to us trying to sell something or beg. It got tiring saying no so many times. Even just standing by the cathedral we were continued to be bombarded by sellers. We couldn't really enjoy the plaza.Like other cities in Peru we didn't like the trash in the streets and stray dogs.
Beautiful place. Beautiful place with lots of restaurants, shops, banks and historic buildings around. Lots of space to enjoy the sun and security around the plaza.
Very nice plaza. Open and green, surrounded by ships and restaurants. Expect to get hassled by street vendors, tour operators and massueses though.
Central Plaza in Cusco. huge plaza, surrounded by churches, restaurants and shops. Just a short walk to Inka walls with amazing stonework.

A nice square with beautiful scenic views. This is a nice place to relax in the sun and a lot of historical sites around the square. Also a nice view over the hills. Touristy, oh yes but still the site you will remember when leaving Cusco.
Clean and pedestrian-friendly. This place has really changed over the years. When we were there, cars were banned, it was clean and showed off the natural beauty of its setting.

Part stunning, part tourist trap. Wow - well this is the most beautiful city square in Peru, and probably South America. Particularly at night where the golden street light, twinkling lights on the hillsides and a clear night sky make for amazing photos. There's no way you should ever miss it.Just be ready to bat off rascals at every turn selling you rubbish art, dodgy massages 'alpaca' jumpers and plastic jewellery. Stand still for three seconds and you will see!It's a small price to pay though, so enjoy.For more Cusco travel tips, check out our blog:https://ednaventures.wordpress.com/2014/12/09/cuzco-a-beautiful-countdown/

timeless.... the plaza de armas as does the historic center transports you back in time. the plaza has the exquisite gold guilded statue of the spanish conquistador, Francisco Pizarro and fountains. the cathedral of cusco looks beautiful from different vantage points. One can loiter around for hours and take in the scene from the balconies of one of the restaurants/ cafes surrounding the plaza.

Loitering is elevated to an art form here. Such a beautiful plaza. Great people watching. Great dog watching (lots of friendly strays). Beautiful statues. Cathedrals on two sides. Flash mobs. TV newscasts. And a Starbucks.

Tourist Trap Central. Beautiful grounds. Surrounded by tourist trap places like Starbucks, McDonalds and KFC. Want a massage? Plenty of girls handing out flyers...not what I came to Cusco for. One highlight was Paddys Pub in the corner upstairs.

Nice place to walk around. While I was working in Cuzco I decided to visit this plaza and enjoy the "plaza"This is where the Cathedral is. Also you'll find different shops, restaurants and museums You can just seat on benches and just see people walking around. It's different if you at night with the lights or if you go during the day. There are usually lots I lots people walking around.

Day and Night Time Fun!. You never know what you're going to find! By day, the plaza is filled with tourists enjoying visiting the cathedral and two churches, the shopping and restaurants, and the fountain in the center of the square. We returned in the evening and were treated to street dancers (some dressed in traditional clothing and the other group dressed in street clothes). Then, to add to our enjoyment, a wedding party exited the cathedral and we got to enjoy seeing the bride and groom in their wedding finery as well as all their guests exiting the cathedral. What a treat!
Gorgeous place. Beautiful, but you'll have to live with the peddlers and their wares. It's not bad though and can be fun.

Expansive Plaza de Armas surrounded by churches. Three churches including the impressive cathedral makes this a must stop. Need to see the Inca Palace foundation upon which the cathedral sits to understand the 16th century link between the two empires. In the middle of the Plaza is a large statue of the Inca lording it over everything. Strange to see a KFC next door to the cathedral but have no fear, our guide told us tongue in cheek that it's the newest restaurant Kentucky Fried Cuy (that's gunea pig)

Lovely Plaza. Lovely place to visit in Cusco, plenty of good shops and restaurants, keep away from touts though that seem to congregate in plaza. Even western style restaurants bu8t kept withon old facades.

Beautiful but crowded. It's a great place to hang out while in Cusco. One thing you should get used to is saying no to all the streetvendors. And please, stop giving money to children or buying from them. They should go to school and have a childhood.
Center of Tourism in Cusco.. The Plaza is a great central location in Cusco. It's surrounded by load of shops and restaurants and of course the Cathedral is a must see.
A MUST SEE. Day and Night, be sure to visit this plaza both times. It is lively and scenic. You will want to take some time to sit and watch the activity. This is a must see in Cusco.
Spanish buildings. A mix of Inca and Spanish buildings with cathedral, shops churches, so clean and tidy with beautiful flowers in the central plaza
Ideal place for people watching. It's the centre of Cuzco.. Nice place to chill out and watch locals and tourists daily lives. It also has an amazing view of the cathedral and St Loreto Church.
Incredible scenery. One of the best plazas I've ever seen! Best time: just before sunset with the beautiful (yet very stip) hills of Cuzco at the background and the wonderful lights on...magic

Nice and peaceful. Great place to hang out or meet people. Nice and central to cusco and many tourist attractions around the square. Arranged to meet people by the fountain and instantly found them. It has a nice feel to it with the calming water and the the view of the hills behind the city. Surrounded by some nice architecture of the churches it also makes for some nice photos. Just be warned that the grass may be nice and pretty but your not allowed to sit or walk on it.
The spot to be. Plaza de Armas is the center of Cusco... surrounded by great restaurants, shopping and a few churches. This is a terrific place to sit on a bench and people watch.

Plaza activity was great. We spent time wandering all over the Plaza as it had so many interesting attractions to see. Many people were selling their trinkets, which we found fun to barter with. We also found a quaint Alpaca Store to purchase our sweaters and scarves.

Nice little place to walk around an visit.. This is a good example of a South American Plaza de Armas. Very nice church and central square with lots of services around it. Restaurants, banks and the market are very close. Very safe and comfortable to relax, hang out or sight see.
Lovely place. The plaza is impressive, the cathedral, the fountain, the monument, it all makes it a very nice location .
Take your time. Take you time around the square. The surroundings are very pleasant and there are a lot of sights to see. To just hang on the square is nice as well.

Take you time to look around. The plaza de armas at cusco it's a beautiful place to go and enjoy a coffee or go eat in one of the many restaurants that have a balcony overlooking the plaza. You can also get pictures with the native Indians who sometimes have baby llamas or baby goats with them and ofer you to take a picture with them. Just be careful at night because pickpocket can happen if you are distracted specially if little kids try to get your attention.

Safe & Pleasant. We were staying at a hotel near this square, so we were able to see it day and night. It is a really nice square at any time of the day, it is filled with locals and tourists, there are always taxis roaming around looking for work. There is usually a police presence during the day, they try to control the shoe shiners and the walking vendors from bothering you in the square, even though we didn´t mind too much. But their presence is always appreciated.The square is surrounded by night clubs and provides a place to relax when you want fresh air.

Historical and picturesque. Walking onto the plaza...a diverse perspective of the historical and contemporary views...engaging, with the local community and tourists. Restaurants and venues attracted our attention, and we visited numerous times during our stay in Cusco.

Great place to stroll around . Very interesting place to just walk around and experience the people and culture of cusco.
With lots of areas to be grab something to eat or drink it's an area not to be missed.
Mind you being the heart of the town it's hard to walk around Cusco with out running into this gem of a place,

Worth a stroll. We visited at night and during the day. It is a nice plaza with a lot of side streets with interesting shops. The main plaza has The Cathedral which is beautiful. The area around the square is filled with shops and restaurants. Kuna is located here and they were having an awesome sale for top Llama clothing and accessories. As a side, we were told the best prices would be in Cuzco but that is not necessarily true.

Great place for night visit. We were here yesterday during the day and it was hot. We were able to walk around in our tour for a short time and that was enough. This plaza is very nice, clean and well kept. Lots of people around around and at no point in time we felt unsafe or insecure.It was at night that we ended up going to a buffet restaurant facing the plaza which was great. The food was great and the entertainment was wonderful. It definitely brought the culture of music and dance together for any tourist to appreciate. Highly recommend doing that if this is going to be a short visit to Cuzco.

Seconde best Plaza de Armas. My favourite Plaza de Armas in Peru after Arequipa's. I like the vibe, the Pachacutec statue as well as the colonial buildings with their arches and wooden balconies that surround the plaza.
Beautiful central plaza. Surrounded by lots of beautiful churches and colonial buildings Cusco's Plaza de Armas is not to be missed!
Something happening all the time. Great plaza, never know what you are going to see there. Great for people watching and relaxing. a must on Sundays, to see any parades.
one of best plaza de arms. especially in the night. the cathedral and church of san ignacio on two sides and porticos on the other two sides..gardens in the centre..

Lively square. There is plenty to do and see around the square, you will find lots of people trying to sell you things, hats, keying's, paintings, and entice you into their restaurants etc... but once you have said no they leave you alone quite quickly. We found ourselves in many of the pubs/restaurants with a balcony so we could people watch and take in the sights.

Centre of Cusco. We visited when the festivities were in full swing, in February. Wonderful market stalls and food stalls selling a huge variety of artefacts, clothing and of course food. Couldn't bring myself to eat the Guinea pigs so went for the local version of Menu Del Dia and very tasty it was too. Lots of restaurants around the square for eating lunchtime and evenings. See my other reviews.

Centre to enjoy. Great place to sit and watch people go about their daily lives. Lots happening in this large square from locals selling their wares to tourists moving round town. Bars and restaurants close by.

Plaza . This is the center of everything in Cusco. They have a few good restaurants in this area as well. They have a couple good bars as well.
Instagram: @tommiesox

Charming and Unique. My girlfriend and I loved old town Cusco, especially Plaza de Armas. There's great restaurants with balconies overlooking the square. The churches are some of the best we've seen in the world. Excellent people watching and great views.

Sunday in a Catholic City. From quiet early morning , with couples and children off to some church, the Square changed, by 10.00 am into a place for a Rally of groups concerned with "Education" As the groups had banners and men and women were dressed in matching suits and marched across a review stand, I am not sure what that had to do woth education. But hey, all to their own ! It was disconcerting or, rather, funny, to see some groups try marching stiff-kneed, out of step. Proud but need drilling, guys !The Plaza is large and a green park inset with paths and a statue. Shops surround the square - small and varied. All in all, a better Plaza than most. After all, Cusco is the capital of the Region and the Qusquenos see them selves as the correct capital of Peru.

Stop and Enjoy It. Plaza de Armas is the center of both old and new Cusco. As with other town squares, it is ringed with significant architecture and history that is not to be missed. However, there are also many good restaurants, bars and night clubs in and near the square so it can be the center of your visit. In general, the area is safe by day and, if you are careful, safe by night too. But I would challenge you to stop and spend some time just sitting and enjoying the plaza. It's something that we don't do enough of as tourists.
nice place to hang out and enjoy the atmosphere. the town center. lots of resturants around the square and lots of benches to sit on and watch the world go by
The Center of Attention. This plaza is the center of attention and activity in Cusco. A great place to spend a few hours just relaxing and people watching.

very interesting. one of the best main square in peru, this plaza de armas is surrounded by many important and interesting buildings. very worth spending a couple hours in relax watching the daily life of peruvian streaming in front of u

Plaza de Armas center of everything in Cuzco. I booked a hostel 5 blocks away from the Plaza de Armas. It was the hostel Mallqui. Most of the hostels in the area cost $10-$20. Hostel Mallqui was exceptional with breakfast included with private room and bath with HBO for $17 per night. Everything you will need is in the Plaza de Armas area. Numerous tour agencies, restaurants, bars. Friday and Saturday nights were the most lively.

The unavoidable hub, well worth seeing. It's a beautiful square which really feels like the centre of town. It has the fantastic cathedral on one side and the equally fantastic Jesuit church on another. And when the Peruvian farmers revolt in support of their demands for subsidies, this is where they congregate for demonstrations and speeches! Sadly your evening strolls in the square will be punctuated several times a minute by restaurant touts, tour touts and people trying to sell you anything and everything. Be Zen and float through it! There are two good places to watch the world go by from the second floor (1st if you are English): Paddy's Bar, and Starbucks. The church/cathedral tours and a sit down for coffee will take you 2-4 hours depending on your interests.

Nice to take in the local activities. I enjoyed sitting in the square watching both the tourists and locals milling around. There are lots of restaurants around the square and of course the Cathedral. Plus for some of us, a Starbucks that has a view of all the activities.

Not that interesting in and of itself. The square itself has the cathedral on it, and you will definitely walk through it many times on your way to somewhere else. But the square itself isn't that exciting. There are lots of people hassling you to get your shoes shined or buy bad drawings or take a photo with a baby goat or llama (we got hit up 57 times today). There are some touristy restaurants and shops on the square itself. But most of what's interesting in Cusco (other than the cathedral) is somewhere else.

The heart of Cusco. Enjoyed a rally and celebration on the day we were here with singing and local dancing. Enjoyed walking through all the outlying streets and shopping. Had to say no more than a million times, but they were respectful. What a beautiful place!

A vista of the people of Cusco. I stood in the center of Huacaypata and saw the stone of the 12 Anges, the Inca walls of Inti Q'ijillo and the colonial Cathedral. Where else can you turn and see so much history and life.
The center of everything. You can go anywhere from there. On a waling distance you may get to know a lot of Cuzco. The Cathedral... is just amazing

Plaza de Armas. very pretty main square with nice view of surrounding area; lots of restaurants and churches; the large cathedral is worth the visit inside; if you encounter vendors trying to sell their wares, they will take "no" for an answer and leave you alone....good prices though.

Charming Plaza. The Plaza is beautiful, surrounded by churches and shops. We were there on beautiful days and people were enjoying sitting on benches and sauntering through the Plaza. The Tourist Police keep traffic and vendors moving on. I love Cusco and the Plaza de Armas was lovely.

Great place to people watch and explore the side streets. The central hub of Cusco and the place that you start to explore this great city.Each side street is full of the unexpected and unique.Ranging from the chocolate museums to spiritual holistic worship and the abundance of cafes and restaurants and museums.Watch out for the street police on Segways who disperse the street vendors with their paintings whilst they plead with you to part with your money whilst sitting in the square.This place is my favourite in Cusco and one I will never forget

Great place to visit and hang out. Beautiful square in the middle of the city with churches, museums, dining, and shopping all close by. Loved the architecture and history of the buildings and the vibe of the area was great with businesses, tourists, street vendors, and locals mixing together in the square area.

Central and bustling. The Plaza de Armas is central in Cusco and everything you're likely to visit is within a couple of blocks walking distance.There is a hive of activity and you'll spend a lot of time fending off offers of massages, tours and tourist goods.There are many restaurants and it is a great place to people watch

take a walk aside. do not follow the crowd - make sure you step a side - different view. ery interesting. make sure you have your camera charged and enough memory on the card. best to get few linse - close up and long shoot.

No gracias. Ha. . I stayed for a month in cusco three years ago. The square is full of activity, you can sit by the fountain for many an hour, just sitting, you can find a spot in the Irish bar overlooking it to just take in the sites. Visit the LEK bar for salsa lesson at night. Or eat at the many restaurants surrounding the square. Learn one thing in Spanish, " no gracias" as You will get hassled by inca massage women, kids selling stuff, locals in ancient dress selling selfies with them, but it's all good humoured, I made friends with a couple of street kids, they are funny and very polite. If you meet Alfredo say hello. :)Loved it here in cusco, chill with the locals they are real nice when you make the effort.

Very interesting square . Compare to other country's city, this may not be the most beautiful square, but it is the most interesting one. Sit at square you will get a lot of vendors come to ask for buying their stuffs. From small key chain to charango. The good thing is they will not bug you when you said no to them. I think the square at night is better than day time.

Center point in Cusco. We walked from our hotel to Plaza de Armas, the main center point of Cusco. Beautiful place to visit, the big cathedral of Cusco, another beautiful Church in Main Square, Iglesia La Compania. Many different restaurants on the second floors around the square, overlooking Plaza de Armas. Site streets and small alleys off the main square, interesting walk you will find local stores, restaurants, handicrafts, etc. You also can walk to Plaza San Francisco many local street food stands on Sundays, and continue to Mercado Central de San Pedro (Local Super Market) to experience the local hang out and Peruvian foods. You can also find and book different day tours in this area including boarding Cusco Sight-seeing Bus. A must place to explore, while you are in Cusco....

The heart beat of Cusco. The Plaza de Armas is a wonderful square in the Centro Historico de Cusco with some green space and benches for taking a break and just people watching - very enjoyable. The architechure around the square is fascinating complete with a cathedral, church and colonial buildings. A few historic Inca streets lead off the square - there's always something interesting to see around a corner. On the square itself are several restaurants, banks, shops, etc. The plaza seems to be the heart beat of Cusco. And if your hotel is within ear shot you will continue to hear that beat through the night especially on weekends....

Great restaurants near the Plaza. The Plaza de Armas was beautiful at night. It was all lit up with the cathedral in the background and the lights from all the homes in the hills surrounding. We walked from our hotel which was about twenty minutes away. We did a walking tour of the city. Many of the attractions were within walking distance of our hotel including the central market place.

Start Here in Cusco. The Plaza is the center of most activity in Cusco. This is where you want to start. Everything in town branches out from the main square. Lots of great little sidestreets to go explore. Plenty of restaruants, lots of churches, nice little parks.

Cusco's plaza. Seems time stood still, beautiful churches around it, shops, restaurants, drug stores. Lots of massage girls, clean and decent. As a matter of fact my brother dropped his passport while gettingone didn't realize it 'till he saw the girl waiting for him at the hotel to give it back.

Spend some time. If you are in Cuzco, you ought not miss the plaza. A great place for walking about or hanging out. Numerous restaurants to choose from. Shops worth exploring. Hike up the side streets for the views and fewer tourists. Historic sites nearby are worth your time. And return in the evening for a different "feel."
Nice Plaza. Nice plaza of Cuzco, around this wonderful area, it is located many churches and nice colonial restaurants, the views are much better than other places.

Colonial. you can still see the original Inca culture along with the Spanish colonial influence. The cathedral is magnificent and you can see the native Peruvian's as well as foreign tourist enjoying the beautiful plaza.

beautiful but lots of street vendorsq. You will get hassled if you sit on the park bench for long. Still a lovely view and experience. Definitely try some of the 1 sol treats for sale: We had the quail eggs, water melon, as well as churros, pop corn, and the street corn. Yum
history. Center of the ere of spanish govern. Great cathedral is here.

The central square. One of the most beautiful colonial Spanish central squares that I have been in the new world. The most important buildings of cusco are here except the santo domingo church. Don't eat in the restaurants on the sides of the square they look like total rip offs.

Typical city plaza. This Plaza de Armas is charming in that it is surrounded by ornate historic buildings and cobblestone roads. Tourists abound but keep an eye out for hustlers. Colorful local children will approach with a baby goat in tow only to beg you for $ to pose for a picture. Adorable though. The fountain in the center is small by comparison to most cities but still works nicely with the cathedral in the backdrop for pictures.

Beautiful square at the heart of Cusco. Must see square going through the historical center of Cusco. It's a good reference to find restaurants and fancier shops, if that's your thing. Depending on when you visit Cusco, expressions of popular culture can be seen, such as the Carnaval parties.

A beautiful centro square. This is a very large centro square with a beautiful church but also lovely green space and benches. All around the square are interesting shops and services. For example, Peru Rail has an office in the square so you can plan your trip to Machu Picchu with them. A nice place to relax for a little while.

Sit for a while and people watch. Nice place to grab a drink or a cup of coffee, pull up a stair and people watch. The street vendors can be a bit annoying but most are not too pushy. Just relax and enjoy the view.
cute plaza. when i have been there i could enjoy the view, and the churchs of the cusco, with a agreable climate, also the friendly people, all is in order, really save.

The sacred place of tears. Best place for a picture, La compañia de Jesus Church or the Jesuits church. the stone porticos with names of the products sold many years agoand of course now Starbucks, McDonalds o KFC,still Cusco´s main meeting place.
Nice hangout downtown kind of place. Restaurants, massage, catedral, local shopping, chocklates, hotels - CHECK ... very quaint square with loads of entertainment, great to hang out by just walking
Lovely views. Nice gardens, very clean, with benches for sitting. Great views of the cathedral and the surrounding square of Cusco. Worth a visit.

Enjoyable place.. First, the weather was good, a bit of a nip in the air early morning (6am) but very peaceful at that time and brilliant for photo's. Plentyu of bar restaurants in the area and ATM also. An unreal feeling when you look up toward the east and see all the TV/Communication masts on a denuded mountain. Later in the day plenty of tourists and seemingly happy locals which I found very colourful and enjoyable.

Historical Centre of Cusco. Has been cleaned up since my last visit in 1998. Workers were busy planting flowers. No garbage laying around and no beggars.The church is worth a visit. For a nice view of the square have a drink or lunch at Paddy's Pub.

the meeting place of Cusco. it is not only the main square of the city with a statue of the first Inca king, Manco Capac. It is also full of life. Just sit there and enjoy looking around. Around 10:30, join there one of the several free walking tours, very interesting!

nice relaxing area. Although, historically this place is known for sad stories. Currently, it is a place to sit and relax. You can sit at the steps of the cathedral in front of plaza-de armas or with in the park where you can be a spectator of day-to-day routine, other tourists. It is a great public park in the heart of town. All the shopping and dining is around that area.
Quite and calm place. I liked almost all, everything is surrounding the plaza.many bars restaurants travel agents, close to all the atractions

The "Heart" of the City of Cusco. As in most Spanish cities, the plaza or city square is the most important feature. As such, the Plaza de Armas is the "Heart" of the City of Cusco. Around the plaza are situated several buildings - remnants of the Inca Empire and Cathedral from the Spanish times. A visit gives a glimpse of Inca and Spanish architecture.
Touristy, but pleasant. If you can handle the touristy feel to this area, there all lots of hidden gems nearby. People will always be trying to sell you something.

Beautiful Park. The main park of Cusco's historic center. Good atmosphere, lots of good restaurants, churches and stores around the park. We used to go there to relax and buy souvenirs. You can't visit Cusco without going there.

The plaza is hot & sunny, there's no shade anywhere!. There wasn't a shady area in sight, the hot temperatures made it hard to take. There's the typical statue and it is surrounded by the mandatory church, stores all around the other sides. Vendors and tourists everywhere. About what you find in every Plaza de Armas all around the Andean countries.

Beware the annoying vendors!. This plaza itself is really lovely. I was there in December, and enjoyed walking around this area, where there were colorful trees, pretty flowers, grassy lawns, picnic benches on which to rest. Across the street from the plaza are some great restaurants, the stately Santo Domingo Cathedral, and more. My only gripe (which is why this is a 4-star and not a 5-star), is that the place is crawling with vendors & touts, who follow & pester & beseech & harass. Ugh. After spending several days fighting through this crowd, I learned to sneak around the block, thus avoiding the touts and reaching my destination in a more circuitous manner.
One of the Best Places in Peru. No big Signs for McDonalds or Starbucks. Just very decent. Buildings are maintained very well. Christmas Decoration was very nice.

Great shopping & Beautiful Church!!!. This was fun. Just be careful when shopping. Most people know you are a tourist and will take complete advantage of that. You can usually bargain them down half the price. Don't go into the acutaul stores in Plaza de Armas, go to the side shops - they're cheaper.

Spend an afternoon people watching!. We spent an afternoon in the sun for hours just people watching.... Yes you will have locals coming up to try to sell you things, they are working so don't get mad, they are just trying to get in on the tourist action! Many locals would come with their dogs not on leash, cute to watch them play. Very safe, tourist police everywhere
Impossible to miss even if you want to. The quad is where the tourist life takes place. Best restaurants, bars, hotels, etc are near or surrounding the Plaza de Armas. Won't miss it!!

really pretty, you'll get accosted to buy things in the plaza if you sit on benches. I really liked the plaza, it's really pretty, super busy and a fun place to people watch. Though you will get accosted by sellers of every kind while you sit on the benches. You can typically waive them off. We found a cafe with a balcony overlooking the plaza and that was ideal - great view, food and drinks while people watching.

Charming!. We visited Cusco on our way to Machu Picchu. Cusco is a lovely place. Such a busy place. This square is where everyone gathers to visit and celebrate together. The community was having a celebration when we were there and all the school kids were practicing their dances. They loved when people stopped to watch. at night the city looks like a fairytale.

Main Square. There always seems to be things going on in the square and it is a good kick off point for the rest of the city. We got to see a few demonstrations by workers when we were there. Peaceful ones I hasten to add

pretty plaza with lots of shops and a beautiful church. Beautiful plaza with conveinent shops for any last minute purchases you need - like a quality poncho or a knock off north face rain jacket ( i got mine for $50 vs. the $115 at the North Face store). The church here is definitely worth a visit. There are a ton of fascinating little details in the artwork that show how the native people were subverting the catholics with small details in their paintings.

Center of Cusco. I have been there 3 years before and went there again last month. I wish I can take pictures of the night light with tripod. Unfortunately that they didn't turn the light on as usually.

Great area to walk around. The immediate Plaza de Armas has tons of restaurants, shops, and touristy sites. Make sure to venture outside of the main square by two or three blocks to see some awesome local restaurants and great souvenir shops.
History meets modern day conveniences.. The square is surrounded by architectural glory ! Greta's place for photos. There were a lot of restaurants and shops but some are definitely tourist traps.

Stunning. This is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen! The gorgeous Cathedral is mind-blowing, and everything here is colorful and intriguing. You can feel the history around you, even breathe it in the air! I would go back here in a heartbeat. Visiting the church was the best part... thr immense backstory and the richness of culture will take your breath away.

New Year's Eve Here!!. The title says it all. We made sure to return from our hike up Huayna Picchu and buy our lucky yellow underwear and necklaces in time for New Year's Eve in one of the greatest places to be at midnight. What a mad and crazy fiesta! Beer and vodka flowing everywhere, fireworks being set off right in the middle of the crowds, police trucks cruising 'round and 'round, keeping relative peace and enjoyment, all with the the Plaza, the Basilica Cathedral and the Iglesia de la Compania as irreverent, yet perfect backdrops to the building excitement. The crowds were up and down the stairs of the church screaming like "banshees", tourists from the world over, Cusquenos, and folks from as far away as Lima, all squashed in like a mosh pit in the Plaza de Armas, and ready and raring to begin their run, 12 times around the square (for good luck) at the stroke of midnight. What an unforgettable and unique celebration.

Pretty center of the town. Just as quaint and lovely Cusco's old town area is, the center is a beautiful little place where tourists and locals descend to take in the warm Cusco sun in the day, and enjoy the almost ethreal feel when the lights turn on. Also important to take rooms which have a view of the Plaza.

Great arquitecture all around. It seems that the whole Cusco just relay in this amazing Plaza. All kind of restaurants, hotels and churches have found the best place to be at, and all of us tourists, we love walking and getting around so many places for fun, religious art and churches, and the best, restaurants, bars and pubs 24h a day!

great meeting point. I love the transformation of this place. The Cuzco council has done a great job! I was here in 1985 and at that time you only walked around the place. Now you can sit and enjoy the folk life<3

Massage? Machu Picchu tour? Painting?. It is a must visit. It isn't like this review is going to hurt business in Plaza de Armas. The architecture is amazing but like any busy area full of tourists you are going to be hassled by people trying to sell you something. I turned down the same four ladies offering me a massage every day twice a day for two months. As long as you don't buy anything other than a (legit) tour go for it! One small piece of info relative to Cusco. Depending on how long you are staying and what all you plan to do you will end up purchasing a boleto turístico. A lot of the tour books will tell you that you can purchase partial boleto turístico's. One for Cusco and one for the Sacred Valley. We were there for several months living in Cusco and thought oh we can just do the partial of each place. It turned out that the partials are only good for a day or two and have limited places you can visit. I wanted to go to the museo de historia regional in Cusco but it isn't included in the partial ticket Cusco ticket which is only good for two days I think. So, if you are in Cusco for a short period. Go big and get the full ticket because it will include everything and is good for ten days.If any of this info changes or is wrong let me know and I will correct it. If you are planning on visiting Cusco, it is amazing and you will love it.

The Vibrant Center of Cusco. This is a very busy and vibrant plaza right in the center of Cusco. I was fortunate to see it at all times of the day during my visit to Peru because I stayed at a hotel in the Plaza. From my hotel room, I could see rows of buildings with red roofs and white concrete walls, and brown mountains that surround the plaza for as far as eyes can see. I enjoyed seeing people rush through the plaza as they went to work in the mornings; pupils being guided to and from school; tourists taking pictures all day as they explored the plaza, the nearby Cathedral, museum of Religious Art, and Los Compania church; vendors and hawkers trying to sell their wares to tourists, yellow taxis racing through the plaza, couples taking night strolls, etc. There is a fountain at the center of the plaza with the statue of Pachacutec at its top and statues of mermen blowing horns at the bottom. At night, the plaza is ablaze with lights and colors and many residents and tourists hang out on its benches, and the stairs of the cathedral till the wee hours of the morning. The grand Cathedral, Compania, bright flowers, flowing fountains and its statues, all add lots of color and character to this plaza. It has many stores, currency exchange places, hotels, and restaurants so I would recommend staying close to the plaza if you want to stay in the center of Cusco. I loved it.

All in the Centre. Around the Plaza de Armas you will find everything from restaurants, coffee shops, clothing shops and factories, to jewellery stores and much more. It is all centrally located here. Within walking distance to other hotels, restaurants, and stores.

Plenty to eat and buy. Large clean plaza surrounded by restaurants and shops. Dominated by the Cathedral. Most of the restaurants in this are all well rated and the shops sell regional craft. Well made as opposed to the expected trinkets.

WHERE ALL ACTION IS FOUND IN CUSCO. If you are looking for the main square in Cusco, this it is. It is walking distance from most hotels in downtown Cusco, however, a taxi ride is only $1 when traveling around the centro part of Cusco. Plaza de Armas connects to many restaurants, the Main Cathedral, and a city tour bus company that can take you around outside of downtown. It is a great land mark to meet friends then go for a coffee or lunch. There are many indigenous people selling hand-made souvenirs for tourist also. I enjoyed people watching everyday. Hope you enjoy this site when you visit Cusco next.. Happy Travels!!!

Beautiful Plaza, lots of sellers. Plaza de Armas is a beautiful plaza and worth visiting in both the night and day. However, it is also the most touristic part of Cusco, so everyone is trying to sell you something - painting, massage, city tour...., which means it is not as relaxing as other parts of the city.

a beautiful central park. bustling to life on Christmas eve with all sorts of wares and food from regions all around Cusco. The night ends with a spectacular explosion of fireworks at midnight... We thought for sure the following day, on Christmas, it would be littered with all the detritus from the previous day, but it was completely spotless and as beautiful as ever. A great place to people watch...

Beautiful, best Plaza in South America!. This is the most well kept and beautiful plaza in South America that I've seen! The flowers are gorgeous! The church nearby is beautiful! There are two other plazas near by but this one is the best! I even went during a political rally and I felt so safe! It can be scary being in other countries when something like that happens but Cusco is clearly capable. It was amazing!

Picturesque square. We have travelled through a number of Peruvian towns and cities and this square is one of the most impressive. Photo opportunities galore, both day and night. Beautiful architecture of cathedral and surrounding churches. The square itself has a large statute of the local native ruler and a lovely fountain. Like many squares in Peru, it is central to many other sites. Just a reminder, it is very touristy and there are many touts trying to get your business to go on tours and to eat at their restaurant. In terms of the latter, there are many other little gems a little walk away in the back streets which are much more affordable.

Great place for walking around. In Cusco for two days before going to Aguas Caliente, we had plenty of time to use. We just walked around the Plaza, ate, used wifi, talked to people, shopped. What a great square.

Great!. Plaza de Armas is a beautiful plaza filled with many restaurants and shops for all of your needs and enjoyment. It has very nice scenery and they have very nice places to buy clothes, scarves, etc. made out of baby alpaca.

Awesome spot for NYE!. We walked through this plaza a ton, it's the center point and makes it much easier to find other things from this point. We also visited here for New Years Eve, it's a must do! We joined in on the tradition of walking counter clockwise around the square at midnight which was amazing. So much energy and a fantastic atmosphere of celebration!

the Main Square in Cusco, nice enough. This is the main square in Cusco. The two most important churches of the city are located there, along with the most expensive stores, all selling baby alpaca (where do they get all these baby alpacas to make all the baby alpaca clothing?) by the labelling "baby alpaca" all Peru should be covered with bleating baby alpacas. Over priced stores and restaurants but the square itself is nice enough.

Plaza De Armas. Its a very large square, surrounded by shops and restaurants. In the center is a water fountain with benches...its a great place to spend time people-watching and also to just sit there to soak up the sun and enjoy the surroundings.

you can't avoid it. Wherever you stay in Cusco you most probably will have to cross that place to go somewhere else. Nice Fountain, statue and some older buildings / churches are around as well as many restaurants.

Great during Christmas Eve and Christmas. I was at the Plaza de Armas a few times. I was on a tour and ended up on Dec 23, 24,25, 26 and 29. On the 24 there is a Christmas market inside the plaza. Then on the 25, there are Christmas celebrations held here with dances in front of the Cathedral as well as people holding baby dolls while attending mass. There are two churches in this square and there is a history regarding the reason that there are two right beside each other. There are also many Quechua people around the area asking if you want to take a photo for a tip. Some have lambs or llamas. For American chains, there is a Starbucks, McDonald's and KFC here. Though they are pretty hidden within the buildings. It is mainly for tourists.I passed by the square everyday and there is a lot of car and people traffic but it's also connected to a lot of things. I enjoyed walking around to look at the buildings.The Cathedral is open for tourists in the afternoon for 25 sols. The other church seems to open and there will be sign at the door whether it is allowing tourists to enter. Both places do not allow photos.

Central focal point. Beautiful city, great meeting place, beautiful surroundings, bars (paddys always a good one or jacks also a great one for backpackers), not the cheapest place to have drinks or a coffee/food etc, and be careful of the children selling and pickpockets, other than that really nice place to be ! Hostels all around so really easy to get too and from, down all the side streets are quickly little shops selling literally all sorts, at night be careful of "dodgy" taxi drivers (unlicensed) and the local dodgy folk, as long as your sensible , it's an amazing place to visit

Central Cusco-Plaza De Armas. This is a nice quite place to sit and look all around Cusco with mountains covering on all sides . It has all the good restaurants in one place and is a happening place in Cusco

Interesting. We visited Christmas Eve when there was a huge local market. The buildings and fountain were interesting and there was an Irish pub on the corner where we spent the evening overlooking the plaza. We walked down there in the evening and felt quite safe with lots of families and couples around. Loads of restaurants and everything was open late.

Amazing. It is a unique and spectacular plaza of Peru, so full of ancient architecture mixed with the Spain colonization is what makes this plaza unique. Full of restaurants, Coffees, Pubs where you can relax drink their national beer or a delightful lunch or dinner and enjoy the beauty of this place.

Walk, sit and see. This was the main market, plaza and center of life in the Incan Capital. Now is surrounded by impressive churches, tourist-trap restaurants and travel agencies. Impressive at day, magnificent at night.

Beautiful architecture, clean city center.. We didn't have a lot of time to spend in Cusco, but Plaza de Armas is a beautiful city center plaza. The fountain in the center is beautiful and I loved how the streets all came off of the plaza. Loved the architecture of the old church. Just beware of the guys selling art work. They say they are the artist but they are not and the prices begin high and then get lower & lower as you continue to say no. Some of the paintings are beautiful though.

Place of Arms. It can't be missed. There are two first-rate churches (one of them is the Cathedral) on the Plaza, and it's a great place for people watching. There was a parade with a brass band on the Sunday that I was there.

Plaza De Armas. Take a walk along the cobblestone streets and sit on the plaza steps at night. The hills are decorated in lights, the smell of the air is cool. Very relaxing. You will be planning for your next trip....so forget Bora Bora, Europe and come and visit Cuzco, you will not ever forget it. Also bring some Ibuprofen for your headache that will go away after you become acclimatized to the altitude. Or drink coca tea like I did.
Beautiful. This plaza is large and beautiful! It's a great place to sit and appreciate your surroundings, talk to locals or just people watch.

AMAZING TIME!!!. i love the plaza in cusco amazing experience, please bring a camera to take the amazing picture of the city life. its a very safe city for tourist too, i walked every where by myself even at nighttime. this is the oldest city in south america before the spanish took over. lots of history. its get very chilly at nighttime, so its recommend to wear a sweater. hope you have fun like i did.

Stunning!. Most of the central plazas in Peru are beautiful, each in their own way- from the largest cities to the smallest villages. The plaza in Cusco was probably my favorite, however. I wish we had had more time to visit the surrounding churches and to just sit and watch the life in the plaza.

Corpus Christi festival celebration. Our travel agent, Kuoda Travels reserved a private balcony on the second floor during the annual Corpus Christi festival celebration located in the centre of Cusco. Simply an awesome place to see and meet locals from all around Peru. You will be better aware of their cultures and religions from the different parts of Peru.

GREAT FOR BAR HOPPING AND SHOPPING. Plaza de Armas was a great central point to visit for my friends and I. -Clean cobble streets that you can explore. - Very safe for tourist. ***I suggest that you listen to the locals and don't venture to far from here.

Enchanting site. Plaza de Armas is a great place, it is a park in the center of Cuzco, many restaurants and shopping and almost every Sunday, festivals of all kinds and of course, a portal to Machu Picchu, the sacred valley and many other treasures
Nice, clean and relaxing. It had a nice modern, safe feel to the place. There are number of churches, cathedrals, restaurants, fast food places and tour agencies around the plaza.
Lovely!!!. Great for people watching and just relaxing in the square. Superb restaurants all around. I really enjoyed it.

Nothing spectacular on an average day. It's a rather nondescript main square, but a good place to orient yourself & then explore all the interesting sites around the perimeter.
Probably the place to be during festivals...
what a wonderful plaza.... omg... beautiful plaza with the churches and all the small streets around it, a must see if you are in cuzco... is practically the center to get anywhere...

It's amazing to be there. I had seen it so many times in pictures and postcards that I couldn't believe my eyes when I was finally there. Plaza de Armas is the best area of the city, full of history, markets, important building and colonial churches. THE best spot in Cusco, by far. And super safe.
Nice square. The only square in the world with two churches, and they are nice one. If you want to get into for free, go there straight from a night out, because early in the morning it is free.

Good location to stay near in Cusco. We were a block away for this Plaza and the Plaza de San Francisco in Cusco and found that there was lots to do and see around the Plazas and area of several blocks around. Great restaurants, many very interesting shops, markets and historic buildings and attractions.

Nice Large Square. Plaza de Armas in Cusco is one of the larger plazas. It is surrounded by Spanish Churches and plenty of shopping opportunities. There are also many activities occurring almost daily in the square that are worth seeing and photographing, from parades to Inca reenactments.

Vast plaza. Very busy plaza even if we were a bit off season (nov). Nice buildings surrounding the site. For shopping, walk away from the plaza; prices will be lower. As for restaurants, again walk few hundreds meters toward the side streets. You will find smaller restaurants, the ones local prefers.If you are with a guide, he will advise you. Hotels may tend to suggest restos that are more expensive and with which they might have a lien. We spent 2 full days in Cusco and walked a lot. We discovered nice boutiques with good prices. Away from the plaza.
Beautiful plaza. Lots of people watching, cathedral, shopping and restaurants. I loved just sitting in the square watching the action.

Charming and full of history. The historic centre of Cuzco with its cathedral, is full with colonial style houses all around and with dozens of cuzqueñas dressed in the famous skirts and the typical hats. There are plenty of street vendors trying to sell you anything but this shouldn't put you off. There are several shops nearby where you can buy nice souvenirs or clothes in alpaca. Highly recommended!

Welcome to the Centre of Cusco. We visited this area on our second day in Cusco as it took us a day to get used to the altitude in this city (3,400 ft). It is a lovely square in front of the city Cathedral on one side and the beautiful Church of La Compania de Jesus on the other along with other colonial period buildings all around. In the centre is the golden statue of Manco Capac, the first Inca. It is a lovely square and you'll not be in Cusco very long before you happen upon it.

Boring. As far as plazas go this is a snore fest. First as soon as you step in to the square someone wants to sell you something or usher you very hurriedly in to a restaurant. Its a tourist trap as much as one can get. Oh and by the way tourist are not allowed to mass. No street food vendors, no feeling of what the town really is.

Take a quick look and leave. You can't miss it. You'll probably walk through it several times. It is rather nice also but it becomes annoying after a few minutes of being approached by so many hawkers. If you miss home, around the plaza you can find Starbucks, KFC and an Irish pub.
Great Plaza. A must see while in Cusco. It is impossible to miss while in Cusco. So far as Latin American plazas go this is pretty first class. Enjoy a coffee while watching Cusco pass by.

Where life happens (in cusco). There is no other place like this square (in cusco, of course)Great buindings all around, nice restaurants, cafes and night clubs (discotecas)This is where you see locals and tourists in CuscoI was there during Halloween,so nice to see the kids all around asking for candies all dressed up in their costumes...
Central Park of Cuzco. Great place to use as meet up point for everyone. All of the major nightlcubs and hotels are located near Plaza De Armas.

Outstanding. Great view, vibrant atmosphere! Worth the trip. Specially at night time the view is breathtaking and very cosmopolitan place. You can find bars, restaurants inernet places and laundry services very close by. But avoid this hostel Pirwa Posada del Corregidor and all its line in cusco and Aguas Calientes, me and 3 friends got robbed there.
A charming square. Such a pretty square with flowers, statues, fountain, beautiful buildings and lots of people enjoying themselves.Do not miss it during your visit to Cusco.
Cool. Great central plaza. Found it especially amusing that there was a war of sorts between the bishop and some monks over who could build the fancies church!

Beautiful square. The buildings within the square have great architecture. Area is very clean with a beautiful fountain in the middle. Many people hang out in the park area around the fountain eating ice cream and just watching other people. The Cathedral on the square is truly amazing to see. Was built many, many years ago and is well preserved....probably due to no wars that have occurred. Many restaurants in the area as well to dine in and view the sites.

Charming Plaza. You need to spend time around this plaza...day or night. Anything you need is here. Restaurants, shops, churches, etc ... All places of interest are in this area. The fountain in the center of the plaza surrounded by flower beds adds to the charm of the well preserved center of the city.
very pretty. the square is very pretty, and a nice area to hang around. A lot of stores and restaurants around the area.

Very nice. This is a good spot for sitting on the steps soaking up Cusco and doing some people watching. The many historic buildings and vast array of people makes it an enjoyable space to spend an hour or two. As with most of Cusco's centre they could do with limiting traffic or stopping it entirely, this would make it a fantastic space.

Small town plaza. The Plaza in Cusco is a standard small town plaza with churches, government buildings, etc. surrounding the same with a fountain in the middle. Flowers were planted making the atmosphere quite nice. The space is large compared to the narrow streets of the city. Understand why the area is the center of the city.

Center of Town. You can't explore Cusco without visiting the Plaza. With impressive architecture and beautiful mountain backdrops, it is bustling with activity, restaurants, shops, and all kinds of interesting people. It's beautiful at night, especially from the various restaurant balconies overlooking the plaza.

Good Place to Sit Back and Relax. On our last day before beginning the trip back home, we spent a few hours on a Sunday sitting in the Plaza and watching the locals in their church finery and the tourists clicking away. We met a University Professor here and spent over an hour talking to her. She pointed us to an excellent local restaurant which would be our last traditional meal in the country. There is always a good deal going on here so we found it to be the perfect place to people watch.
Center of the Town. This is a Cusco main area surrounded by hotels, shops, museums, restaurants, churches.Hundreds of pupils are walking around this Plaza.

Great in the evenings. I found myself hanging out in the Plaza de Armas almost every evening during my stay in Cusco. There always seems to be something going on, or you could just people watch. Beautiful churches and good restaurants surround the plaza, too.

Central location for Cusco activities. The is a great location that is central to the tourist areas of Cusco. There are quite a few people hawking items on the street but they aren't too pushy and as long as you say "no gracias" right away they tend to leave you alone. The restaurants are a bit pricey compared to others but this is a factor of being in the tourist section.

Great central location. This is a great central location in Cusco. It's a bit touristy as this is a main place to hang out but there is a great deal to do and see in this plaza. All of the restaurants will be slightly higher in price compared to others and there are a number of locals trying to push stuff for sale.
Be there to see.... The changing of the guard, and flag raising and lowering are not to be missed. The flowers were beautiful and the surrounding cathedrals added charm.

The reason to visit Cuzco. If you are looking for a reason to visit Cuzco. This is it. The place is beautyful. One side you have the cathedral . Inside the most beautifull I have ever been into. The other side of the plaza the chuch of the Jesuits. Smaller (bigger then the cathedral was not allowed) but here the outside is fantastic. The 2 other sides are old colonial houses. Not far away : the church of San Domingo

Plaza de Armas. Great place to see and explore. You can walk around - visit the museums and the cathedral. There is huge market not too far from the Plaza, about 15 minutes walk. You can find food and souvenirs there at a great price.

Beautiful must see. This is the main square of Cusco. It is absolutely amazing especially at night. There are many different attractions around the square and tons of restaurants offering food from around the world. There are also hop on hop off buses that leave from here.

Good for people watching. This is a pretty square in the center of Cusco - a good place to relax after an uphill hike at a high altitude. Surrounded by restaurants and shops, and the wonderful cathedral (which is a must-see).

While away a few hours in this fine plaza. A beautiful plaza at the heart of Cusco. Gardens and fountains in the central part. Surrounded by old colonial buildings with carved wooden balconies. Full of restaurants, cafes, travel agents, shops, camping equipment stores, churches, tourists and locals. The hub of Cusco, it is a pleasant place to sit and watch the world go by. Secure and safe too.

What "a square" should be. Great atmosphere and felt like a city centre square should be. Everything going on, even the formal Sunday morning parade, great entertainment.Good selection of businesses on the square from the lowly McDs to upmarket shops and restaurants, not forgetting the cathedral, museums etc.Only downside was the constant attention from street vendors, shoeshines et al.

beautiful square. worth walking around. Beautiful place with simple and beautiful people from the andes. I loved watching the locals go about their day...very good exposure to the culture and Peruvian costumes.

Sit and watch. This square is a great place to sit and watch the residents of Cusco going about their lives. It was here that the bands and marchers assembled for the Sunday parade and where the political and military dignitaries sat and watched the parade pass them.

The historic center of Cusco. Plaza De Armas is what use to be The Palacio Del Inka, the ceremonial plaza for the Incans. Spanish conquestadors have built churches and convert it into a plaza. The Jesuit church, the Cusco Cathedral, restaurants and shops now populate the plaza. It's a pretty plaza, it had historical significant, but I wish they can restore it to its original cultural significant to show case the original ceremonial Incan Palace.

Stayed close. Because we had a hotel just a few blocks away we were always crossing this for Plaza for museums or restaurants. Fabulous place to rest the travellers weary feet and enjoy the sights and sounds of the day.

Historic Mirador of rich colors and diversity.... Traveling with photojournalist and an explorer can be a boon and that was my experience from my recent Peru visit. Most tourists get a glimpse but the trained eye spots the cultural emblems. Plaza with its five hundred year old history is one of the perfect spots in South America. Our hotel room had roof windows that looked into the square to capture the night. The Plaza square is very well planned and has ample security due to the bustling tourist community among which 3.2 million visit the Machu Picchu every year. The Spanish architecture is evident and the local people are very helpful and nice who mainly speak Spanish, with Quechua and Imara spoken sparsely. The Cathedral is quite different with paintings that are different such as the Last Supper depicting twelve apostles having a guinea pig. The ambitious Spanish have left a big dent on the Incan population during their invasion and most are converted into main stream Roman Catholicism. Interestingly, the locals deep rooted Incan values and traditions of reverence to "Pachamama," meaning mother earth is noticeable. Cusco in the Urubamba valley serves as a tourist junction to many attractions. The fountain of the Incan emperor in the center of the square is a reminder of the beliefs held by the peoples of Peru. Every Sunday the square is full of activity at least we saw school bands and students dressed in Incan attire following a two hour presentation of the history - reminder to the youngsters who appear to be wooed by the western habits. Lots of restaurants catering to every taste is few steps around the block and so is San Pedro market. Tourists should be aware of touts and scalpers looking for a game. Evenings are colorful and the lighting is at its best and a light jacket will always help beat the cold or unexpected showers. Police women can be seen regulating the traffic in their smart appearance and always helpful to visitors. WiFi is everywhere for free!October 12 is celebrated as "Tanta Raymi," meaning bread festival in the nearby Orepesa that shows off its secretly held family recipes of the special bread baked in their own earthen oven tasting of licorice, sweet fennel, allspice or some other aromatic blend achieved firing Eucalyptus logs. Bargaining is always welcome and coca tea is freely offered in most hostels and hotels and for the coffee lovers Peruvian coffee is a treat besides the Starbucks on the corner. High altitude sickness is usually got over after a day. Cristo Blanco offers an aerial viewpoint of the city from above the hill. Ride on the Perurail to Machu Picchu from Poroy to Aguas Callientes is an interesting ride to see the life by the mountain side.A true Andes culture with a lots of sights, sounds, tastes, smell and much more for the tourist within and absolutely no disappointment.
The magic plaza of Cusco. A beautiful plaza to sit and enjoy the Cusco atmosphere. Almost every day there's a parade or something new to see and do. A great start when you visit Cusco.
Very nice place to wonder around. I think it’s one of the most preserved places in Cusco, policemen everywhere and they have this strange rule that you cannot get on the lawns…
Awesome. Awesome town square with lots of history. You can spend a day just exploring this area. Find the local market to buy all your souvenirs.

Beautiful and used by the community. Yes, there are tourists; yes, there are some junky shops nearby; however, the square is well maintained and has places to sit while the two churches are large and dominating. If you relax you can see that local folks also use the Plaza. One day we sat with a older local man (actually,probably our age) and watched a parade and patriotic celebration. Despite limited common language between us, he communicated what was going on and we followed his lead in when to stand or sit. On another day a funeral group accompanied by a band emerged from the Cathedral and the casket bearers marched with the attendees along the Plaza. Do notice the local rainbow colored flag, and if you are open to interacting with folks, then sit down and enjoy yourself.
Center and Heart of the City. Lots of great places to eat on or around the plaza, but very touristy during the day, and can be crowded. That said, it's hard to avoid it.

Tourist Hell!. Ok, the review title is a little dramatic, but if you are looking for a place to sit, and eat a bagged lunch, while enjoying the many cathedrals of the Plaza, do not expect to do so in peace & quiet. With vendors selling sunglasses, artwork and various other wares, coupled with the never ending tour group reps and an endless stream of cars and horns, this place is the tourist central of Cusco. The plaza is quite nice and the history that you will learn on any one of the bus tours is very interesting. But the fact that there is a Starbucks, KFC and McDonalds in the square maybe takes away from the allure a little...

Best Plaza ever!. Big kathedral with 2 churches El Triunfo and Jésus Maria e José are surrounding the plaza. Very charming "Plaza". There's a foutain in the middle of the square and benches to rest on and enjoy...
Pretty square with great shops and restaurants.. This square is very easy to navigate and is loaded with shops and restaurants. I exchanged money at the Scotiabank here and the rate was very good.
Typical Peruvian Square. The Plaza de Armas is a typical Peruvian square with plenty of benches to sit down and people watch. You can visit the 2 churches on the square as well.

Beautiful Plaza. This is a very picturesque plaza in the touristic area of Cusco. The plaza has several churches including the Cathedral that sit on the Square. There are also several food options, including Limo, which I would highly recommend in addition to Starbucks and KFC. There are also several banks that do currency exchange.

South . South America in general is a crowded mess. .. I've really enjoyed my time in this region of half a million. . A Lil more calm a Lil more friendly .. but as anywhere insane traffic rules so be careful. .
Lots of eateries in this area. . And some America standards .. chocolate museum is close too yummmm

The best main square of the country. This is one of the main atractions of the whole country, in my opinion the most beautiful square of Peru. You have to go back by night it looks even more beautifull with the lights of the houses on the hills, they look like stars...

Lovely square, great shopping. Pretty location, cathedral and university are sights to see. The restaurants around the square are a bit touristy, so plan to go a bit off of this central locale if you want to experience more traditional and interesting food choices. Excellent and safe place for money exchange and ATMs.
Great food and shopping. Not only that but here are hostels located in the area that go for $8-$10 per night. Visit the Inca Museum and the cathedrals. The local food experience is not to be missed.

A clean and safe part of Peru.. You will be hassled but street vendors and restaurant merchants
Restaurant Prices are too high for Peru. Walk a few blocks for better value.
Get together!. Gathering center for sightseeing around the square. Usually some activity going on and lots to see; cathedral, stores, restaurants, etc. People watching is also part of the fun.
worth a visit. A nice place to visit very pretty but a bit of an tourist trap. Get ready to be surrounded by people trying to sell you things

Fun and touristy but historical too.. Boy there is a lot to see here. First you will be offered massage by everyone on every sidewalk of every street in this square. You will also be approached by ladies and kids dressed up and carrying baby llamas. Take their picture...1 sol please. Don't try to sneak a picture...they will hound you for payment- they see everything.The Inca Museum is a must and the churches/cathedrals were interesting and beautiful. Venture away from the square there is more. Venture too far and you see what everyday life is like in the non-touristy areas.PeruRail is located in Plaza de Armas near the McDonalds and down from the Church. And if you need anything for trekking there is a street on the opposite side of the square from PeruRail that has everything outdoors. Nothing has prices on it, be prepared to bargain. Behind the Cathedral on Laredo is a Starbucks. (behind the cathedral, left through a courtyard and upstairs...great view of the plaza during a rain)

Plaza de Armas. Plaza de Armas is always full of life, at any time, we've seen as early as 4 am and there are people there always. Lots of shopping and restaurants. Money exchange shops in abundance, competitive rates, you can negotiate as the guy next door may be more flexible. Lots of tour operators, you can book a trek or a bus tour or buy an airline ticket.

Cuzco's center of activity - night and day. Something's always happening around the Plaza, which is surrounded by a mixture of churches and businesses. What did surprise us is that, unlike many other places in the world, the cathedral and the other religious monuments are not lighted at all. We felt completely safe at night as well, and the tourist police is there to make certain that nothing bad happens.

Beautiful Square. My wife and I spent 3 nights in Cusco and we loved hanging out at the Plaza de Armas. It's a beautiful setting with the park in the center of the square and with the Cusco Cathedral as a backdrop. There are a ton of nice restaurants and shops outlining the square, with several very nice hotels nearby. If you're staying in Cusco, THIS is the place to be.We felt very safe walking around at night as there are tourist police everywhere. For the less adventurous eater, there is a KFC, McDonalds and Starbucks in the square, though thankfully their signage is not obtrusive.Our favorite spots in that area: Cusco Novotel Hotel, Marriott Hotel, and the Incanto Restaurant. We didn't stay at the Marriott but it was beautiful! Our meal at the Incanto Restaurant was one of the best I've had anywhere.

We loved the Plaza de Armas. Great for people watching, shopping, food and drink, museums, cathedrals and just relaxing on a bench in the sunshine. The Plaza is a great place to start and end the day while in Cusco. Lots of police presence, taxi stands and city tour busses that take you on sightseeing drives around the city. I suggest you take the yellow one with the open rooftop seats, a great way to see the city!!!

Spectacular view of Cusco. When you visit the Plaza de Armas and see the cathedral it easily rivals anything in Europe inside. The plaza overlooks the entire city as you look around the the surrounding mountains. You cannot go to Cusco and not stop here!

Relaxing Park in the Middle of Historic Cusco. Even if you are only in Cusco for a couple of days you will pass through this area over and over getting to your hotel, restaurants and other sites in town. Take the time to stop and sit for a while and just take in the activity going on around you. The park is well maintained and planted with flowers with many benches.
