During our first day in town we were getting our bearings in the park and suddenly heard a parade coming around the corner. It was one of several we would see during our week in Cusco. This one was something related to a spring festival with costumed characters and a makeshift marching band. Grab a bite to go from one of the surrounding restaurants and picnic in the plaza or get a balcony seat overlooking the park and enjoy the people watching, you never know what you might see!

Be ready to say "buzz off" frequently. We did not like this centre because of the persistence of the touts. Restaurants, tours, sungalsses - you name it! The plaza itself is nothing special in terms of greenery and surrounding buildings. If you walk about Cuzco, you'll pass though this "attraction"

lots of good spots for pictures. This plaza has a lot to show, Very historical constructions ,churchs and more . good food in some of the restaurant around. i took a sightseen tour in this palce and it was woth it
view of history. There is a lot of history around the plaza, although sadly, it is a reminder of how the Spanish conquest destroyed the Inca civilization
Great views. Good stop for pics of the historical buildings in the city square. Lots of small shops around, high end and local artisan.
This is a beautiful plaza!. What a gorgeous plaza! Not only does it have the most beautiful church I've ever visited, but great restaurants and shops surrounding the square.

I love this plaza!. So beautiful! Seated in the center of Cusco City, it's a great meeting place as it has been for centuries. Surrounded by beautiful buildings, there are shops and restaurants galore! Plenty of benches, but good luck finding one that isn't already occupied. That's because everyone meets there!
Historical center, with unfortunate distractions. Very nice plaza, but a shame that the experience is ruined by the hordes of exceedingly aggressive peddlers.
great place. My hotel was just nearby and we spent lots of time wondering around this beautiful plaza. Very good shopping place here both budget and high end

Former and current meeting place in Cusco. Currently flanked by two churches, the Central Cathedral and La Compania, and colonnaded buildings, this plaza has certainly served as the center of activity for the city before and after the Spanish Conquest. Not all Incan culture has been suppressed and some even celebrated in Cusco. The centerpiece fountain, though recently added, raises controversy but also lends remembrance of the Cusco of the past.

The history of Cusco lives in Plaza de Armas. Our guide took us to Plaza de Armas were we learned about their fights, Gods, culture. A huge part of their history took place in Plaza de Armas. Do not miss it!

The Plaza. A great place to just sit and take in the culture of Cusco. Here the local people would come up to you to sell their wares. My husband had his shoes cleaned and polished here by two very anxious young fellows.

Worth a visit. There are numerous stores on all four sides of the plaza (including McDonald's and Starbucks!). We procured warm clothing and many gifts in that area; probably a bit more expensive than other markets around the city, but still cheaper than Agua Caliente and Lima. If you have time, just sit in the square and enjoy the view, talk to the locals, even if they are trying to sell you things.
Nice center. Festival was in full swing when we arrived in time for the parade. History of the place is great, shops and restaurants were all nice.
very nice. down 3 block from our hotel very nice walk of the historic center and close to hotel can't beat that
Nice plaza surrounded by History, food and shops.. Large beautiful square with great views in all directions. The heart of the old section of cusco with cobble narrow streets and world calls charm.

Nice place. It's the city centre of Cusco, and its a bit busy, but not that much. You can find shops and restaurants on the nearby streets, and also if you go just a little bit further you can find the local farmer's market. Also, around there are the coca museum and the chocolate museum.
Nice place in Cusco. If you do much walking in Cusco, this will be your center point of reference. Beautiful churches, decent restaurants, really expensive shops (go off the plaza to shop).

Interesting town square with many shops and restaurants. Large Cathedral on one side.. easy access, variety of stores and restaurants. Large grassy area in center is a good place for relaxation. Many beautiful flowers. This is a central location for the town and many streets either run from here or are in close proximity. At the time of our visit, they were doing some excavating work right off the Plaza where it connects with Avenida del Sol.

Busy City Center. The cathedral was impressive inside and out. The plaza monument was impressive as well. I did not like being accosted by all the locals trying to sell me their wares when we f sat down to rest on a bench to enjoy the late afternoon.
Plaza de Armas. Go on Sunday Morning to see the parade Very fun display of Peruvian culture. Also the statue in the middle is worthy of a photo
Places to visit in Cusco. We passed by this on our bus tour. It is a nice square where many people gather. Shopping is nearby as are many restaurants.
lovely and fun place to hang out!. Buy some fruits/snacks and have a seat in one of those many benches around. Enjoy the Scenes and people watching! love the view.
Town Centre felt like home. When resting in the centre by the water fountain, the sellers were at bay! Taxis were easy to get, all the shopping needs from pharmacy to trinkets was easy to enjoy.

Pretty plaza turning into a tourist trap. The Plaza de Armas was very pretty and a relatively pleasant place to sit (if you ignore the constant stream of people trying to sell you trinkets/tours/massages). There was a constant police presence, presumably to reassure the tourist population which greatly outnumbered the local population. The prices at the restaurants and shops were all about what one might pay in the US (though prices in Soles) so the locals by and large cannot afford to shop there. Lots of benches make it a nice place to rest your feet, but for anything else, it is rapidly approaching 'tourist trap' status.

Good base for shopping and museums. The Plaza is basically the center of it all. It is surrounded by the Cathedral, various places to shop and eat and at close proximity to many museums. Behind the plaza there are many street vendors selling knit goods, crafts and food.

Must see in daylight and on dusk. Its one place you must see in CuscoA typical Spanish square with excellent architecture and anther fine Inca statue in the centreGrab a coffee, sit on the Cathedral steps and take it all in. You may even catch a religious Parade as we didProbably a half hour or so will be enough depending on what else you wish to see

Downtown. Unlike other cities with classic downtowns, Cuzco's is still legitimate and "working." Get there soon before a new international airport floods the place with tourists (in the worst way). Right now, you have to really want to get to Cusco to get there, so it's still authentic. Highly recommended. Note: the city is at 11,000' altitude. Most people adjust to it, but a few can't.

not to be missed. Beautiful and historical, great area to people watch. The only drawbacks were tons of people trying to sell trinkets, shoe shining, massages, etc. and the restaurants around are pretty touristy.

What better place for history. Located in the center of the old city, there you can stand and just In visioned a long history!!! Beautiful place for pictures, restaurants and churches!!! Cusco, has so much to offer everywhere you turn!!!

Cleanest place in Cusco. Nothing extremely special, looks like most of the Plaza de Armas in Perú. There are a lot of expensive shops, lots of police officers and more people that try to rip you off: cleaning your shoes, selling you souvenirs and luring you into their restaurants, bars and clubs.
Worth a visit. This area was beautiful and worth visiting. I wish there weren't so many people peddling goods but all were polite.

Good people watching. Great vibe and place to sit and soak up the atmosphere. Busy place, much to see and do, or just grab a coffee and sit overlooking the square from one of the lovely colonial balconies.
Beautiful plaza . Very beautiful plaza with tons of activity always. The only knock is the countless number of touts trying to sell you junk.

We enjoyed people watching here!. We were warned that this is a dangerous area after dark but we were able to enjoy people watching- alpacas with people and people in local costumes posing for photos as well as people selling clothing and food. The restaurants included some well known American chains.
Great People watching. Visit this site to see Cuzco in action. Tourists from all over the world are here. Picture taking is a must. Its the best launching point for the Inka/Peru Andean experience.

A great place. There are a lot of bench seats so you can catch your breath and people watch. You will get the locals coming up and trying to sell you things, but a polite 'no thank you' and they will move on. I enjoyed my rests here watching everything going on.

All colonial towns begin at the square, this is no exception.... Day, evening or night, the central square of Cusco is where the action begins...People watching is good, of course, and all things extend from here in spokes- the main alpaca and tourist stores, the ATM's and banks, pharmacies, travel agents, tourist attractions etc....Don't miss the cathedral, the Inka statue in the fountain in the center (looks totally different day and night), and it's a short walk in any direction to the major attractions in town...For those of you who want a Starbucks, you'll find it here...One of the most heartbreaking memories of my 23 days in Peru was going into an indoor ATM on the square at 7 am, and finding a young child sleeping alone in the corner with his stuffed bear.... of course, he woke up when I got money, and with heavy heart, I gave him $ for breakfast, and he let me take his photo, but his eyes (and speculation about his back story) still haunt me...
wonderful. Very cute ... Has an impressive magnetism, I really like the arches of the buildings, have a rich sun in the morning is the maximum .
Not bad. It is a wide open plaza like most cities have. The buildings around it are nice and it has some pretty statues. If you spend any time in Cuzco you won't be able to miss it.

A must see. Great shops are here, off on the side roads. We also grabbed a bus tour here, and found the starbucks. The churches are beautiful. The fountain is nice. You only need an hour or two to wander around but this is a must see if in Cuzco. The shops are also nice, a chance to get some quality items. Our hotel (and most hotels) are a quick walking distance away.

By day or by night always pretty. Love this Plaza, nice place to relax and do nothing, just look around the beautiful churches and old housesAlso liked the Inka now placed on top of the Square Fountain
Cusco's main square. Lots of activity and sights in and around the square.We like the shopping and restaurants in the area. We also enjoyed our visit to the cathedral which very ornate.

Historical and pretty. The square is good for people watching and photography, and I really enjoyed it at night. It is lively and safe, and there are lovely buildings surrounding the square, as well as a ton of little shops selling things for your trek, souvenirs, street food, and restaurants.

Quaint. We were here during a huge festival so it was extremely crowded with locals and tourists. That being said, it was still nice. The architecture, people, restaurants, people, atmosphere, cobblestone streets, and well, the people, were beautiful and interesting. Cusco is a delight. There are several plazas, but we stayed near this one and spent more time here. I've said this in other Cusco reviews: if using American dollars, bring NEW bills with no tears, writing or folds. And bring small denominations of ones or fives.

Great place for sights and people watching.. This is a great place to start your sightseeing tour of Cusco. Two impressive churches, the walk along Loreto street and several squares within a couple of blocks make it a central location with lots to see.People watching is also a popular thing to do.The square is well lit at night and there are a lot of people which make it feel safe.The colonial architecture of the surrounding buildings give it great atmosphere and a sense if history.

Magic place. One of the most beautiful plazas I ever visited! Just sit and watch the kids comming back from school, the wonderful arches and the balconies. Lots of flowers, very colorful. And the 2 churches close to the other!
Nice to hang out.. The plaza is a nice place to people watch. Lots of locals and tourist hang out here. This is a starting point for many. Easy to catch a taxi.

Lovely Square. Easily one of the most beautiful city centers I have ever seen. You wil find yourself here often--it is the beating heart of Cusco. Between the Peruvian kids laughing, the tourists snapping photos, the Indian women selling their wares, and the old couples enjoying the benches in the sun, it is full of life. Great cafes, beautiful churches (careful, you have to pay to go in) and awesome fountain. Loved it.

Nice historic sight. This is a place were you walk to most of the historical sights of cusco, there you can take some pics from locals and churches and the city itself.If you are traveling in a group, this plaza would be a good meeting point.

I returned here almost daily...it was my anchor point.. I found myself returning to the huge square on almost a daily basis, to rest, eat, purchase train tickets, and observe the parades around the plaza. The largest cathedral is here and my favorite cafés, pubs, and silver shops were within a block. It's lovely with its central fountain and flower garden. It's also the anchor point from which I always got my bearings. Pick up a tour of the city on either side of the plaza by boarding a red and yellow double decker bus which gives you a two hour overview of the city as well a quick drive through one of the ruins, Saqsayhuaman. So much to see!
beautiful!. Best place in Cuzco, couldn't stop taking pictures! The Cathedral is truly beautiful and it really seems you've gone back in time. Amazing.

The plaza of solicitation, and some cool stuff. The Plaza de Armas is, as many folks have pointed out, a good place to walk around and people watch and take in some of the city's more historic colonial architecture and culture. It is also a great place to be solicited with everything from "massage, Señor?" to "maybe some marijuana?" Of course this is a common occurrence in areas of concentrated tourists like this, but these people are relentless! This (somewhat) aggressive solicitation was actually the only irritating thing I found being in the country (other than being ripped off in Lima). That having been said, a simple "Lo Siento, no gracias" kept the people at bay. Just don't expect to walk around freely without offers for products and services being fired across your bow every few feet, especially if you're a gringo - doubly so if you're a pesky American. But, there are several wonderful restaurants, the beautiful architecture of the cathedrals, as well as souvenir and outdoor sporting goods shops, plus a few internet cafe call centers, ATMs, and other luxuries/necessities of the modern traveler. The square is also the central location for Cusco's many celebrations - such as Corpus Christi and festivities leading up to it, which was a site to behold. Check it out, have a look around, relax a bit, just don't plan to lay in the grass and be left alone. There are better places in town for that.

Good Place To People Watch/Rest. Large plaza with plenty of benches and steps to catch your breath. A central point to get your bearings. Many restaurants just a couple blocks away in almost every direction. Plenty of restaurants and shops along the walk ways. Good picture taking place. (To Travel Is To Live)

Touristy yet quaint and unique. First and most impt piece of advice - Wear proper anti-slip shoes and walk carefully. My daughter and I cannot believe that the Doc Martens we wore up and down Huayna Picchu couldn't keep us from slipping walking the cobblestone pavements of the Plaza de Armas. Despite that, we love the festive atmosphere and the quaint streets and alleys. We only had a total of 3 days there but I think I could stay here for a longer period and still not feel jaded. The restaurants are great, the Pisco Sours never fail to please and the shopkeepers and vendors never too obstrusive. We didn't find the time to check out the basilicas and museums - I'm sure they must be interesting too but we gave it a miss to loll about in our very beautiful and comfortable Casa San Blas suite.
Beware of restaurant solicitors!. Happening place in the heart of the city. I really disliked being solicited by restaurant workers who were trying to get you to go into their restaurant.
Great place to hang out. Bustling activities, shops, restaurants, museums, amazing architecture--the center of it all in Cusco.
Beautiful. Lovely park/plaza. The grounds are well kept, and the plaza as well as the city is clean and safe. Fountains, churches, shops, restaurants are all nearby.

Heart of town. Centre of town surrounded by so many aspects - history, cathedrals, restaurants, people, shops and locals trying to sell you souvenirs. So many towns and cities have such squares but this is one of the better ones to start an historical tour.
People watching plaza. Small,historic & interesting. Love the fountain & flowers & local color.like to sit at Los Balcones & eat a delicious &inexpensive lunch & watch the tourists.

the Heart of Cusco. Typical South American central square. Always busy, with a central fountain, clean and well-maintained and surrounded by beautiful buildings, shops and restaurants. Lots of locals to sell you things here, a polite ‘no gracias' will usually suffice.

Good place to start your tour of Cusco. This is a good place to start your tour of the historic centre of Cusco.Lots of churches(most have a fee for entry).Lots of people...that means be alert !Some interesting shopping.Tip .The children & people who dress in the local costumes with animals expect to be tipped if you take their photos. So if there are 2 people you tip both.... Remember its their job!But its worth it as it looks great when you get home and show off your holiday pics.

Sunday with flag celebration. First day in Cusco, I was in Plaza de Armas and I didn't understand all the movement. Turns out every Sunday morning there is a typical flag celebration with the army. Nice to see.

picturesque. lots of activity, photo opportunity from the start, day or night. The only bad thing was all of the locals selling you junk, but I was in there country. It was easy to say no-muchas gracias
Centre of cusco!. Grat spot to start and go wandering from. Leads to numerous great spots, markets, churches, shopping, restaurants. Surrounded by beautiful buildings. Worth a look whilst in cusco.

Always something going on!. The Plaza - day or night, is always hopping with some activity. There are shops and restaurants galore, as well as the Cathedral, Basilica and a few galleries for local art. When here four years ago, we were treated to the Festival of San Christobal, which included religious statuary filling the cathedral, and the most unnerving, but spectacular display of fire works! This past visit, we saw several sets of dancers and performers, along with a religious procession that ended up in the Cathedral. Newly married, or about to be married couples frequently come to get their pictures taken on the steps of the Basilica.Be warned that you will be approached a thousand times to buy any number of items for sale. A "no gracias" is enough to keep most walking on by.. very few vendors were at all aggressive, and most will leave you with a "maybe you'll buy tomorrow?". From time to time there will be little girls holding lambs and they will offer to allow you to hold the lamb for pictures. The price is usually 2 soles PER GIRL, and they, above everyone else we encountered, were the most rude when demanding their money. But the Plaza is the main center of action in Cusco, and a good place to start each evening as you venture out to shop and eat.
Fun area. A lot of shops, restaurants and cafes to peruse. There's also great views of the mountains and a church to tour. Enjoy!
Very lively and central place. Must visit for all tourists. Close to all hotels and restaurants. Half the city can be viewed from the center. We took a walking tour using Lonely planet.

Very rich plaza. I went to Cusco in june, a month full of attractions in this plaza, which is the core of the city. Every day there was a different attraction, fulfilled with local culture. The population in Peru, at least in the Andes region, is very attached to the ancient culture, and it gives a special meaning in the events. There are people from all over the world in this plaza. We watched the Corpus Christi parade, the Inti Raymi, the birthday of Cusco, all of these events were very special and meaningful.There are lots of shops around the plaza, some of them with very beautiful things, but most of them expensive, in comparison with other places in the city. Other thing to say is about security. One woman in my group had her backpack stolen, with all her documents. She just left it in a chair in one restaurant of the plaza, then it vanished. They said that some burglars keep an eye on one person, and then starts following until find some breach to act. So be careful!Besides those little problems, it is a very beautiful plaza, with flowers and benchs, and surrounded by marvelous and ancient constructions.
Festival. If you go the last week of may you can see a parade of Santos(wooden saints carried by 20 to 40 people). It is an incredible festival.

Fun Place to Visit. Quaint plaza surrounded by lots of shops and restaurants. Great place to sit and people watch. On Sunday, we got to witness the President of Cusco and the military perform. Quite entertaining.

Beautiful and vibrant. There is a wealth of history you can view from this square but there is also plenty going on. We were there during the final few days of the World Cup final so it may hard to generalise our experiences, in yes of noise and excitement. Every Sunday morning there is a parade and it is very interesting to observe the different traditions that Peru has. In the centre of the square there is a beautiful statue of Pachacuti, one of the most famous Incas of the entire empire. As with other places in Peru be prepared for the number of times you are approached as a westerner to buy things - a simple 'non gracias' works for the most part. For the adults in the party there is an Irish pub and a British bar just on the square too. No visit to Cusco should avoid this square.

Beautiful place. I was expecting a very crowded place, but was happily surprised to find a cosy, open space full of history. Yes, there are the occasional tourist sales people (which are much nicer than in any other parts of the world, a simple "no, gracias" will bring a smile on their face), but these do not spoil the experience. The Plaza de Armas is literally the heart of Cusco, from there all the nice places are within walking distance. Shopping is best on the little squares around the Plaza. The center of Cusco is a very safe place.

Gorgeous. Beautiful place. Every Peruvian town has its Plaza de Armas and the one in Cusco is REALLY beautiful to appreciate. There are 2 cathedrals there. It is lovely to sit down on a bentch and enjoy the view and the life however get ready to be harrassed by the local hagglers trying to sell you stuff!!!!!

Amazing. This is my 2nd time here. Everything look pretty much the same. I like the lighting poles that has Jaguar face on them. There'll be local girls from couple villages walk around plaza de Armas as tourist greeters. You can take pictures with them for free and ask information as much as you can. Around this area you also can see Spanish terrace in some area.During my 1st visit it was about Christmas. On every 22nd December people will come to reserve the space to sell their local stuff and on 23rd December there'll be a festival that people from surrounded area. In doing so on Christmas' eve people will stay home to celebrate with their family. That was very impressive.

Beautiful place, ruined by hawkers. Plaza de Armas is a beautiful place to view, with a nice cathedral in front of a central square with a great statue, However, it is marred greatly by the amount of people constantly trying to sell you something. As hard as I tried to relax and take in the beautiful scenery, every minute you are dealing with another person selling tat. I found each one very pushy and they took a great deal of effort to fend off. It really affected my experience there and probably the one place where I lost my temper.
FANTASTIC. We loved the Churches at the Plaza de Armas. Down the road incredible murals, food, museums, people, all not to be missed.

Plaza de Armas. This is a beautiful plaza with spanish architecture, Incan statues and the beautiful Christo Blanco looking down on you from the hill above. I was not expecting Cusco to be as interesting and modern as it was. Lots of restaurants, museums and attractions to see.
Beautiful. Great historic significance shows great Peruvian character. This is a must see location. Cusco is a lovely city.

Always something going on. Maybe it was just because there was a festival during the four days we were in Cusco, but there were always parades of people in colorful costumes at the square. It made for good pictures and a lively scene, even if it did cause us to occasionally change direction because of a blocked off street.

Watch the sun rise over the city. Plaza de Armas was just steps away from our hotel. We enjoyed walking around the Plaza in the evening to view the historic churches and the landscaped park beautifully lit up. In the morning, I enjoyed a run through the Plaza to watch the sun rise over the city.

Beautiful Plaza with great shopping. Look. You are in a foreign country with many very poor people. There is going to be crime. I wish I'd been more aware. The plaza was lovely, but the sights and sounds made me complacent. I had may wallet and all of my credit cards, license etc., lifted. I could rant and rave...and i did my share, but when I think back, the child that took it thought he was doing his best to support his family. Does the loss of my money and things hurt? Absolutely. Will I visit again? Absolutely. Did I somehow help the people of Peru? I hope so. Just be aware of the dangers and you will be fine. Keep money in a money belt and passport in a separate place. It's not hard to do.
The spirit of Cuzco. Festivals, shopping, restaurants, historic buildings, whatever you want from Cuzco, you got it almost 24 hours a day..

Take your time to really check it all out!. You think you have seen it all...but there is so much detail in every single corner of this Plaza,that you really need to walk around it again. Many restaurant,shops, travel agencies museum and the Cathedral adorn the Plaza de Armas in. Cusco. And every corner will give you a new place to look at.
Touristy but beautiful. Good restaurants nearby and overpriced shops. Great place for a walk and pictures, but other than this not much around unless you are keen to go in a church.
Architecturally magnificent. Good for lounging about but you will be approached by people selling something if you sit on the benches. MacDonalds is best VFM for people watching.

Fun but very touristy. This is arguably the center of Cusco, at least the tourist part. The main square is dominated by expensive restaurants and bars, all with surprisingly familiar fare: McDonald's, pubs, Starbucks. The center of the square is the iconic statue of an Incan king and the largest building in the square is the Santa Domingo Cathedral. This cathedral is actually a pretty cool place and deserves a stop, with a guide, for an explanation of the grand and ornate relics inside. Bottom line: You will spend time here and be dropped off here for much of your trip, but make sure you go out and elsewhere.

Beautiful plaza - best so far for us in S Americas. Great place to do people watching, eat a snack, drink a beer or a coca tea. Enjoyed it much. A few streets away are shops, markets, historical sites, major hotels, super restaurants.

Plaza de armas. We went on.a tour in 6/22/2014 with the group Explorica. The guide hustled us from our hotel, Casa de Hermanas, to the very center of the plaza where there is a fabulous fountain surrounded by many statues. All of the sudden we heard a band strike up! He had gotten us there at the exact time that the guard marched out in front of the castle. It was amazing! Place was muy crowded, it being the day after the solstice. Many amazing floats for the parade and tens of thousands of people. Tens of thousands. People. There was a huge stage at one end of the plaza where they held celebration until late into the night. We could hear the music and crowd until late into the night. Unforgettable.
chill out. So pretty and great atmosphere during Inti Raymi celebrations, a great place to chill out and read for a while in the sun.

A must see for travelers!. The Plaza is the center of town and always busy! The traditional garb is so colorful and fun to see, the llamas (or were they alpacas?) made me smile, enjoyed passing through the plaza each day. One night, there was a dance party outside in the plaza! So much fun! Only downside, MANY beggars in plaza can be hard to deal with.

Where everything goes on .. Wherever you want to go in Cuzco you will pass the Plaza, there goes the parades for a complete month if you go in June. All of the communities dresses in bright colors and dance. But also is a little cold in this time of the year. There are in the arches some nice restaurants.

Heart of the City. Whatever a tourist might want, he probably can find it here among shops, restaurants, street vendors/artists and scenery. The square always is bustling. It thrives on the tourists' dollars (or soles), so if you want value, explore the side streets. We found amazing buys on North Face down jackets at a quarter of the usual costs, not to mention delicious restaurants hungry for our business. Remember that cash in local currency is best. MasterCard is accepted in a few places, but Visa is hit or miss.

Great public space!. Plaza de Armas is an amazing place, where Cusco inhabitants meet and where the big celebrations take place. If you visit Cusco in June, you can enjoy everyday of tipical dances and wonderful dresses... The scale of the Plaza indicates the importance Cusco had in the colonial times... The Plaza is a very clean and safe place and under the "porticos" around the plaza you can find beutiful shops and nice restaurants...We visit the Plaza many times during our trip! It is worth!
Great site. There was much restored so you could see what it was like back in the day. Easy access and well maintained

Central Spot to People Watch. You'll inevitably come across the plaza de armas if you head to the church or walk around the town at all. There are some great restaurants right off the plaza, and it is stunning to see at night!

A really Nice Gathering Place. We were in Cusco in May, three days before we did the 4 days, 42 km Inca Trail hike to Machu Picchu. Every day we walked to Plaza de Armas from our B&B in San Blas, took family pictures, and met travellers from other countries. The local St. Pedro market is only a short walk from the Plaza, and the goods and products at St. Pedro are more fair price than shops around the Plaza.

Medival Plaza at sunset. We came straight from the airport driving with our guide Pilar through the contemporary Cusco and all of a sudden arrived in the middle of the last millennium! The Plaza with its golden statue and the Cathedral was all ablaze by the descending sun , people were drinking and laughing on the bars' balconies and Madame History was definitely on the square! The air was clear and cool, red roofs of Cusco were shining in the last rays of sun and Incas Souvenirs were everywhere. We were in Peru, on the ancient Plaza and we could feel it with our hearts, see it by our own eyes and even hear it in the conversations of the passerby! The transformation was absolutely amazing!

Great architecture. We loved the shops, restaurants and the main cathedral. The Spanish architecture was beautiful. we spent about six hours walking around, and then took a bus tour of Cusco at sunset.

Amazing. Beautiful, charming, fun, exciting. Has a great energy and not nearly as crowded or touristy as I expected. The plaza de Armas in Cusco reminds me of the fairytale city in Shrek. Truly a magical place.

Definitely one of SA´s prettiest. This is a real Plaza de Armas as it should be: the city's highlights are there, you feel in its center, it is a meeting and gathering place for locals and tourists alike, and in the evenings the lights make it really romantic. If only it were warmer in Cusco....

Magical and Lively. We arrived at the start of the Winter Solstice Festival - the parades, dancing, partying. The colors.We visited the plaza when we first arrived into the Andes, and again our last night. Most of the buildings' doors were closed for the parade, but from the outside, the architecture is impressive. At night, most were closed due to the outdoor parties and time of day. The Plaza is a relatively clean area, nice for a romantic stroll - or acclimation to the altitude. If you visit at night in the winter - bundle up.

Good place to hang out in the sun. Great place to people watch and chill out for a while. Lots of seats some sun and some shade. The traders will come over and leave you alone once you show no interest.
Busy and lively. Late June around winter solstice is busy (and crazy) time in the middle of Cusco as we discovered with many festivities and celebrations. all good fun and interesting to watch.
cool place. i stayed here for two days before my inca trail and its full of life especially at night lots of good restaurants bars and clubs. if you wnt to party go to mama africa good fun

Plenty of Festivals. Visited in June 2014 and there were plenty of activities and festivals. It can get a little crowded so take care to watch your valuables but with normal precautions you shouldn't have a problem. This was a great place to people watch and enjoy Peruvian Culture.

Go to the Market. Nice plaza, and similar in quality to those you will find in other Peruvian cities. Definitely worth going to browse the shoppes and restaurants surrounding the square. But the real experience is going to the market down the street (just ask for directions from just about anybody). The market is huge and has anything you could expect and more. Just beware...if you're in the target market for an item, see if you can have somebody else buy it. For example, a man was selling skincare products to the girls in our group for S/.35 but when I came by asking how much, he gave it to me for S/.10.

the shoe shine capital of peru!. Sit back and watch the world go by. Get a shoe shine for a dollar and he will even let you read his paper while you wait. The shoe shines are actually exceptional suprisingly.

Average Plaza.... You will find yourself here at assorted times while in Cusco, and that is just fine. The Cathedral is here. It's lively during the day, and there are some decent shops and cafes around the perimeter. There is really nothing else of note here. Everyone is trying to sell you something, and annoying...AND this is an unsafe place to be after dark. You won't find much here, hence the just average review.
Plaza de Armas. Excellent place for people watching, shopping, eating. There are 2 churches, a must see; this also is a meeting point for entertainment.

Beautiful and happening place. I really enjoyed spending time sitting at the plaza de armas and people watching, it is very busy with lots of travellers and local people in their traditional clothes. Lots of venders sell things on the street, but they will take no for an answer and are not that annoy. The fountain is beautiful and the cathedrals are beautifully lit in the evenings, all the spanish colonial houses made this plaza very special. The square is more beautiful in the evening I think, where I can see all the lights from the surrounded mountains light up in the background.

Enchanting square. The Plaza de Armas should not be missed. The architecture is beautiful and the surrounding area is filled with interesting little shops and restaurants. I found it most beautiful at night. This was definitely my favourite place in Cusco!

Fun, so long as you dont sit down. Cusco's Plaza de Armas is very touristy. It is surrounded by a couple of nice churches, the Compañia de Jesus, and the Cathedral. There is also a MacDonalds and quality Alpaca goods shops. At all hours of the day you will be approached by people with a pile of paintings under their arm. If you sit down they will come and sit beside you and proceed to flick through dozens of pictures, telling you in detail what they are. It makes for an interesting conversation but can get tiresome after the third of fourth time it happens. I was here on a Saturday morning and there was some great street entertainment in front of the cathedral. People in masks whipping each other.

Easy to see !. Take some time to walk around this area. It is not very big, so walk around and take your time. Lots of little shops and restaurants. Sit along the steps near the Cathedral and take it all in !

HISTORY, BEAUTY, PICKPOCKETS AND SHAMELESS VENDORS. If not for the issue of the pickpockets and the almost constant assault by people trying to sell you (mostly) junk like mass produced earrings, "paintings" and "crafts", this plaza would be rated as an excellent place to visit by me. You really shouldn't miss it, but while you are there, you need to pretend that you are on the seedier side of Times Square and be extremely vigilant. Keep your valuables close to you (front is best) and don't flash a lot of $. (I-phones are especially targeted!) Be very careful at the ATMs and practice saying the phrase "No, Gracias" politely - but firmly - to the vendors who roam the plaza. The more time you spend here, the more annoying it becomes and the more you feel as if you are being viewed as a walking wallet. What bothers me more than anything else here is how shamelessly and frequently very young children are used as tools to entice potential customers. There are many, many beautiful, locally made arts and crafts to be seen and purchased in Peru, but you will not find much that falls into that category in the plaza. If you do decide to stop and buy something from a vendor, get your money ready before you do so, try to have close to - if not exact - change, and be prepared to be besieged by other vendors who see you making your purchase. When walking about this plaza, you will likely also be approached by traditionally costumed women and children with llamas offering to pose with you for a photograph, for a small price. If you decide to go for it, again, pay attention to the people around you and don't put down your belongings. (I'm more comfortable doing these kinds of things and souvenir shopping in general at the market in Pisac, about 40 minutes outside of Cusco.) The plaza is beautiful and always clean, the cathedrals are both well worth a visit, especially the main one (Cusco Cathedral?) and you'll find some decent cafes and restaurants here, but you need to go up to San Blas, or to one of the big markets (like San Pedro) or to neighborhoods outside of the main plaza to find the more authentic and unique arts, crafts and eateries. There is a pretty good little juice place that offers a huge selection of freshly squeezed tropical juices and blends, with a menu that lists and describes the health benefits of various juices...they also have a delicious coca tea with lime and mint ... yum! Sit upstairs for a great view of the plaza. (BTW, the absolute best place to go for juices is the "juice ladies" at the San Pedro market, where you will get a FRESH blender-full of whatever you'd like for about $5!) TRAFFIC ALERT! If you are planning to take a taxi somewhere that will require going through the plaza, check first at your hotel to see if any activities are scheduled for that day. In the week that we were there, there was a large demonstration by public school teachers and a large sort of parade/competition/ceremony involving hundreds of school children from around Peru. Cars coming in to the square from the side roads were trapped, some for a very long time, before they could get through!Speaking of taxis, do yourself a favor and ask BEFORE you get in how much it will be to reach your destination. The prices vary widely depending upon how much they think you'll pay, basically. For the most part, they are within reason- but just don't assume that because you took a cab from your hotel to San Blas for 3 sols yesterday that the same ride will cost the same tomorrow...and cabs arranged through your hotel will often cost more than if you go flag one down on your own.

Fun during the night, annoying during the day. Plaza de Armas is certainly pretty but there is some many people that try to sell you things (at least 30 an hour) that it makes it really annoying. I dont normally like big cities too so that might explain why I didnt really like it. BUT, for the nightlife, it is really cool: there is a lot of cool bars where you can have pretty good music from all around the world.
Beautiful City Center. Lovely city center surrounded by cathedrals built by the Spanish. Tons of shops, even a McDonalds hidden under the arches.

Nice central square with choice eateries and cafés. Central square providing access to many nice coffee shops, bars and restaurants. Alternatively sit in the square people watching. Some people selling paintings may get a bit annoying though.

Very nice spot to view both the cathedral and Jesuit church.. We enjoyed sitting in the center of the plaza, taking photos and people watching. There are many people trying to sell you things, but if you are not interested, just look them in the eye and politely, but firmly, say 'no thank you'.

Concentrated history. The Plaza de Armas has played a key, if rather bloody, role in the history of Peru. Atahualpa, the last Inca king, was beheaded here by the conquistadores. A couple of hundred years later, the Plaza saw revolutionary leader Tupac Amaru II have his arms and legs pulled off by ropes attached to horses, before his head suffered a similar fate to Atahualpa's. On two and a half sides of the square are the remnants of numerous Inca palaces and other large dwellings, stonework still in incredible condition, converted into houses by conquistadores (who added balconies and a Spanish-style series of arches, making a covered terrace round the square) and most recently turned into shops and restaurants (including, unfortunately, a McDonalds and KFC). To the north east is the imposing edifice of the cathedral, and on the south eastern side lies the Jesuit church. Almost everything you'll want to see and do in Cusco lies within a 10 minute walk of the Plaza de Armas, so you'll inevitably find yourself passing through here frequently. Or else simply find a place to have a coffee (preferably not Starbucks; yes there is one of these too) and watch the world go by. Be warned that you will inevitably be mobbed by locals trying to sell you tourist tat, either acrylic hats or tacky artwork that is mass produced in a factory elsewhere in town, despite whatever claims the seller might make that it's "their" work.

Best Place to People Watch. Never a quiet moment in the Plaza de Armas, no matter what time of day. If you sit long enough on a sunny park bench, you'll get to hear a band play, buy a trinket from a local, and pet a friendly stray dog.

The best place in Cusco. You can spend the whole day just by sitting in one of the benches and watch life flowing by. The place is beautifully decorated with cathedrals, churches, fountain, restaurants and shops.The central attraction in Cusco.

~ The Center of the Navel of the World ~. At one time, it is said that the Inca had beach sand brought in to cover the Plaza for his pleasure.At another time, the Spanish Conquistadors were holed up in one building here, completely surrounded by Incan warriors who *nearly* crushed them completely, which of course would have completely changed the entire history of Peru from 1500's on.Today, it is the centerpiece of Cusco- both architecturally as well as culturally. Budget some time to simply spend here doing little more than soaking in the ambiance, feasting on the architecture, and watching the people, tourists and locals, doing their thing.It is highly advisable to additionally visit at night, as it is a spectacular sight ( before 10 pm, the fountain turns off and the shops go dark ) to see it lite up, glowing, and surrounded by the foothills beyond... and, of course, the ever present and trippy "floating Jesus" up near the long-ago sacked and dismantled old fortress. If a nice dinner is in your budget, there are a number of fine restaurants located on the second floors of these buildings with enclosed balconies offering splendid views of the entire Plaza, church, and Cathedral. Simply keep an eye out for the menus at the foot of the stairwells leading to the second floor, as the restaurants and not easily seen or identifiable to the casual passerby.If you've done any advance reading about the history of the Incan empire, and the Spanish Conquest, your imagination will be full of vivid recollections of the history that took place here. I recommend The Last Days of the Incas, by Kim MacQuarrie. This should be required reading for anyone traveling to MP & the SV, and it's a delightfully easy read.
Spanish Heritage. The view of the square takes you back to a feel of Spain (Sevilla? ) The lanscape, the wooden balconies, the imposing cathedral. Everything is so imponent.
Plaza. My husband and loved how we could walk to all the attractions in the plaza. It is a busy plaza and also be prepared for locals with items for purchase.
Beautiful .. Great spot for photos, food and shopping. The city has really cleaned this space up a lot. A must see when there in Cuzco.

Could not get away from people selling things!!. Avoid Plaza de Armas unless you want to be constantly hounded by people selling things. Every 30 seconds someone was in my face and most you had to tell no multiple times. Cusco was the only place in Peru that I felt so overwhelmed with the sales people.

Nice both during the day and evening. The architecure is really cool. There's plenty to see, do and eat around the square. It was a beautiful sight both during the day and in the evening hours as well. We couldn't stop taking pictures.

Safe enjoyable Peruvian plaza. With the statue of Pachacutec as it's centerpiece, this plaza is inviting for it's openness and sense of security (even at night). Nice shops and restaraunts surround the plaza.

Nice Main Square. The main square is not big but it is surrounded by shops and restaurants. The catherdral is exactly opposite to the main square. There are some chairs in the square, you can take a rest on them or on the steps of the catherdral. It is interesting to see the cars flowing from one side to the other.

Prettiest Peruvian Plaza. The Plaza de Armas in Cusco is the prettiest we visited during our 20 day trip of Peru. Beautiful gardens, fountain - best place for people watching although you'll be harrassed/annoyed/pestered to buy buy buy..... there is official police, tourist police, traffic police everywhere who will deter these merchants. But they were the cheapest souvenirs in tours and trying to earn a living so give them a chance. If you say no, they won't annoy they'll walk away.

The HUB for people watching. Perfect spot to sit to rest the feet a bit. It is a perfect spot to watch all of the different people and cultures converge on the center of town and it's historical attractions.

Great architecture & historic buildings. Excellent place to visit, with great restaurants, shopping, chilling, walking, people watching, chatting with the locals, having fun with the street vendors, and much more. Quite a safe place with a few cops around. Lots of pigeons.
beautiful buildings and nice suroundings. All the buildings and atmosphere they create day and night. nice shops and restaurants around. the sellers may bother sometimes but neverharassing
chiling in Peru. excellent Plaza to walk around and do some shopping, or just enjoy the landscape since the entire Plaza is very historic.

Great Square to Hang out and Sign up for tours. Very nice square to hang out in. There are many tourist shops that line the square. Great place to sign up for tours. Good prices. There are so many hiking stores that sell knock off North Face clothes. If you need Internet there is a Starbucks on the second floor in the Square. You will be approached by many people to look at Art and local goods. Prices can be negotiated down to crazy levels. Offer 25% of what they ask and slowly come up. Walk away and you will have the best price as they chase you down for your soles.

Excellent atmosphere, food, people watching. A great place to spend some time, any time of day. The food in surrounding restaurants is great. If you can score a balcony seat, enjoy watching everything without being approached to buy things every 5 minutes (ha). Even the people selling goods make it a good experience - some will stop to chat about their background and lives, which can be very interesting.

Find a restaurant with a balcony for the best view. Plazas are so unique to Central and South America and they all have their own beauty and culture. One of the most difficult parts is to take it all in, but in Cusco, they help you out by surrounding the Plaza de Armas with restaurants and balconies. We ate three of our meals at various places in the Plaza, all sitting on the balcony and it was truly the best way to take in everything at the Plaza while enjoying a delicious (if not slightly overprice) meal or cup of coffee.

Gotta be there on a Sunday!. We were so fortunate to be staying at the Hotel Plaza De Armas, and there to see the festivities in the Plaza on Sunday morning. Amazing parades of the military, schools, community dancers and more. There was a flag raising ceremony, as well. We walked over to the cathedral and were blessed to have the opportunity to hear the choir singing for a bit. Absolutely beautiful!

Great center of the city. A lovely and bustling plaza. There are always children and dogs playing in the park, and of course the vendors as well.This plaza has a wide variety of restaurants. Even the most expensive ones were very affordable on an American student budget. Not much nightlife.

Interesting area. Very interesting and beautiful - many small shops and restaurants around. There are a lot of locals trying to sell small items... make sure you let them know if you are not interested - just ignoring them will not help you. Look them in the eye and say "No gracias". It may take more than once but they will retreat - they are just trying to make a living. Great people watching!

Beautiful but too many interruptions. My family and I were told that the Plaza de Armas was one of the first things we needed to see when we visited Cusco. We did visit and it was quite beautiful. However, in just 15 minutes, we were approached by at least 10 individuals selling various things. Some of the merchants were quite persistent. We were also approached by several children selling small items, which was disconcerting. So if you are going to the plaza, expect it to be beautiful but be aware that it might not be a peaceful place to sit and enjoy.
the square. lots of shops close by and restaurants and scotia bank, the cathedral and is pretty safe, stay in this area, its walking to everything

Lots to see here and safe even later in the eve. We were overnighting in Cusco on our way to Lima and wandered to the Plaza in search of food. It was after 9pm so not all the stores were open but it was still bustling with people everywhere. As two "older" ladies we felt perfectly safe. The restaurants were all open and crowded. Several we went into were full so we ended up eating at the bar in one of them. The service was excellent and we enjoyed our meal without having to wait a few hours for a table. After dinner we wandered through several shops on our way way. We also stopped in to see the cathedral- it was magnificent.

Very Cultural. I loved this place, very cultural but also there is a lot of bars and night life activities around to go. If you see girls with Peru traditional clothing and alpacas/llamas if you want to get a picture do not think is free!

Can't help but to visit. This is a beautiful square and the Center of Cusco. There are sites & restaurants all around. We were there on a Friday and there was a parade (not sure why) and then in the evening there was live music and folk dancing. It is a very lively place. There are locals dressed in traditional clothing and for 1 sole you can have your picture taken with them.
Day or night, wonderful for people watching!. Like a movie set, beautiful. Twice we happened upon musicians, another time a religious procession. Benches comfy.

Sit and shake your head.... ... Unless of course you actually want to buy something from the friendly street pedlars, take photos with traditionally dressed up young or old ladies, get your shoes fixed or shined. Otherwise, you can do what I do and just sit there, people watch, take photos of the great surrounding and keep shaking my head to say no :) It's a great place to be, especially earlier part of the morning when the whole place is not that crowded up yet. You will get clear shots (it can be quite a bother having too many people crowding in your frame when you just want a decent landscape shot) of the surrounding buildings. A lot of people also use it as a meeting point and you will be able to generally find anything you need in the shops surrounding the Plaza.
Meeting point. It`s Cusco`s touristic and activities heart. Everything spins around it and it`s great as a meeting point because everybody knows where it is and how to get there.
Nice friendly square for people watching. Felt very safe here. Good if you want your shoes cleaned! Lots of restaurants around the square. Many upstairs with balconies overlooking the square

Beautiful but busy. The Plaza de Armas is a beautiful plaza with the Cathedral and Church being very dominant features. The central fountain seems to be a favorite photo point and there are an assortment of restaurants, tour agencies and stores surrounding it. The down side is it is also very touristy with a Starbucks, McDonalds and KFC and just try sitting on one of the park benches for 15 minutes and see how many people try to sell you something.

Touristy but pleasant. This part of Cusco is set up well for tourists, and that's okay. The Plaza de Armas is very scenic and surrounded by interesting churches, restaurants, supply stores, and touristy shops. Also a few banks for exchaning money into soles. As the center for tourists in Cusco you will almost certainly pass through this spot and it's worth doing so since there is a lot to see here.There are a lot of people selling stuff, which detracts somewhat from the idea of just enjoying the space but they are not overly aggressive.

Amazing sights, annoying hawkers. This is the epicenter of Cusco, so you will spend time here. The churches are incredible. The fountain and the benches in the center of the small park are lovely. The hawkers ruin it all however. Too bad the authorities don't control the constant harassment of tourists.

A beautiful tourist trap. Make sure to visit the Plaza del Armas at night as it is truly magical. This is the center of Cusco and definitely the center of tourism. Here you will find an abundance of restaurants and stores that cater to the tourists. People will ask you to purchase their goods. Although people ask, they move on when one states a simple "no gracias." BEWARE THE TRAFFIC..cars do not stop for pedestrians in and around Plaza de Armas

Spectacular town square. Wonderful architecture, a nice fountain with a beautiful gold statue and churches that you can visit inside make this a very interesting location. Lima Tours took us here as part of a Cuzco tour. They also took us to the Tunupa restaurant at the same square for an enjoyable meal.

Loved the people watching. We stayed just steps away from the Plaza and could hop out there anytime and enjoy the bustle - reminded me a lot of Madrid. The cathedral is gorgeous. We could sit, relax and people watch.
Heart of the City. This is the central square within Cusco. Parades, banks, restaurants, people selling knick-knacks and dogs populate this area. Very pretty to take in the view.

Relax!. Place des Armas is "the Center" of Cusco! Apart from the Cathedral and the Jesuit church representing the Colonial Times with its somewhat dire bearing on the native Peruvial people the place is flanked with original 2-storey buildings Cuscean style. If you need a rest from exploring the city sit down on one of the benches and whatch the scenery. It's truly entertaining.

Pretty, lots of restaurants & dogs. We ate around here often- it was pricier, but more populated, so we felt safer. We wish we had time to go into the churches, but we didn't. We enjoyed giving our leftovers to the stray dogs! Papacha and Greens were two great restaurants. Mama Africa is a club and is free with led-salsa dancing from 9-11 every night... SO fun! smokey, but fun!

In the center of it all. Try to go at various times of the day/night as the light plays different atmospheres. Our favorite moment was the late afternoon with long shadows and golden light (great photos :)

Too many street and food vendors. Quiet a nice area - would be even better without the traffic and street vendors. Cusco is going to have to deal with excessive traffic and diesel pollution in the very future. If they could ride the city center of the auto - it would be a much better place. Air pollution around 5 pm is EXCESSIVE on some of the smaller street. Plaza is lovely - eat at Limo for a great view. Restaurant hackers on the street are excessive. - Limo does not do this - they do not have to .

A very pleasant walk with beautiful views. The surroundings are gorgeous and the weather was to die forI liked the friendly police who were very helpful, the only annoyance were too many people selliings. Not as bad as Sa Pa in Viet Nam!

Beautiful square, clean, and historic. When you arrive to the square in Cusco you'll be very pleased. It's a beautiful square, very clean, and somewhere you can just sit relax and take in the history.The fountain is very nice but the water doesn't run 24/7. I didn't post any pictures as I think the current 400+ are sufficient. How in the world could I add to that?There is a police presence throughout the square and town, nothing alarming, but it does add to the sense of security which is nice.The only drawback, the four rather than 5, were the dogs and street vendors. The dogs I can handle, they don't hassle you, walk on by if you're not showing them interest, and don't try to sell you prints of paintings, jewelry, or alpaca-based clothing. The street vendors: annoying.
Go and Relax... A big plaza! clean and safe. Lots of nice rain and people! I wish to be there back again! don't miss it

Where everyone gets together. The Plaza de Armas in Cusco, is a place where locals and tourists gather around. Sometimes to gaze the magnificent architecture around, or just to take a break from a heavy traveling day. I enjoyed watching people walking around and the variety of culture that merges here.Day and night it has its own personality. The cathedral looks magnificent with the light work.

Beautiful Active Plaza. I enjoyed my time here on many trips. It is great to see the architecture, see the people who are locals and travel, to rest, or to see parades. It is wonderful to enjoy a helado on a beautiful sunny day. Night time is magical as well. Probably one of my favorite plazas in the world.

A beautiful plaza to grace a historical city. In my opinion it’s among the most beautiful plazas in the world, with its green lawns and flower gardens, surrounded by several historical colonial cathedrals and churches, and superb examples of Inca stone work never far away.During the day it is frequented by locals and tourists alike, bathing in the sun, relaxing on the benches or taking photographs of themselves in front of the fountain (see my photos).On the down side you will be hassled by young girls selling souvenirs, boys claiming to be artists selling pot boilers from Hong Kong, and ladies in silly costumes holding baby llamas pushing in on your photo session and asking for “propina”. Best no to engage them unless you are willing to buy.Note: I was warned by a local not to use the travel agents around the square, as turned out to be good advice.

Iconic Square. Plaza de Armas is Cusco's iconic main square. It takes up one large city block. With the city's relatively low architectural profile, it is a marvelous square in which to walk through or sit, taking in the strolling locals and the ubiquitous vendors, and the views of the surrounding hills and the two large cathedrals that adjoin the square. It is also nice to sit in one of the bars or restaurants with outdoor tables on their second or third floor terraces to get a perspective of the square from above. Quaffing a cold one on a sunny day and people-watching from above provides a distinct pleasure.The one downside of the square, which the authorities should correct, is that there are no toilet facilities within close proximity of the square, so one must use one of the establishments that line the adjacent street which means popping for a purchase of some kind.

The place to hang out in Cusco. This plaza is the heart and soul of Cusco and as a tourist, I found myself hanging around it nearly everyday.Just watching the busy people going by, the great small shops and many tourists hanging around is fun enough but this plaza is also the home to all the best night clubs in the city.
Center of Cusco. A very lovely and large square with a lot of historical colonial buildings along the sides together with two important churches.

Balconies. You pass through it to go anywhere in the touristy areas. Mind the fast and unstoppable cars! The best bit is the balcony style. Practically every shop on the square has one: even KFC and Starbucks! You can sit up over the pavement and watch the world go by.

Tourist trap.... Although the beautiful cathedrals and historic center are beautiful, it is ridden with solicitors who are relentless. My best advice? Although it is rude, just walk by and don't engage. Try to visit places like San Blas or San Francisco.

a true experience. As a solo traveller my stopover in Cusco was going to be unreal. It was breathtaking. The Plaza de Armas has something about it that makes you want to go back and find out more. Maybe it's the giant Cathedrals or the unique history that surrounds Cusco. You'll find plenty of cafes and shops if you have the time away from completing the Inca Trail. Sit back and enjoy it. Be mindful of the locals that are really keen to impress you with their art work and make you pay for it. They can be annoying, especially if you give them an inch of interest. Make your intentions clear from the beginning. English is common in the Plaza so don't panic if your Spanish is very slow like mine. Traffic can be tricky too, just follow the rules and the other people.
Incredible Square. This is one of the most incredible squares in South America! The buildings are beautiful and there are upstairs restaurants with balconies from which to watch life happening there.

I look at it and I see the world!. Here you get the essence of Cusco and at the same time you can meet people from all over the world! You can "samba" in the street with a group of Brazilians, you can watch a local wedding, a local parade and you can participate in a local cultural festival. Yes, I did it all in Plaza de Armas!Also, you find a lot of restaurants, travel agencies, hotels around it.

Center city square to visit and wander around. Not only the square is worth visiting, The surroundings are also astonishing. The area is safe enough, lots of different police around. Lots of handmade souvenir sellers present.
Nice clean square with interesting sights.. A good place to people watch, you can sit on the Cathedral steps or on one of the benches around the fountain in the centre. Lots of hawkers though.

Safe center-city square. Nice intro to Cusco, big cathedral which is an interesting visit right there, many reliable restaurants close by. Many beat cops walking at night so this square (and all of Cusco) is safe for anyone. Hawkers abound here but the police actually chase them off after a while.

Gives you a feel for Cusco. I would not miss this spot if you're coming to Cusco. You don't need much time to stroll around it and you won't be very impressed, but it gives you a grounding and a jumping off point for exploring Cusco (why do we change the 'c' to a 'z' in English and make it 'Cuzco'?).
Okay as squares go. No the nicest town square I have been to in South America. Lots of tourists (including me I guess). Good shopping around it and some restaurants on the square and just off it.

Full of life and vivacity. This is the place in Cusco where it all happens, demonstrations, family get togethers, sightseeing, buying, selling, eating and drinking.This is hub of all social comings and goings.The square is surrounded by shops selling all sorts of gifts including the much sort after baby alpaca textiles. Here is where you would hope on a sightseeing bus and visit all the local sites.

A great place to start your tour and do a bit of people watching. With the cathedral, numerous shops and restaurants and a nice open space with benches to sit, what is not to like. It really feels like the center of town and has spectacular views of the surrounding hills from virtually very angle. Plus this plaza is the source of many historic tales.
Very Enjoyable Plaza. This is a very nice plaza with wonderfully picturesque buildings and vistas surrounding it. We spent more time here than expected just enjoying the atmosphere and scenery.
Nice. Nice, center of old Cusco about 4 cathedrals in the centersitting in the park is nice, vendors come up to you to sell things so be careful, the children know how to pick pocket tourists

Must see. Lively plaza, like a walk back in time going up Huacaypata and finding the 12 angled stone and the "puma" and "serpent". I have never felt so safe, security guards all around the plaza. Good tourist shopping along the way.
Stunning!!!. Beautiful and well kept, great photo opportunities, and nice to enjoy the view whilst eating on the balcony of the many restaurants on the square.

Beautiful plaza and friendly people. My friend and I stayed in Tierra Viva that was closest to the plaza. The plaza is surrounded by shops and restaurants and was always busy. The plaza is beautiful in the afternoon and night time and peaceful in the morning. I felt always felt safe walking through the plaza and through alleyways. There are vendors trying to sell you stuff but will leave you alone should you just say no and show no interest at all.

New Year there it's crazy!. We've been at Plaza Armas at New Year Eve and it's crazy!We felt like war started. There were fireworks everywhere, flying towards people. Plaza is beutiful during day and night time.

Love the plaza!. Great square with lots of things to do: shopping, inexpensive massages, fabulous restaurants!! A lot of merchants/vendors will hunt you down to buy their merchandise, but if you say no a few times, they will leave you alone. Loved it!

A wonderful place to sit in the centre of Cusco. The Plaza de Armas is a great place to just sit and watch the passing parade of tourists, backpackers and Peruvian people, some dressed in their traditional consumes. There are two large churches, covered colonnades with shops below and balconied restaurants on the second level, and a great statue of an Inca warrior in the middle of the Plaza. There are wonderful views of the hills surrounding Cusco from the Plaza too. What's not to like?

Adorable square, lots of shops and restaurants right on the square. Many people trying to sell stuff to tourists, but they leave you alone if you say no. Lots of restaurant and cafe options and lots of nearby shopping and markets.

Impressive. This square is beautiful when you can see it. It is so busy that sometimes all you see are people. Sunday mornings have the military parades, a not to miss, if you like to see local culture displaying itself with pride. I suggest not staying near the Plaza if you want some peace and quiet- this place is active all the time, it seems.

New Year 2014 @ Plaza de Armas, Cusco. We had an amazing time in Cusco! Minutes before midnight thousands of locals and travelers congregated at the Plaza de Armas and when the New Year arrived hundreds of fire works, music and people from every corner of the planet where there in a incredible demonstration of love. All the races, colors, religions together to celebrate in peace. We follow the local traditions; before 12 we had written in a paper all the bad that happened during 2013! The tradition says that at 12 you need to burn that piece of paper and walk around the square something that we all have done that night! The energy was unbelieved!!! Thanks www.outlandcuisine.com
keep an eye on your wallet. Beautiful place to take pictures but keep an eye on your wallet, camera, etc. The surroundings are nice to walk and many places to visit. It´s worth a half day at least.
People watching!. We were fortunate enough to be there for the Christmas Eve market. The sights, sounds, and smells were fascinating. Lots of good places to eat and drink in the area.

Christmas at the Plaza. On Christmas eve we saw hundreds of people from neighboring villages and towns come to the plaza with their families. They had bags and sacks of things to sell at the market. All families camped out at the plaza on the eve, braving the cold and rain. At midnight the bells began to toll at the Cathedral and fireworks went off for about 40 minutes. the entire sky was lit up. Next morning, we saw hundreds of white tents pop up all around the plaza. Families were taking their baby Jesus' to the cathedral for blessings, while others were worked their way through the market creating their custom nativity sets to take back home.At the same time, people like us had our ponchos and umbrellas and worked our way through the market buying pachamama earrings, alpaca scarves and 'machino' sweaters and caps.

Gorgeous. I love Cuzco and Plaza de Armas is stunning plenty of tourist and locals around. This is place is so peaceful. Plenty of restaurants and shops. Worth a visit. You can find starbucks, McDonald and even KFC in the square.

Christmas in Cusco. Plaza de Armas was in full Christmas Splendor when I arrived on Christmas Day.Tourists and local families melded together as they strolled around the Plaza on the way to visit the Nativity Scene, restaurants or the Christmas larger than life decorations on the plaza green.The plaza is reminiscent of what the local scene probably looked like a century ago. It keeps the history alive in Cusco.I hope this never changes.

Great place at Christmas. The Plaza is very pretty, having been done up with lights & reindeer & a nativity scene for Christmas. If it is not raining then it is a great place to sit & take in the ambience. The outer perimeter has many touristic restaurants & shops as well money exchange places. Well worth a vist.

Nice Place to Relax. This Plaza is a nice place to relax and watch the kids chase the pigeons and people watch in the afternoon. It's surrounded by old cathedrals shops and restaurants. If you don't let the vendors bother you, it is a pleasant place to put your feet up. Take the time to talk to some of the local people to make your visit more enjoyable.
Central Cusco. Lovely plaza, with flowers and nice restaurants surrounding it, but street vendors were very annoying, would have liked to just sit down and relax there.

Lovely Plaza to hang out and people watch. If your staying in Cusco, stay in this area, lots of shops, restaurants, hotels in this very busy area. Don't go out too late alone, like in any other city., Be aware of pick pockets.

Busy in the evening. During the day the plaza de Armas gets overshadowed by the many attractions around, like Cathedral, Inca Museum et al. During the evening and night, under the lights this places looks great. The view of Cristo Blanco from here also looks great
amazing view. when you are at the Plaza de Armas you feel like people aroud there are friends, kids playing around, beaitifull gardens, security everywhere, just amazing feelings.
Nice. It was good but watch out for all the people trying to sell you junk. They really should stop this as it was annoying after the 20th person tried to sell us "their personal art"

Beautiful at Night!. We decided impulsively to step out at night to grab some dinner. We reached the Plaza De Armas in Cusco and were pleasantly surprised to see the beauty of the place at night with lights, people, fireworks and the magnificent architecture of the plaza buildings and monuments. We just grabbed a coffee and sat outside on the steps of the main cathedral. It was just so enjoyable watching people and just experiencing the ambience. Do not miss going to this place at night even if it is just for a half hour or so.

Enjoyable, people-watching plaza!. Loved this area of Cusco. The plaza was lively and colorful with people. Very nice gardens and well kept. Lots of laneways with shopping and restaurants. I'd go back in a heartbeat.

wonderful restaurants and sites and shopping!. Lovely, fountained center in Cusco with so many historical and beautiful cathedrals- excellent restaurants, Limo-236 Portal de Carnes- was a favorite- cerviche to die for! Favorite alpaca shopping- KUNA store- even had bed blankets! Kuna does not ship items so will need to ask at hotel for that service. The silver jewelry stores are too many to mention...and don't forget about the beautiful Plaza itself! I felt this was gave us insight into the heart of Cusco. Sit and watch the sunset reflecting on the surrounding mountains and feel the romance of the city as well as the history and pageantry. If you're luck you might even see a wedding entering the CathedraLOVED IT!
Imensa. Muito grande, sempre cheia de gente. Comércio, restaurantes, pizzarias, etc. Tem tudo!Very large, always full of people.Shops, restaurants, etc.. It has everything!

A nice place to people watch. After shopping around the square, we settled onto a bench in the Plaza de Armas and watched locals and tourists walk by for a while. Very pleasant place to get a feel for this wonderful area of Peru.

"The Pulsing Heart of a Living Legend". Before the conquest, the main plaza of Cusco was the Center of the World, in the Inca vision. You actually will find the "true center" as you walk out of the plaza a few steps, and will run into the headlines of the 4 quarters of the Inca empire inlaid in brass on the sidewalk.It made a strange effect to be right there, where one of the greatest empires of our past history saw its days of splendor and decline...In itself, the "Plaza de Armas" is a great place where to visit monuments and museums, shop in state of the art boutiques or bargain with street vendors, dine in characteristic restaurants, meet people from all walks of life, and enjoy the most fantastic night-view of a city lit as a surrounding firmament.The best part was to find out that, finally, they put a statue of the ninth Inca emperor, Yupanqui who renamed himself Pachacutec (Quechua for "Changer of the World") at the top of the fountain at the center of the gardens in the middle of the plaza, a sign of recognition and respect for their cultural origins, beyond all the christian impositions happened along the centuries.

Lovely plaza, but too much traffic. The plaza is lovely, surrounded by beautiful buildings and the usual shops and restaurants. However, they haven't closed it off to traffic as is true in many colonial towns, and the constant stream of traffic really takes away from the ambiance. Also, I found that it was impossible to sit in any of the plazas because the street vendors swarmed on me like flies on a picnic. Maybe it's because it was off-season and there weren't many NorteAmericanos around, but it was really unpleasant.

Teeming with life. Not only is this a beautiful square, there are many churches to visit, crafts to hunt down, a tourist info center, off-street ATM and lots of people enjoying the square. During our stay, the square was even turned into a speedway for a car racing event. Wonderful to visit day or night and close to many of Cusco's other attractions.

Loved plaza de armas. Plaza de armas is beautiful, i was there a few days ago and I couldn't be happier everything you need is nearby, tours, $ exchange, great restaurants, places to shop in case you forgot something. Such as in my case my sneakers got ruined by heavy rain and I found a great store nearby. I would definately recommend for anyone to stay at a hotel close to it, since you would only have to walk to it. I was also there for Halloween, it very nice and crowded with children trick or treating, however be aware that some kids are very pushy so becareful when handing out your candy. The clubs in the second floor like mama Africa are really good too, with all adults in customs. You can't got wrong with plaza de armas, at any time of the year.

Great people watching. As in every Latin town the central plaza is the heart of the city. You could spend the entire day just watching little ones taking their first steps or the school kids as they head home. It is a place of laughter and socializing and tourists are privileged to be included. There are almost daily parades and celebrations to entertain you, the only downside being the constant parade of vendors with something to sell. Restaurant choices abound, from McD to Inka Grill and everything in between.

Go Sunday Morning. The square is a great place to while away the time, with lots of interesting shops and restaurants as well as several churches. Every Sunday morning there is a parade with music dancing etc lasting several hours. This is real life for the locals and not some sham put on for tourists, worth seeing.
Very beautiful. A great place to sit and enjoy the beauty of Cuzco. Starbucks patio, the 2nd floor is a great place to take some beautiful shots. KFC and McD are there too.

Beautiful , romantic , and safe city. Beautiful , romantic , and safe city
