No matter what time I've seen this place is still beautiful.
Morning, noon , evening. It's always beautiful.

Beautiful, day and night. I wish we'd had a few more days to spend in Cusco. It's a beautiful city with a genuine Peruvian vibe. It's clean and everyone's friendly, and contrary to most tourist towns, you can still get a great, cheap meal right on the main square.

Where the Action is. You cannot miss this in Cusco, it is the central place where all visitors go. Busy and vibrant, but very safe with lots of police around, right next is the Cathedral, great restaurants, shops, hotels, and the gateway to San Blas and Avenue El Sol.

Nice, large square. New Inka statue in fountain (Guide told us that the fountain was added a couple years ago). This is a real gathering place for locals. It was fun to sit and watch the children playing, locals reading or meeting friends here. Nice place to catch your breath, look at the 2 cathedrals on the square and the shops and activity all around.

Lovely square. Stayed in Cusco for a few nights.And the square was meters from my hotel.Lovely place to chill out and watch the day pass by.... just sitting and admiring the lovely architecture or the lovely landscape.The square was well kept and properly maintained.On the last night night of my stay there was a concert with local musicians(loved the pan-flute and the local music).Lovely place to just chill out.
Nice square. Nice place to stay, with next to the church a Starbucks on the first floor with a nice view and excellent coffee.
Literally can't miss it. It's pretty much the center square. You won't miss it. Great architecture around the square. Very nicely kept center square

Always something to see. Absolutley beautiful, the fountains and the churches as well as the landscaping. There's usually something to see there at all hours of the day. The only downside is that there's lots of vendors trying to get you to purchase something, which can get a little tiresome, but over a great place to spend some time.

Great photo ops and people watching. I have asthma, and climbing the narrow streets can take a lot out of you. So I really enjoyed taking mini breaks in the Plaza. The people watching rivals the National Mall in DC or Central Park in NYC.

One of the most amazing places i've been. It's just one of the most amazing places i've been.
I've spent a couple of days only wondering the square.
The enviroment is wonderful, the people walking and taking pictures, everything there, is involving in a kind of nice mistic.
It's definately a must see...

Entertaining. I enjoyed walking around Plaza de Armas, theres restaurants and bars. Theres a starbucks there, which I enjoyed going to a few times. If you have never been here, you should definitely visit. Its very safe, theres police officers everywhere.

Must see in Cusco. The Plaza de Armas is the main square, center of the city and a must see if in Cusco. I loved this location and found it beautiful and interesting all around. It is a great place for pictures and an introduction to the Andean region. Very different feel at day and night - visit both times!

Incredibly Beautiful. This is the location where I fell in love with Peru. The history is fantastic and there is so much to explore. Plus, the people watching is free. Take the time to have a seat and take it all in. You'll be thankful you did. Make sure to spend a bit of time there in the day as well as evening.
Multicultural. Is the center of the social activity of the city. Is very multicultural because there are a lot of tourist and Quechua people. Almost all weekends you can see religious parades.

beautiful an full of life place. The PLAZA DE ARMAS is a very beautiful place. During the day, you can seat at the PLAZA DE ARMAS an watch a people walking , talking, trying sell something to you, and see many mountains far away.

Plaza de Armas. Cuzco's Plaza de Armas by night is a beautiful sight to see. is surrounded by historical buildings, restaurants, stores, churches, and more just like Starbucks & McDonalds . but why would you eat money when you can eat good Peruvian food

Always something. Plaza de Armas is the place where people gather for so many different events that in the week we were there we watched two colorful parades with so many costumes, a concert, and car show. There are so many restaurants around the Plaza competing with one another that we could only try a small fraction of them and there is an abundance of places for shopping.

Very Pretty Square. The square itself is pretty with lots of tourist type restaurants and many travel agencies. The cathedral on the square is 30 soles to tour, which seems a bit high and there is tiny cost to go in the museum as well.

An exciting square. This large square is surrounded by lots of colonian buildings housing,cafes,restaurants,bars and shops. Every Sunday they have a parade withmarching bands, children in costume,army, swat teams, schools all taking part in the parade. Vibrant and exciting and lasts for ages. Night scene is also vibrant with lots of choices for dinner.

A magnet for locals and tourists alike. A fascinating place. People from all over the world....the Orient, Europe, South America, North America, and other places all hanging out in the square enjoying the food, commerce, and entertainment. And there is the constant parade of colorful locals selling their wares. Add to that the beautiful park, the imposing statue, and the massive cathedral, and you see why it is such a magnet for locals and tourists alike.

Great center to behold. Really liked Cusco so much that our three day stay turned out to be a five day. I didn't know what to expect but this was a pleasant surprise. It has a little of everything, old world charm and new world amenities, such as Starbucks and McDonald's and yes KFC. The plaza is always fun to sit and people watch. There is also a double decker bus that will take you around the city and out of the city. Check it out.

Vibrant Center of Cuzco. Skip Lima on your way to Machupicchu and spend more time in Cuzco. The town is relatively safe and caters for the tourists very well. There is an endless list of things to do and great shopping and restaurants. I visited Sep 2013 and only had three nights stay. I wished I had a bit more time to fully discover the town and surrounding area.
right close to the hostel,. always something going on! you will not have time to get bored!parades, mini shows, bands, and of course the ever present street venders!

Unique. Beautiful and well preserved.. Lo que la hace impresionante es sus alrededores. La imponente catedral, los edificios coloniales de dos pisos (puede ser bastante dificil encontrar la puerta adecuada para acceder al lugar que quieres del segundo piso), las estrechas y empinadas calles, el piso (las piedras son bonitas, el asfalto es feo), y por supuesto, los cerros o montañas. Especialmente en la noche, disfrute de la vista de esas montañas llenas de luces.Las malas noticias son que las cadenas americanas ya están ahí. Aunque debo decir me gustó el Starbucks. Una pena que McDonald's y KFC ya estén ahí.What makes it stunning is the sorrounding buildings. The imposing cathedral, the colonial two-floor buildings (it can be a challenge to find the right door to access the place you want on second floors), the narrow and steep streets, the floor (stones are beautiful, asphalt is ugly), and of course, the mountains. Specially at night, enjoy the view of those mountains full of lights.The bad news is that american chains are already there. I liked the Starbucks though. McDonald´s and KFC... it's a pity.
Lovely and lively. Beautiful architecturally and the locals are wonderful.Do not miss this area. Especially in the rain (which doesn't last long) it is gorgeous.

Brace Yourself!. Plaza de Armas is the center of tourism for Cuzco. Sit down on a bench and the street vendors will swarm you. They literally line up to push whatever it is they want to sell. They don't readily accept "no". We are very glad we stayed in a different part of Cuzco and could experience the "real" city.

Really Fun Leading Up To Inti Raymi in June. We visited Cusco and were lucky enough to be there for Inti Raymi. While I understand this area can be a huge tourist trap, the area was flooded with locals celebrating leading up to Inti Raymi. Each night high school kids performed traditional dances in the Plaza. My husband and I loved the energy. I would recommend going in June for the festival.

Count the tourists. It's the place to go when you're a tourist which isn't really my "thing". Most of the city tours start there with a tour of the Basilica so it's inevitable. The shops are expensive and the people selling anything and everything are fairly relentless. You have to go there at least once during the day and then again at night but that's more than ample.

ALIVE!. This is the heart of the town and there is always something going on . Weather you like to people watch or step out for dinner or shopping this is the place to be. everyone so friendly and welling to help point you to the right direction weather its a hot cup of hot chocolate or Pollo a La Brasa someone always knows were to point you. You can easily spend hours in Plaza de Armas.

Great place to people watch. The plaza is a hive of activity. From people selling 'art', keyrings, hats, scarves, shoe cleaning and much more to the buzz of traffic and the amazing surroundings of the Andes. The plaza is everything I expected Peru to be. It's easy to pass a couple of hours here just people watching and taking in the atmosphere. The plaza is surrounded by shops, some great restaurants, the Church and the Cathedral.
great people watching. fabulous place to sit back and watch the world go by and people watch. Pretty architecture too! Always something to watch, if not just the sun setting over the hills.

Spend less time in the plaza, more time exploring around it. The plaza itself is a nice, open park and there is some decent people watching but the real attractions are the various stores, restaurants, churches, nooks and crannies around the plaza. Since all of these places warrant their own reviews on TripAdvisor I'm not factoring them into my review of the plaza, which you'll experience anyway just by visiting the historical center. It's an essential gateway to more interesting things.

Patrimonio de la Humanidad. The historical center of Lima offers the Plaza de Armas, the Cathedral where Francisco Pizarro was buried, the Convent of Santo Domingo where even at present few monks live and is the first burial place of Santa Rosa de Lima and where San Martin de Porres used to serve the poor and sick.

spent many hours here. Great for people watching, observing daily life, and relaxing in the sun. Its a well kept beautiful square. Cafes and stores though are overpriced. better to venture a little off the square for good fare and better prices.

Lovely Colonial Plaza. The Cathedral and the church of The Company of Jesus are wonderful examples of Spanish colonial churches. The Plaza is a reminder of of the importance of the city to the Spanish conquistadors. We were fortunate to be there for the festivals surrounding the Feast of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. Many religious organizations decorate and parade floats in honor of different Saints. There is music and dancing and parades in the streets surrounding the Plaza. The Plaza is the center of the city and the center of city life, surrounded by many hotels and restaurants. Definitely a must when in Cusco.
lovely. very pretty and lively. you can catch the yellow bus for a 2hour tour of Cusco and the surrounding area for $20 soles

Cuzco Plaza de Armas. It's a nice place to visit and take some pics. You can see a little bit of history, buy some gifts and enjoy a very really nice peruvian food. Be carefull with the little kids in the streets.

Picturesque. Obviously, any trip to Cusco will include a visit to the Plaza de Armas. Try to overlook the constant bombardment of massage coupons being passed out and focus on the beauty of the cathedral and surrounding mountains. It's a lovely place.

Nice big square and lots of people watching. We spent a lot of time here as the square always seem to fall in between our hotel and where we wanted to go. Always lots of people here so good people watching. With the right sunlight (late day good), can be very dramatic.

Can't miss this if you're in Cusco. If you visit Cusco while in Peru, you have to see the Plaza de Armas. It's beautiful, has tons of delicious restaurants around it, and is a great place for shopping.
It is a must in Cusco. You have to go to Plaza de Armas or main square to say properly that you know Cusco. Take pictures of all of the churches surrounding the square. You won't regret!
unreal. Amazing, totally loved this place. Defo add it to your list of places to see. Lively place which had a buzz of activity
Lots to see and do. This huge plaza is full of life, from Inka legacy to beautifu catholic churches, to excellent restaurants and cafes.

worth seeing. specially at night this baroque Spanish square is very animated, as all the 3 other squares nearby. We where lucky to see a Madonna procession with fireworks and a band. Very traditional

Centrality is asset; fan out for the good stuff.. Yup, PdA is central to the Cusco experience and it's great for pics day and night but the plaza itself is merely a reference point: whether the Mercado west, the cathedrals, McD/Starbucks for break, wifi, and bathrooms, people watching, or as a centroid for San Blas or elsewhere wandering, PdA is really a referent for other things rather than an attraction itself. Another good thing about PdA is the presence of the police though we never felt like we needed them; sure there are hawkers galore but most just end with "Okay, see you later then?" when you say no thanks -- most stuff pretty cheap currency-wise although the quality looked decent. Walk up and down nearby alleys for better deals. Crosswalks seem advisory. Lots of restaurant food options for all budgets but especially cheap street food up near Museo Inka in the evenings (among other times, see pic). Great place to end everyday before heading back to lodging. The fact that our timing was COMPLETELY lucky for catching the parade of Corpus Christi saints was awesome and view from S-bucks was perfect. Really kinda electric...

Beautiful Square. Loved this part of Cusco! A very beautiful and well maintained square, with churches and pretty architecture around. We went there a few times, and sat in the garden and also ate at restaurants around. Nice place for pictures too.
Pretty square. Nice photo op with the inca statue and well manicured flower beds. A nice spot to people watch from. Lots of restaurants and tour operators around square

Beautiful park. This main plaza has a little of everything...it has upscale shops, money exchanges, sporting good store, McDonald's, KFC, a few restaurants, beautiful cathedrals, and even a lovely setting to just breath! Worth a look. There is usually something going on in the square. A lovely spot to just hang out ... There is even a Starbucks!

See Local Culture. This is a beautiful area, both architecturally and culturally. The buildings are amazing and worth your time. But my favorite part was just sitting on the steps and watching the locals of Cusco. For a short time, I didn't feel so touristy. Don't miss this opportunity.

Square of The Warrior - Plaza de Armas ( Cusco ). Both The Cathedral of Santo Domingo and The Iglesia la Compania de Jesus (that is one of the best examples of Baroque architecture ) offers dramatic architectural landscapes. It makes the Plaza de Armas a magical place. For me, it was more than enough to wonder the square in order to take in the beauty of these two majestic buildings. If you think the buildings are impressive from a first glance, it's definitely worth taking a look inside. The golden altar piece in the Iglesia la Compania de Jesus features an image of the Virgin as well as other symbols that echoes the Roman Catholic heritage. Make sure that you grab a piscola [ pisco (is a liquor distilled from Muscat grapes) and coca cola blend ] at one of the restaurants in the square. The perfect way to say: " Me encanta plaza de armas" and to enjoy one of the most beautiful sunsets that Peru has to offer.

As nice plaza as you will find. What a beautiful plaza. The cultural heart of old Cusco, it is large and surrounded by 2 beautiful churches and tons of restaurants and shops. You could hang out and people watch or drink a Cusquena all day. Must see location in Cusco. Great place to start a tour of Cusco.

A beautiful square in Cusco. It is Cusco's main square. It resambles a lot of Spain's Plazas as it was build near the year of 1.500. Near that square you have a lot of places to eat local food and to buy local itens.
AMAZING. The square is not hard to miss as its the centre of Cusco. We were drawn back many times. make sure you take a stroll at night.

A people-watching paradise. There's so much to see without even leaving your seat! The two beautiful churches, gardens, and restaurants wrap around you. Find a nice place to sit and stay a while. Vendors will recognize you as a tourist and try to sell stuff, but they aren't pushy and will move on quickly.If you stay long enough, you're bound to see a parade, flag ceremony, or party going on. In fact, we saw some new event pretty much every time we walk through here - and that was several times per day! We even passed by about 5am one morning and there were kids practicing a synchronized dance in the street. This plaza is definitely the heartbeat of the historical city. You simply can't visit Cusco without visiting the Plaza de Armas.
Nice Sights and Area to Visit in Cusco. The square was very safe and had some nice restaraunts and shops around it. It is a must see when in Cusco.
Wow!. We visited right before the winter solstice. There were parades and dancing daily. Soo cool to sit on one of the terraces around the plaza and watch all of the goings on!

A beautiful park to enjoy!. This is like a tiny city with a colonial Spaniard style, well preserved with a beautiful garden, fountain, and historic sites you can enjoy just seated on one of the old benches. If you have the luck to be there on Corpus Christy Holiday you can see the religious procession and taste the spicy and flavored Cuzco cuisine.

Enchanting place. Plaza de Armas is one beautiful square definitely to hang out and observe the gorgeous views of the mountains! filled with tons of tourist and amazing churches dating from early incas! this place is one location to check out and hang out! from its cobble stone streets to its very nice small shops and with tons of restaurants to dine in surround this place! you can never go wrong with this place!! definitely a must see while visiting Cusco.

Tourist Trap!!!!!!!!!!. As soon as I stepped off the bus for Cusco, 5 cabbies screaming "taxi, taxi" in my face and grabbing at my luggage, I knew it was going to be "that kind of place". The plaza is NO exception. VERY aggressive vendors all over the place see you coming a mile away. You want tour? You want massage? You want this thing I knitted? You want to take pictures with my baby goat wearing a hat? You want fake alpaca? You want to eat at my super expensive restaurant? ALL THE RESTAURANTS are priced the same as NYC! Dont even think about trying to order Cuy(Guinea Pig). Its cheap and a regular in cusco, like a hamburger is in the US, but they will hit you hard! Avoid the square whenever possible!

Main Square in town with something always going on!. The main square is the focal point of Cusco. There is so much going on here- parades, jugglers, great people watching, etc. As well as the big Cathedral, and a smaller but equally impressive Church. Plenty of restaurants and shopping as well. Our hotel was around the corner, so it was easy for us to get to the square and participate/observe all the activity that was going on. Don't overlook this!
Amazing!. Beautiful place! amazing history and culture! Everywhere you look is just a piece of a history that will be always there! Im in love with Cusco! Hope to came back one day...
amazing!. Fantastic spot to have a meal and look out over the grand courtyard, taking in the local history and artwork.

Everything is here. Everything you wnat to do is in the plaza. Filled with restaurants, bars, nighclubs, some museums. And the well known McDonalds, KFC and Starbucks :) Has a beautiful fountain right in the middle and surrounded with surreal cathedrals :)

Great square to wander around in.. We enjoyed going back to this square several times during the 3 days we were in Cusco. Restaurants line the square, as well as Cathedrals, nice stores, souvenir shops and offices.

Beautiful. A beautiful square with well-kept gardens and gorgeous fountain. Do visit it at night, and try any of the restaurants. Very safe to walk around at night. Just learn to say "No gracias" to all the vendors trying to sell you paintings, tshirts and finger puppets!!
Beautiful Plaza. Just really pretty buildings has a nearby monastery not to be missed! Cute cafe/bar across from the Governor's palace.

Very nice historical area. The Plaza is surrounded by old churches and a nice park in the middle. There are shops and tourist information everywhere. You should venture off the main square and it seems each side road has its own uniquness. It was not hard to find other interesting squares and people. Do expect to get accosted by all sorts of vendors or trinket sellers in the Plaza and side streets. If ytou politely say no thank you they do leave you alone. We were also there in the early evening and felt safe.

Place where you can spend hours.. This is the place where you can just spend hours doing people watching. It is a happening place, where something or the other is happening. We were there for 3 days, one day we had town parade, other day Corpus Christi parade. Locals seem to come down and enjoy a good stroll on Sunday afternoon and on top you have shoe shine kids, hawkers asking you buy something. Lots of restaurant around but all are touristy and pricey. You can find more authentic and cheaper food in some tucked away roads away from plaza aramas.

Great place to people watch. The plaza is buzzing with life, with tourists snapping away and locals meeting, it's a hive of activity.The two Cathedrals are worth visiting but just sitting on one of the benches and taking in the activity around you is a nice way to spend a few minutes. There are colourful locals dressed in traditional garments, whilst they do ask for $$ to take a picture with them. There are a number of restaurants and cafes that also line the plaza, from cheap and cheerful to the more fine dining options.I would recommend coming back in the evening as well to see the Plaza lit up, we were lucky to see a fireworks display in front of the Cathedral on one of the nights we were there.

Nice to see!. I had the opportunity to be there during a religious ceremony with procession and it was wonderful. And even during a normal day this place is really nice and it would be perfect if you don't have street vendors and "shoe shiners" harassing you every minute (impossible to be quiet, they are many and always trying to sell you something).

Nice place. Quite a few decent restaurants in the area, the Cathedral and square are lovely to look at, my favourite time to visit was in the evening when the hills were lit up with their yellow and blue lights, beautiful.Note to first timers: not everyone is an art student trying to sell his/her art and not all of the massage parlours are legit so be careful and say "no thank you" and keep walking, unless you're into that sort of thing.I travelled alone and had no real problems, only being accosted a few times by people trying to sell me things, generally nice people though. You cannot say you've visited Cuzco without seeing plaza de Armas

In a different world. Sit in the square, watch the locals go by or hit one of the restaurants or coffee shops around the square. Our favorite place..Bambos...out of this world burgers! or hit a juice bar..hmmm yummy
Great place to people watch. The center of the tourists area. Lots of restaurants, banks, shops. Often there are parades, bands etc.
Cusco Highlights. The plaza offers many photo opportunities of the cathedral and surrounding buildings. The area has several good restaurants and is a must for sightseeing in Cusco.

Must See in Cusco. I love plazas in South/Latin American countries, and this one was no exception. With the cathedral, church, fountain, and controversial Inca statue, I found it charming and very interesting. Of course there are vendors that will approach you, but they are not numerous or aggressive and a polite "no gracias" is all it takes.

Huacaypata - Plaza de llanto - The place to cry..... There is a good reason why is called Huacaypata the main plaza of Cusco. By the way, this is the only place that the Spaniards couldn't destroy. The perimeter of it is exactly as it was in the time of the Inkas. So when you step on it think how many of the Inka feet walked around where you do... This plaza was very important. It's call the Huacaypata - Huacay=Crying - Pata=Plaza. Here is where the Inkas brought in shame whom ever rebelled or didn't comply with their laws. Their laws were quite simple but very strict. Ama sua=Don't steal, Ama llulla = Don't lie - Ama llulla=Don't be lazy, Ama llenka=Don't kill. Revere the Sun as the only God, respect mother nature, be good to all. Reciprocity was the bases for their way of governing as much it's still a way of life in the high lands of Peru in the Andes. Here in this plaza the Inkas also brought after their battles the leaders of conquered lands for all the people to see, some of them were kill in front of the Wacas (deities) some whom were affiliated to the Empire were honored and giving feasts. On this same plaza thousands of the Inka people died defending their land, their Sacred City Cusco from the invaders. Here was executed the last hope of freedom Tupac Amaru on which four horses stretched his body to death, with his last breath shouted... Hayk’aqpas yuyayniyku saruchasqa karanchu!! Our minds will never surrender!! Here in the Plaza of Huacypata now a days Cusco celebrates all it's traditional costumes, modern and old. What goes in Cusco on this plaza has a double meaning. Nothing done in Cusco is what you see. It always have a deep inner explanation. Here Meztizos, criollos as much as the aboriginals direct descents of the Inkas hold hands to reminiscent their glorious past.Here on the Huacaypta were shed tears of blood of joy, defeat and desperation. From my point of view, this plaza holds the spirit of the Inkas.

Classic!. This is, of course, the central plaza in Cusco. Boasting two cathedrals and a lovely central park with beautiful flowers, it is the essence of this fascinating city. You will find yourself returning time after time. It also has some great restaurants. We really enjoyed the Baghdad Restaurant (interesting name for a place that serves traditional Peruvian food). This is where I enjoyed a delicious and reasonably priced Cuy (guinea pig), perhaps THE national dish. Delicious!

a great place to walk, dine out, people-watch, and shop. Our hotel was about a block from this plaza. We enjoyed seeing the cathedral on the plaza (including touring the interior - really interesting artwork), eat in a couple of restaurants that faced the plaza, and shopped a little. The fountain was also a nice focal point. On our first evening, there was a parade of various bands dressed in traditional costume. (I am not sure what the celebration was, but it was fun to watch.)The restaurants we tried at the plaza were the Inka Grill (good sandwich spot) and Limo (great for drinks, appetizers, and dinner). Limo was upstairs and has a nice view of the plaza. For shopping, the stores here are a bit expensive as they are in the tourist area. However, the 3 ladies in our group all bought alpaca scarves at Kuna. For those who want to buy Pisco to take back home, the airport was cheaper than the stores near the tourist areas.

This is a must see if you have limited time in Cusco.. The Square is beautiful. There are two old, majestic cathedrals. Lots of people gather in the park in the center which has a fountain and lovely flowers. There are multiple restaurants, stores and a Peru Rail office here. I wanted to shop for some nicer baby alpaca sweaters and this area seems to have the best selection. Do shop around and compare prices as I found the wool cape I wanted for 400 soles (monetary unit of Peru) and previous stores had wanted500 soles for it. Quality sterling silver items may also be found here. There is also a small alley where the vendors sit in open stalls and you can deal for best prices on local items. This area is very scenic for photos. There are many women dressed in traditional costumes and holding baby goats for you to take their photo then offer a monetary donation. Most tell you that you decide how much to offer. It can get very crowded here. There are a number of locals who will approach you to buy little junk stuff they are selling out of their back pack and they can be persistent.

The Centre of Cuzco. This is a Must Do attraction on visiting Cusco. It is the centre of the city and the location of the Cathedral.
It is interesting just to stop and watch the hurly-burly of this city. The mountains make an amazing backdrop.

A most attractive square. We thought the Plaza de Armas was a very attractive square with the fountain in the middle and surrounded by the cathedral, churches and colonial buildings. Whilst we were there we enjoyed a wonderful street parade with colourful costumes and music against this backdrop.Yes, there are a lot of vendors which can be a bit annoying but when we said no, we were not pestered and we felt rather sorry for them trying to make a little money and getting so many refusals. It was a good place to just sit on a step and take it all in. There are some restaurants around and we had lunch in the Irish pub looking out over the square.

Must-see in Cusco. You can't visit Cusco without going to see the Plaza de Armas. It's beautiful both during the day and at night. The restaurants immediately surrounding it are a little pricier than others in the city but there are plenty of cheaper, equally tasty places on the side-streets
Fun center. The Plaza is a great gathering place. Lots of activity, wonderful people. Eat at the Inka Grill. Food, atmosphere and entertainment are great.

Nice area. It was very picturesque and although there were many people trying to sell things to you, nobody was overly aggressive. This was the center of activity with lots of restaurants looking out on it.

Bustling!. There is so much to see and do in this square, shops, restaurants, local trinket sellers, and of course the wonderful architecture, sit here and watch the world go by while listening to the hubub of the town, all with beautiful fountains, you feel safe, alive, and part of something special.

Carnival. On the time I visited Cusco there was some kind of carnival going on. Plaza de Armas was full of young people celebrating and throwing artifical snow on each other (espacially on beautifull girls). Plaza itself is quite nice place to watch people and there are many good restaurants.

Great area with alot to do, but alot of vendors. This was one of my fave spots in Cusco. You are right in the heart of alot of action. There are plenty of restaurants, shopping, tour vendors and well as two beautiful churches.The plaza is enjoyed by both locals and tourist. It was nice to sit and just people watch.There is a police presence in the area. It was also easy to catch a taxi if need so.The only issue is the number of vendors, esp in the daytime. It gets tiresome with people asking do you want to buy this or that. Understand since there are a large number of tourist are in the plaza and the opportunity to make money is possible, don't ask the same person five minutes later if they want to buy something!
I visit it almost every day.. There will always be people at the Plaza, friendly people who are willing to practice your Spanish and to talk to. I love to see the sunset at the Plaza as well.

Its pretty. Its really pretty during daytime aswell as night. Def. worth going there at least one of booth.a good place to just sit down for a bit and just taking it all in and watching some ppl pass by.

Beautiful. The plaza is gorgeous, and safe at almost all hours of the night (cameras and police at night for the clubbers/bar hoppers). During the day, colonial and Incan architecture make it enchanting. I took off some points for the only downside....the "jaladores", who stand outside each store and restaurant to convince you to enter, and the roving sellers. Unfortunately the selling for massages, restaurants, souvenirs, and tours is very aggressive, you shouldn't engage it only encourages them!
Amazing!. Worth a visit! There is usually a lot going on in the Plaza including parades, dances, etc. and it is in a great location right in the middle of Cuzco

Beautiful area to take pictures. Whether it was a bright sunny day, or night time, this was a favorite area for my husband and I to photograph! Its pretty photogenic. At night, take a stroll (its pretty safe) and all of cusco lights up like a christmas tree, its so pretty! Its a pretty clean plaza, and if you are lucky you might catch a cultural procession/organized march, and get a good view of it from the Starbucks up high, or witness it with the locals down below. We saw it on a sunday before we left. Love the cathedrals and fountains.

Fun place to visit and stroll.. This is a lively place to be in Cusco! It was quite busy on a Saturday night with lots of people, busy restaurants and weddings at the several churches on the plaza. We felt safe, noticing plenty of police patrolling. On Sunday morning, there was a big parade going around the plaza. It seemed to be from the university, but there were also costumed dancers and musicians. A nice surprise! We were told that parades are common. The architecture is lovely. Be sure to visit the churches.
To rest after an exciting day in Machu Picchu. A good place to catch up with friends after returning from Machu Picchu.Just to spend some time enjoying fresh air.

Nice Plaza. A nice plaza in the centre of Cusco. From here you will be able to find most things you are looking for. However, the large number of offers tourist received while walking along the square is somewhat annoying. The plaza itself is not the most beautiful in Peru or the region, but has a historic buildings and churches surrounding it.
It's the happening place in Cusco.. Lots of parades and festivities every month, restaurants, shops, and within walking distance of most places you would want to visit in the city.

Great place to people and building watch. Lovely historic buildings, loads of interesting people and a great selection of restaurants. The area is safe thanks to a high police presence and the streets are constantly cleaned.
Unesco Heritage Site. Spectacular with lots of churches and cathedrals and the Avenue of the Sun running parallel. Lots of restaurants and shops now vye for tourist dollars there.
Great place to people watch. We whiled away a couple spare hours just sitting in the the Plaza watching people coming and going. There is a starbucks close to get your coffee fix.

internation ambassadors. We enjoyed our daily visits in the plaza meeting people from all over the world enjoying their visit to cusco. The people everywhere were friendly. The only negative are the street vendors trying to make a living and you just have to continuously say "no" to tem which is difficult. There is a Starbuck's for that good old American coffee.

One of the best plazas in SA. I have attended one of the biggest parades today around the plaza de armas in cuzco. What a beautiful place to have such an event. I hope my photos due the place justice. Cuzco is my fave city in SA so far.

Lovely Atmosphere. We were there on the day of the Señor de los Temores festival. It lasted several hours an proved to be quite an interesting experience. We were approached by many street vendors and bought a few items there. You do have to be careful not to get ripped off. What they claim is original art is not, because the same art is sold down the street by others. Other than that we didn't notice any dishonesty going on. Again, it's a real nice place to spend a few hours and just to look at people passing by.
Gorgeous plaza in the middle of Cusco. Lovely shops and restaurants surround this plaza. The flowers were beautiful. It's lovely just to stroll around looking at your surroundings.

So Pretty!. The plaza justs adds to the beauty of it's surroundings. What is not to like about this place?! The fountain is great, especially in the morning sunlight. Worth a stop when visiting the cathedral.

One of the best in South America!. A fine combination of old buildings, cathedrals, basilicas, set in a opent square with lush vegetation and restaurants with old balconies. Cusco at its best! Once you been there there will be always the want to go back. I loved it!

Very nice square. Interesting architecture and conjunction of colours. Near the Plaza there are many museums to visit and also many restaurants where you can eat and rest before continuing your walk. However, be aware that many peruvians will try to sell you all sorts of things and they will be very persistent at times.

Very touristy. A very picturesque and well maintained square, lots of shopping, eateries. Lots of peddlers but they do not bother you. Took a tour of Cuzco from on double decker bus. Would like to go there again sometime.

Good starting point. Seems like this is the place to start any tour in Cusco. Cabs definately know how to get here. Get ready for street peddlers to approach you but just say "no gracias" and they usually leave you alone. Cabs leaving the plaza, especially after dark or raining, cost more (sometimes double) than arriving. There are plenty of shops and restaurants surrounding along with narrow cobblestone streets. Excellent views

Those Inca knew what they were doing.. The forefathers were right, there is something mystical about the way sunlight hits in the square. 'Went to Sunday Mass at the Cathedral. Some cafes, lots of browsing. Always felt like there was action just around the corner. Actually the side streets were better for finding some shade from the high-altitude sun. Once, coming around a corner near the square, about two dozen uniformed, shielded officers came marching in a line ahead of me -- it was a demonstration! Actually, it was very peaceful and not the dangerous thing I might have imagined, they were asking for high pay for educators, and they weren't getting too out of hand, because it was a school presentations in the square with kids in uniforms and band music. Demonstration doesn't mean riot. There are lots of street sellers, but a person selling their own art is completely different from selling plastic things made in another country, really.

In the heart of Cusco. I was several time in Cusco and really like the athomosphere at the main place in Cusco. It's a brilliant place for just being and observing the things going on around. But be prepared for all the sellers!!

pretty and picturesque!. as expected, this lovely spot is where everyone - locals and tourists alike - spend their time. There are plenty of little restaurants and cafes overlooking the square. I went to Cappuccino Cafe as well as the BBQ joint and had a nice time.

A must. You have to come through here on your way to everywhere. Check out the Cathedral and the Jesuit Church and absorb the atmosphere. Just don't stand still for too long or you'll get pestered by endless art and trinket sellers.Try to avoid eating here or staying here - the square is noisy at all hours, the food and drink is mostly overpriced compared to other parts of the city, and the vendors and peddlers will not give you a moment's rest.

pleasant time. me and my friends had a great time here, we found an excellent terrace restaurant (los balcones), we admired the interesting buildings and we photographed a lot of nice scenes of the buildings with amazing mountain backgrounds. don't give in to the very persistent street vendors :)

Great center to an even better network of side streets.. Explore, and make your way up and through the San Blas streets. You'll get bombarded with street vendors everywhere (kindly expect that in an impoverished region), and simply say "no gracias".
Great for photos.. Very pretty great for photos but a real tourist trap.Be careful with the street sellers,bthey are very insistent.

People Watch. Great place to people watch and relax after walking around the old historic center for a bit. It feels like you are right in the middle of the city, especially when you see all the mountains in the background of the city.
Wonderful. The place is awesome, full of tourists and people from the city relaxing, in addition to the great atmosphere with colonial buildings all around

Main square. Good place to take photos. The police is very nice to assist you. I remember best when I ask for the address of Starbuck and a police guides us to Punchay, a nice place to drink he best coffee at Cusco.

Beautiful. I love this square. It's my favourite place to sit and watch the world go by or read a book. There is plenty to see, many nice restaurants. Though if you're a backpacker head away from the square for affordable food. Beautiful churches. Lots of pretty balconies to grab a coffee and enjoy the view. One possible downside is the amount of street vendors. You will be offered lots of local produce to buy. I simply used it as a way to practice my Spanish.

Plaza surrounded by churches. The Plaza has a large fountain in the center that is a magnet for photographers of all types. It is surrounded by Churches. The Cathedral being one of them. We were treated to a band concert by the police band while there which added a nice plus.

The beautiful centre of Cusco. Little to say after that title. It is a lovely spot to wander round and take in the various buildings & balconies, plus views up to mountains, both day and night. It felt very safe at all times to us ( a middle-late aged couple). Lots of trees and flowers so it is like a park right in the middle of everything - great planning by the Incas and/or Spanish!

Picturesque square. Truly felt like I had stepped back in time while exploring this beautiful historic square. I especially loved the fountain in the centre made out of gold with swans and the beautiful churches surrounding the square. If you walk up towards the nearby inca museum, you can get a brilliant view and picture of the entire square with the rooftops. There are plenty of options for food, both western and local delicacies. The only thing I probably disliked was the people standing outside shops and restaurants trying to usher you inside.

Probably the best Plaza de Armas in Latin America. Cusco's Plaza de Armas is just about perfect. Churches on 2 sides, stores and excellent restaurants on the other two, lots of places to sit and just take it all in--this is a great place to relax either on a park bench, the cathedral steps, or 2nd floor restaurants that look out over the plaza.

Very tourist friendly. Where there is a story behind every rock, building and street. This amazing plaza gives you a feeling of going back in time. Completely safe place to take out your camera and snap pictures all around.Most of the locals in that area speak english and are waiting for you to bargain a good deal. Some local girls dressed ethnically randomly put a baby lamb in my arms for me to take a picture with it. All well and good if you are open to that kind of tourism.

Cool Plaza. Plaza de Armas is really cool. I always felt safe there even at night or early in the morning. There are plenty of tourist police around so you never feel in danger. The buildings around the plaza are beautiful. True, McDonalds, Starbucks and KFC have moved in in recent years but the municipality have made them adhere to strict restrictions on their signage and advertising. It's all very tasteful and subtle and makes the plaza more the better for it. It's great at night, sitting on one of the balconies over-looking the plaza with all the hills lit up and the Christo Redentor looking down over the valley.

Beautiful Square. One not to miss. The main square in Cusco and so so pretty.Old colonial buildings mixed with modern shops and restaurants. Everything in keeping with image of quality area. There is a Macdonalds and KFC but they are so discreet you could miss them.Good restaurants, great sites and churches.Very sake and fairly busy.Many touts but not too much hassle if you ploitely say no.
History and Culture. A wonderful main square in a delightful city, Plaza de Armas is a must on your journey. Many unique historical sites here along with wonderful restaurants and shops.

Lots of stuff to see and do. The Plaza de Armas in Cusco was beautiful. Lots of shops and restaurants. Of course we had to stop at Starbucks. We collect Starbucks City Mugs from cities we visit around the world and were excited to add Peru. The Lima city mug was a great mug to add to our collection. We also ate at McDonalds one day when we wanted a quick and easy lunch to share. It was typical and the food was fine. My son had pizza, which he really enjoyed, but I can’t remember the name of the restaurant. It was one of the ones facing the square right in the plaza. We visited the Cathedral of Santo Domingo and the Church of La Compañia de Jesus. Both were beautiful and we learned a lot about the country and the people.

Lovely sight - not to be missed!. Still amazed by the peaceful feel of each plaza seen in Peru - and Cuzco sure offers that feeling. Manicured lawn, lovely fowers/ trees arrangments.The plaza is surrounded by old buildings with balconies - wood and stone - and galleries covering shops and restaus (ideal for rainy weather!!!).Finally amazing churches and museum of inka to be visited.Highly recimmended.

Good food and bars!. This is the main area so it will be the most expensive! Nice places for drinks and food. If you want to purchase activities like ATV rides and other stuff, I suggest you find a tour place down one of the alleys with all the hostels. Their prices are significantly cheaper than at the plaza. Same thing goes for shopping.Look out for the Fabric center, it's like a mall with very cheap prices. I can't remember the name, but it's WEST of the official place to buy train tickets to Machu Picchu
Nice people watching. Great space to sit around it and while away the day and people watch. Lots to do nearby. Restaurants are close also.

a great place to sit and relax.... the central plaza of Cusco offers beautifully manicured lawns and gardens as well as seasonal displays. Since we were there in December, there was a wonderful creche (Nativity scene).

the most beautiful in South America. Just beautiful. Full of people day and night and looking absolutely fantastic at night-one of the few that looks better at night with the shimmering lighting from the beautiful surrounding buildings

Nice Plaza, lots of people!. Great place. There're a lot of people trying to sell you tours, just keep moving... If you're searching for information to go to Machu Picchu or any of the other attractions you can always negotiate the price :)

New Year's Eve party. It was a different experience standing in the Plaza de Armas in Cusco on New Year's Eve. We specifically made plans to be there on this day, as we had heard how lively the celebration was. Everything was decorated in yellow (the good luck color), and the locals were not shy to share their joy at the new year!

Central City Plaza. Cathedral, plus another church, old buildings facing the square. The Plaza itself is beautiful, with statue and fountains. Cobblestone streets add to the atmosphere. Lots of people selling on the streets but it wasn't too invasive.
certainly the belly button. Great architecture here and lot's of restaurants and bars to choose from. Sorry can't remember any names.

The center of the action in Cuzco. Try not to buy from the first charmingly dressed woman or child that solicits you to purchase jewelry, alpaca, or other crafts, as you will see they are all selling the same stuff. If you can get past some of the hard sells, the Plaza in a fun place for people watching. We were there right around Christmas and, on the 24th, the Plaza was filled with Andinos who come from the outskirts of Cuzco to sell their wares and purchase other goods. It is a fascinating smorgasbord of cultures. The cathedral is definitely worth seeing and taking a tour.

central Cusco. Was in Plaza de Armas for Christmas 2012.All the locals fill the plaza selling plants and ferns, dried bromeliads, moss and twigs, to make the nativity scenes, the centerpiece of Christmas decoration.Stalls everywhere, wonderful colourful native dress. Plaza alight with festive lights and sounds. Fireworks at midnight Christmas Eve, laughter, children.I am in heaven.

New Year's Eve on Plaza de Armas. We returned from Machu Picchu to Cusco on New years Eve and headed directly to the Plaza de Armas. It was completely filled with crowds, drinking and dancing to the sounds of the local band. All kinds of liquor for sale, but the crowd behaved well. At midnight, people began running"in formation" around the square - we found out that was for good luck in the new year. We made our way to our hotel about one am, but the crowds hadn't diminished.We returned several times over the next few days, the plaza is just a wonderful place to "people watch", shop or relax and read if the weather permits. Truly the heart of wonderful Cusco.
The heart of Cusco. Plaza de Armas has everything a tourist need, form a few banks and ATMs, to great shops, bars and restaurants and a lot of travel agencies.

Nice Plaza. Either at night or day is where the action happens in cusco. To my surprise there are a lot of bar and lounges to drink and dance. I had a really fun night in Mythology Lounge right in the plaza

Rest Or Riot. A central place that is always buzzing day and night. Surrounded by many beautiful Spanish style architecture. A place to either meld into the constant activity, or simply sit back and enjoy the activities of others.

Lovely town center. We were so surprised when we arrived at this site. The fountain in the center was fabulous. It attracted families and children. Around the fountain was green grass and other historical buildings and churches. We felt safe and really enjoyed walking in the area.

Festive Sunday morning parade. WE enjoyed the Sunday morning parade. There were many people dressed in a variety of costumes. It was very festive. It gave a sense of the past and present culture of peruvians.

Good place to meet other backpackers. Kind of touristy, but the plaza offers a great view and there are loads of backpackers all over, so its a great place to meet new folks or rendezvous with someone
Great Place. Great spot to go visit. Since it was my first time traveling, I met lots of ppl at the plaza. At night, it was wonderful.

Always something happening there!. Very close to the hotel. A very colorful Plaza, the gardens are magnificent. Every Sunday they have a parade which is very interesting. School children, graduates, army personnel and dancers in national costume parade around the Plaza. A must to see!

Parades, Flag Raising and Speeches Were the Order of the Day.. We were told to walk to Plaza Armas to see the procession becuase it was Sunday. Instead,we saw the parade, ceremonies, lots of people in uniform and many restaurants. Later that afternoon, after the guide picked us up at the hotel for our tour, we found out that our city tour was to start there.We had dinner there that night. There were lots of people there day and night. I felt safe walking there. Plaza de Armas was the hub of the city.

Beautiful square at the center of Cusco. Spend a few hours sipping a cappaccino on the balcony of one of the many cafes that line the square while you watch the sun set. Quite beautiful, and great people watching.

Only a peaceful place. We enjoy this main square is so beautiful with all kind of colonial houses and cathedrals around
me and my family spent time there drinking hot chocolate and enjoyning our vacation in cusco peru
Peddlers everywhere. Around Every corner people will try to sell you something. but it is beautiful and lots of restuarants to choose from.
Interesting area. Pretty grounds and historical surroundings, lots of surrounding shops and restaurants, street vendors, and Sunday morning parade.

Nice Place to sit if you can.. It's a great place to sit. But be ready to be bombarded with kids older ladies trying to sell stuff. and once you start to look you get ingulfed with sellers. we had to leave and come back later. don't even look @ their stuff if you don't want to be chase out of the Plaza.

Beautiful during the morning and magical at nightime.. The weather in November was fantastic, around 72 during November, said that we enjoy our strolls in the Plaza de Armas, we spend a couple of hours there visiting the churches and stores around it and more than anything enjoying the view. Really nice place to visit.

Cusco Plaza. We visited this plaza many times during our visit as it was only a block from our hotel. The churches tower over the plaza, and are very impressive. There are many restaurants to try that overlook the plaza, and the view of the surrounding villages is very nice as well.

One of my favorite places... ever. I live in Cusco and cannot say enough nice things about the Plaza de Armas! I try to get there at least 3 or 4 times a week, if for nothing else than to sit for a few minutes in the sun and soak it all in. The church and cathedral are amazing, there is always a mix of locals and tourist milling around, and there are plenty of places to eat/drink located nearby. I could not recommend it more highly.
Plaza de Armas. Very pretty square. The church is beautiful and there are lots of benches to sit around. The area is surrounded by currency conversion places and restaurants where you get good food.
Churches are pretty. The main square isn't too impressive, but the churches are really nice. There are lots of benches and a neat fountain in the middle.
Beautiful square in a charming city. Loved this square - day time, night time, its delightful. The buildings that surround it are quite spectacular architecture.

best square in peru?. I really liked this square, its large but not too big with greenery and the inca statue in the middle. Its quite spacious with wide roads and old churches plus colonial architecture. Plus you can the high mountains in the background surrounding it, see at different times of the day.
Plaza De Armas. Every Latin American city has a plaza de armas. As they go, this one was nice and had an amazingly beautiful church that could be toured for a minimal fee.

A must if you go hiking. This is probably the only place in Peru to shop for tourist gear like gas or trekking poles. You have to shop around though, as prices vary significantly from place to place. I was looking for trekking poles, one place had em for 120 us, after two minutes walk i found them for 10 bucks.
The hub of the town. Cusco is a city alive with history and modern day commerce and tourism. A great mix of Spanish and Traditional architecture. The food and accommodation on offer is astounding.

rest amongst the flowers. The plaza is always nicely presented and it's a good place to rest for awhile. Beggars and people selling things do come along frequently but are moved on by local police who are constantly there keeping an eye on things.

Peace and Quit. I have traveled to Cusco many times, yet I never tire of the peace and quiet of the Plaza, Early morning and late at night are my favorite times to sit and watch the crowds walk by. Smoking a good cigar and drinking a cup of strong andean coffee, the Plaza is a perfect place to absorb the past and enjoy the present. Time flies by so quickly and boredom is never an issue.
Full of life town center. This place is full of people at night, shows on the street, people from everywhere enjoying the night. Great vibe!
Constant Harassment. The plaza itself is great and very well kept, but you cannot stop walking. If you do you will be hounded by 100's of sellers selling everything from fingure puppets to drugs.
great place to people watch. You cant miss it. We enjoyed just sitting outside and people watching the first day as our bodies adjusted to the altitude.

One of the Finest Plazas. It was surprising to come upon this place for the first time with two majestic Cathedrals bookending the square. It was immaculate, clean and a joy to walk through after a lazy dinner off the square. Unfortunately hidden under the porticos you will find not only great restaurants (Inkagrill for one) but also KFC and mickeydees which are to their credit low key. We were fortunate to be there on a large celebration and parade with grandstand and all the trappings and dignitaries.

Pretty plaza but too many vendors. This plaza is pretty, surrounded by charming arcades and beautiful churches. Nice benches to sit on and relax. The cathedral is definitely worth exploring, though if I recall correctly you had to pay an entrance fee. I suppose if you came during mass, you wouldn't have to pay. Someone recommended to use that we come during the Quechua mass every Sunday. The plaza and other public places in Peru were kept very clean. My main objection is the aggressive street vendors. While they are not as persistent as in Mexico, they are still annoying and really dampened my enthusiasm for spending any time at all in this plaza.

Wonderful Place to Relax and Enjoy the Moment. The Plaza de Armas is probably best described as the main section in Cusco. You´ve got a town square that includes shops, a Cathedral, a museum, plenty of restuarants and - most importantly - a Starbucks haha. There is park in the middle with a fountain.The culture is so evident here. Everyone is so friendly. So many things to do that my advice would be to not try to rush anything. Just relax and take an entire afternoon (or longer) to soak it all in. My wife and i spent like an hour at the Starbucks (which is located on the second floor of one of the buildings and has a fantastic balcony which overlooks the Plaza) just people watching and relaxing.Literally my only complaint is the constant onslaught of vendors trying to sell you something or other, but what are you going to do? Everyone has to make a living.
Can't avoid it. It's beautiful, carefully maintained, but very touristy. Great place to sit and chill, especially if the sun is out.

Surprisingly beautiful town center with surprisingly upscale shops and restaurants. My research into Peru prior to our journey led me to believe that it wasn't a fantastic country, but that there were fantastic things to see inside the country. Without expectations of any kind, much less high ones, we were pleasantly surprised not only by the friendliness of the people but by the stunning beauty of the country. The Plaza was an example of that. The shops and restaurants surrounding it are of a tourist quality that would be acceptable in any developed country, and the square itself, with beautiful landscaping, stunning architecture and the Andes Mountain backdrop, proved to be beautiful by nearly any standard. We were surprised and pleased by almost all aspects of the city of Cusco in general and the Plaza de Armas in particular.

Not much to see here. A little dingy during the day and mostly aggressive street vendors and massage offers at night. the main church was nice inside, but you cant buy a ticket to just see the church, they sell you admission to 3 other places as part of a package whether you want it or not. a real turnoff. nothing to see in the plaza other than to snap a couple photos in front of the basicilla.

Nice. It was a lovely place though there were MANY tourists around. The view was amazing under a grey sky. When you get to the city centre it feels like traveling back in time. There are many restaurants and shops around. It's a must in Cusco Citry

Nice place to hang out. A nice place to relax in between cathedral and museum visits, but you will be approached to buy a card or give a handout. Small kids are helping their families, older are professionals...

Awesome City Center. This City Center is beautiful and bustling with people that are interesting to watch. It is a great and obvious place to meet up with friends, and there are many fabulous restaurants, bars, and shops on the side streets that feed into it.

another inca ruin. I love the inca ruins and this is another one to tick off the list.They are well maintained and offer you an insight into the amazing strength that the culture has at creating great structures.

Real Life.. I spent many happy hours wandering up and down the streets of Cusco, visiting the little markets off the back streets, dropping into bars for very reasonably-priced food and drink, and chatting with the locals, who I found to be friendly, polite, curious and not too pushy when I explained I didn't need yet another decorated gourd.

What a sunny place to sit back and people watch!. And in the middle of some charming architecture too! I loved sitting on the steps of the Cathedral to watch the world walk by - because in Cusco, the world will walk by you. I had a chance to watch a really funny procession go by in front of the Cathedral - a tribute to one of the versions of the Virgin Mary - played by carnival constumed players playing drunks!!! It was so funny!

Charming city center. During our visit to Cusco, my husband and I would often wander down to the Plaza de Armas to sit and people watch. It's a lovely plaza and really the historic city center, so everything (attractions, hotels, restaurants) is nearby. Charming layout and architecture.

This is how a plaza de armas should be!. The big square with some classic settings with its several churces, museums, restaurants, cafes and bars. Nice fountains and flowers with enough places to sit and enjoy everyday life in Cusco!

nice square in which to sit, relax and soak up atmoshphere. This is the main square in Cusco from which all of the City's main attractions are within walking distance. From here the Spanish influence can be clearly seen . It appears to be a popular meeting place. The ever presence of tourist police ensure it is a safe place to linger . From here you can pick up an open topped bus tour of the City andthe overlooking inca site of Sacsayhuaman.

Magical!. Each time I visit Cusco I love walking around the Plaza de Armas. I can't seem to get enough of it. It has so much energy! I love admiring the architecture and the authenticity of the city. There is something about it that makes me feel happy! There is so much history around and I love running into the locals dressed in their native clothes and carrying around baby alpacas or lambs. There is so much going on all the time. People walking around, little bars and restaurants! I love it!
Center of the city. Nice plaza, clean and full of flowers. Lots of locals walking around, some in their native customs. Good area to change money.
Clear Spanish inluence. A clear mix of the Inca and Spanish culture. The center of Cusco with its beautiful Cathedral and plenty of good restaurants and shops

Wonderful Place to Visist. The Plaza is a great part to see the heart of the city! There are shops and restaurants and churches and people. Avoid being overcharged and go shop at the other market down the street- you will be happy you did!
The cobblestone Main Square. Love the feel of this square its cobblestone, the old cathedrals and the sourounding mountains are just beautiful.
Great place!. There are many activities in this plaza. Also, there are many good restaurants surrounding the Plaza. The view to the Andes in the background is amazing!
A magic place. Plaza de Armas is one of the best places to be if you are in Cusco. Sit down there to enjoy the magical environment of the belly-button of the world, Cusco.
Shops and Restaurants. Nice restaurants, bars and good quality shops to invest your money. Also the area is very safe to wonder around.
Friendly, high energy and clean. Great views from any of the balconies around the square.Lots of tourista staff and good shoe shines!
Good place to begin. Good starting point. The cathedral was pretty. You are hit up constantly with vendors trying to sell you stuff, so just sitting in the square to relax is close to impossible

Great place to enjoy the sun and ice cream. Plaza de Armas, central place to move around from there. Great place to meet people from around the world, enjoy the sun and ice cream. Be careful and also have pacience with the street vendors (usually children), I think is getting better though; but they will run you crazy at times. Just say "NO" :)

Can't miss it. The Plaza is the center of town, and there's so much happening in and around it. Especially on weekends, it gets hopping, in a very laid back way. But it's tourist central, with lots of photo ops with llamas, lambs, lovely local folks in their finery. Lots of opportunities to buy stuff. But once you've done it, you're probably done with it.

Inca Capital. Center of the Inca world. Need I say more? Yes. Spansh rebuilt their city on old Inca capital and its buildings are well integrated with each other, forming a unique architecture in the world.

A lovely town square. A lovely cathedral is the focal point, with a few good bars and restaurants mainly in each corner. The well maintained gardens have a fountain in the middle and plenty of benches to sit, rest and watch the world go by. Shoe polishers can be a nuisance though

Beautiful (but tout central). Stunning colonial architecture and a range of cafes and bars to enjoy it from. Sadly not many of them are particularly good, but you can't argue with the view on a sunny day. Just a shame you can't walk more than 10m at a time without being accosted with a menu / sourvenir / guided tour / etc.

Lovely Square. Police everyhere trying to stop the pickpockets
We only heard of one event the whole time we were there
Go on a Sunday.... The whole town is out for the Parade Day -- so much fun! Crowded but a chance to see a "slice of life" in Cuzco.

Lovely!. What a beautiful plaza! Try and visit on Saturday when you are sure to catch multiple weddings and Peruan children adorned in costume. Try the tamales the woman is selling under the archway. Delicious!

The focal point of our wanderings. As we shopped and dined the Plaza was the focal point of our Cusco adventures. Once we learned how to get here from the hotel we radiated out from there to all the other locations we wanted to see but always ended up back in the Plaza

Tourist attraction, but don't shop here. Gorgeous plaza. Very Spanish in a way. Reminded me a lot of Quito. The food and the shopping suck because of tourists. Don't eat or shop here. The only place worth visiting is Starbucks Coffee. Most of coffee in Peru sucked. Although they import a ton of it to the world.

Nice place to relax. This is a beautiful plaza with Cathedrals nad churches. Nice restaurants and cafes near by. Excellent place to sit, relax and watch life in Cusco. One of the nice plaza we saw in Peru.

Love it... I never got bored of coming to the Plaza, a beautiful place with the Cathedral and fountain etc, plenty of benches to just sit and watch the world go by. Lots of shops and restaurants and places to book tours. The Plaza is also surrounded by many side streets offering yet more places to eat and drink and many markets selling lots of goodies. I can't wait to go back

a plaza pretty nice. a beautiful plaza with the cathedral and churches all over. One big problem thou, too many people stopping you all the time to sell some things, get you into their restaurant, give you a massage...

One of the best main squares in the world. This really is one of the classic Plaza de Armas in Peru, where every town has it´s own Plaza de Armas. The arches around the main square, the two churches and the sheer activity going on make it a great place to sit and watch. I am not a big fan at all of the Inka statue that they have put on top of the fountain, indeed people were trying to take the mayor to court over it, and I also think it is a real shame that they have let a couple of fast food chains onto the square but that is life. However it is a great place to sit and while away a bit of time, especially at sundown.
Great place to sit and watch. very pretty town center. Surrounded by shops and restaurants. Lots of dogs running around and artists selling their work. We loved just sitting there and people watching
Really nice. Go to Cusco around the 20-22th of June - the yearly party and celebration in town. All the cities around Cusco as well - it is an amazing experience.
Amazing plaza in central Cusco. Beautiful central plaza. However, the restaurants and shops tend to be a bit more expensive than ones outside the plaza. Still a great place to visit.

Worth visiting. This is the heart historic Cusco, and worth a visit and stroll around. Every Sunday there is a civic celebration involving parades with school kids, military, and city officials. There is usually some tradtitional dancing, too.Drawback is the focus of people looking to sell you something or charge money for a photo. It was distracting and took away from our enjoyment of the beautiful square.
can't avoid this. some cities still have centers that have not been overwhelmed by tourists. Still, Starbuck, McDonalds and Kentuck Fried Chicken are there - so, go before the Gap shows up!
Go there on Sunday to see all the marching!!. A very beautiful big plaza in thecent of Cusco.be sure to go on Sunday around late morning to see everyone marching. Why? because they can!

So much fun... Always some sort of festivity going on, whcih makes the city very colorful.. I loved it all.The street vendors could get a bit annoying but that part of the whole experince... They are adorable, specially the kids!!

Star from here for. This is the center of Cusco. Many shops and restaurants are around this area. Big Cathedral is one of the main spots in Cusco.Stroll around small streets from this square. These narrow path gives you a great Cusco feelings.

a must in Lima. Miraflores and Barranco are the most beautiful parts in Lima. If you have time to spare or want to visit the other important parts of the city, you must go Plaza de Armas.It's beatiful but it's nothing amazing really (such other spots of the city).It's your entry part for an afternoon or morning visiting historical sites located around it.
cool to hangout and meet people... it has everything you need in the square! churches, lion dance, people fainting, Starbucks and cheap massages!!

An enjoyable plaza. I really enjoy the Plaza de Armas when I go to visit Cuso! You can go there really at any time of the day and there will be something to different to see. It is also central to many different museums, restaurants, and hotels. It sometimes can feel overwhelming with all that is trying to be sold there but that is part of the experience.
good gathering place. but, not the relaxing place it used to be. visitors are hounded by peddlers selling handicrafts and kids wanting to shine your shoes.

plaza de "grass". lovely square nicknamed plaza de grass by locals due to the large amount of dope peddlars .anything can be bought hear however beware as police presence is heavy and a favorite trick is to sell to you then report you so beware

Cusco Center. Central location with lots happening. Dont feed the dogs you'll never get rid of them. StarBucks is near by! At night it is a great place to people watch but be prepared for lots of vendors to approach you to buy stuff
chill out. Don't miss a coffee or tea-time in one of the many bars and restaurants around the Plaza, where you can enjoy the view from a balcony

Center of a Great City!. Cusco in itself is a unique city with a combined culture of the Inca and Spanish. The Plaza de Armas is a great place to visit if you're in Cusco, along with the cathedrals and restaurants located in it.

Always with a festival. It seems that everyday there was a festival with costumed participants which are always fun to watch. Main hub of the city with traffic running in and out. Surrounded by shops, restaurants and churches. Note that McDonalds, Starbucks and KFC all have locations in the Plaza (too bad).

Delightful place to people watch!. I enjoyed each morning in the Plaza, watching Cuzco come to life. Similarly, by late afternoon almost every day, the Plaza came alive with a festival celebration, with native costumes. Shopping here is fine, but the people watching and dining is fabulous.

Charming!. This is the heart of cusco and his dominated by the cathedral...and restaurants (including a star buck) and shops. We loved strolling around here and had a beautiful view at night. It felt more like Europe with this big plaza. But is distinctly south American. Very busy traffic.
Great place to visit. During our stay in June we have seen parade after parade walking through the plaza during Cusconian Days!

If you've never been here (or to South America) before... read this!. If it's your first time visiting Plaza de Armas (or South America for that matter) here is some advice and suggestions based upon my experiences here. I spent 3 weeks in Cusco and spent time in Plaza de Armas nearly every day while there.Getting Around:Hustle and bustle as thousands of people are touring the area and the best way to get around is often to walk or take a taxi. I would not recommend taking a bus because they are extremely crowded (if you are tourist it's best not to give easy access to your wallet in your back pocket). Bring a good pair of tennis shoes because there are cobblestone roads and flip flops, heels, and sandals often end up causing you to trip or fall. Many of the roads include a good amount of elevation so you'll find it best to be comfortable. Taxis are plentiful, but use caution when taking them because there have been many cases of people dressing up their own cars and pretending to be taxi drivers to rob tourists. If you are staying at a hotel or dining at a restaurant, ask someone that works there to call a taxi for you. Taxi drivers will often "up" the cost when they see you are a tourist. You might want to ask them how much it will cost beforehand. I took a taxi at least 2 times each day & what I would do is not ask the taxi driver how much ahead of time. When I arrived at my destination I would quickly hand him a specific number of soles based upon how much I anticipated the ride being. This actually worked out best. Act like you are a frequent traveler there and that way they won't try to get an extra sole out of you. Speaking the Language:Most taxi drivers speak very little English so be sure to know some Spanish before you go. Shop owners speak a bit of English (as they are used to American and European tourists) but you'll get by just fine pointing at things on menus or in shops. Buying Items & Money:You will constantly be approached here to buy paintings, gloves, candy, sunglasses, etc. It can get rather annoying after awhile and sometimes it is heartbreaking because it's young children begging. Walk at a fast pace and when they try to stop you or walk next to you simply say "No, gracias"and keep going. If you stop walking, they'll surround you. I went with a large group of people and those that kept a fast pace were left alone while those that were trying to be polite and explain they weren't interested got the worst of it. If you typically use US Dollars as your currency, you'll be glad to see your money go further here. It's a developing country so you can expect that you'll spend less on this trip picking up souveniers. People are going to try to sell you "Baby Alpaca" items (gloves, scarves, hats) and none of them are real Baby Alpaca if you are just walking down the street. So be aware of that and that you also can almost always bargain down on any item from a vendor! An example of how far your money will take you:15 minute taxi ride for 2 people - 4 soles = $1.80Huge 60 ounce bottle of water - 2 soles = 90 centsBefore you Go: Stock up on waterless anti-bacterial hand sanitizer, kleenex, daily vitamins, and baby wipes. Almost all of the bathrooms you'll be using cannot be flushed with toilet paper in them (the plumbing isn't as advanced as other places) so you'll have to dispose of your toilet paper in a trash can located by the toilet. They do use Western style toilets, but you won't want to sit on them. You'll develop quite the strong leg muscles from squatting so often. There is often not soap to wash your hands or towels. I found that just using moist baby wipes when using the facilities and anti-bac hand sanitizer afterwards seemed to be the best bet. Take plenty of vitamins and kleenex with you. The level of sanitation leaves a lot to be desired. There are not laws for emissions on cars so there is black smog from exhaust and when you blow your nose the snot often comes out black (yuck...and hence the Kleenex)Cool Places at Plaza de Armas:I enjoy a pub/bar feel so I spent a good amount of time at the Cross Keys (1 block off of Plaza de Armas) and is a British style pub. Roomy, good food (menu in English), and lots of tourists from Europe/USA hanging out there watching futball ...or soccer as we like to call it in the US. There is also an Irish pub 1/2 a block down from that and it's nice but gets very crowded quickly.1. I never would have guessed! (things you probably didn't know):If you choose to get your photographs taken with the adorable little girls dressed in native outfits (and they are often walking small llamas or holding lambs) you must tip them! 1 sole per person. Don't stand a distance from them and take their picture either unless you plan on going over and tipping them afterwards. It is considered very rude not to tip them. They are quite poor and make their money off tourists.2. You could say it's "a dog's world" here because most dogs run freely around town. You'll see them everywhere and all of the time. I'm an animal lover myself, but I didn't pet any of them due to the danger of disease. Again, this is a poor area, so it's not like these dogs are being taken in to see vets on a regular basis. 3. Why yes, that is urine you smell! You just read there are dogs everywhere, right? Well, they've got to do their business just like everybody else so they pee on the streets and on the walls of establishments frequently. People (mainly men) will urinate in public as well.

Good sights and shops etc...lots of street sellers!. San Pedro market is worth a visit. Loved just sitting and watching the world go by! Found the Peruvian people very friendly and helpful. In my opinion you only need 3 days here.
Plaza de Armas. Loved to sit and people watch! Viewed the sunday morning band and flag raising and met interesting people from all over the world.
