“Safe and pictoresque”. Really enjoyed this part of Cusco. We stayed a block away and came here repeatedly. The Cathedral is spectacular, and the structures around the square are both historic, and well-preserved. Very discreetly, some of the buildings owned by the Catholic Church contain KFC, and McDonalds. The area is beautiful, and a pleasant place to sit and contemplate Peru's dramatic history.

Nice Place. The Plaza is a very historical place surrounded by very significant and historical buildings. I found it was a pleasant place to stop and rest on the benches with a snack, but be prepared to be constantly approached by vendors selling various items from jewellry to sun hats!
Beautiful plaza de armas. Beautiful area! The cathedrals are absolutely wonderful. Did not like that sat on a bench and was approached by many people wanting to sell things.

July2011. We've been to Cuzco their Independence day and we saw a large parade at the Plaza along VIP visitos and members of the Government and of course all the population of Cuzco. we saw many school children wearing their school uniform and soldiers. Amarching band was playing music. we liked it a lot. Plaza de Armas has anything you need,shops restaurants,etc.more expensive than other cities.(we found the best prices in Arequipa and going to Colca Canyon).Cuzco is a safe place to walk even at night.

Stay Near Here; Very cool area. We stayed at the Hotel Unumizo which was an excellent experience, but I would recommend getting a hotel very near the Plaza de Armas. This area stays open late with bars, shopping, and restaurant and our hotel was too far to walk, what I considered safely, at night. Make sure you go into La Catedral, it is worth the price. We had a tour of La Catedral, and the area of Cuzco by booking it through Llama Path travel agency. They picked us up from Cuzco airport and took us here and around Cuzco and I really enjoyed having a guide and a ride for the trip. We had to pay the ticket prices for entrance in additional to the tour price, but I think it was worth every penny.If you are here before hiking Machu Picchu, don't forget to buy bug spray, sun screen and TOILET PAPER!
Plaza de Armas. Our hotel was located walking distance to Plaza de Armas. So much happening here. Everything you need is located here. Very clean. A great place to be.

Great for sites, shops, and seeing people. The Plaza de Armas provides opportunity to see sites like La Catedral, shops like Illaria (famous Peruvian silver jewelry) and people watching. The center of the Plaza hold a statue with an interesting story. Mexico and Peru ordered the same fountain at the same time. But the delivery was switched. Peru received the fountain with the Mayan leader atop. The statue was changed last year for a celebration. There are sellers there, but with one exception of a seller who followed, saying, "No, gracias" seems to work. The only negative is that modern fast-food is now infringing in the Plaza. Starbucks (which I have to admit I did visit), McDonalds, and KFC now all have locations on the square. We felt more comforable walking around Cusco than we did other locations in Peru.

Crowded but kept clean. We were there the week before the winter solstice so every day saints were carried through the plaza. Parades seemed to happen every time we passed through. There were however workers there on a regular basis keeping the streets clean. At night local teenagers did traditional dances along the borders of the square. It was amazing. The night before the actual solstice there was a giant party. It seemed like it was more for local Peruvians since we did not see that many tourists in the crowd. There were thousands of people and a giant stage was erected with live music. Children through adults were drinking an large quantities of rum and coke. But even with all the drunkenness no one got out of control and by the next morning the streets were cleaned and hosed down like it had never happened.Yes there were always peddlers and people trying to lure you into their restaurant but it was not more imposing then any other similar city that depends on a tourist economy. The only thing that was excessive was when small children would try to block your path to buy their wares. My husband had to lift up and move a small girl who blocked a doorway with her body and separated us while trying to exit a restaurant. Otherwise just say no and smile and they usually move on.

Pretty but too many aggressive peddlers. While the "salespeople" on the Plaza de Armas aren't as aggressive as the ones in Mexico or Vietnam (where we were chased down the street on a moped because we weren't interested in the peddler's ware), there are a lot of them which gets in the way of simply relaxing or appreciating the architecture. There are several truly beautiful churches and public buildings which definitely deserve a visit. And, of course, there's always Starbucks in a pinch. =)

Grand chaos.. For those who love to people-watch and experience an area by using your feet on the street, a daily dose of the Main Plaza in Cusco is a must. Yes it’s “touristy” but in a Central Park kind-of-way. We made multiple visits here during our 4+ days in town and began to appreciate the area on multiple levels; the Central Square functions as a meeting place, area of relaxation, backdrop to good conversation, and human fishbowl all in one. There are a number of restaurants overlooking the square with upper-floor dining to watch the action from above if desired. We saw a couple religious parades in our brief time here which just added to the local vibe. Souvenir shops, local party-goers, restaurants, and who-knows-what-else all mingle here in a safe environment. And it's free! Have fun.

Great place to enjoy the ambience of Cuzco and people watch!. Very safe, shops and restaurants right there. Great mix of locals and tourists enjoying the square. Many places to sit and people watch or read a book or enjoy a nice drink.

BUSY BUSY area. Plaza de Armas is beautiful as with many of the Plazas all over Peru. The Cathedral and La Compania church on each corner is stunning. Water fountain is also a lovely area to take photos from. I walked up to Calle Suecia and got a pretty great view of the whole plaza and photo shots. Lot of people touting souveniers and the square is spoilt by the presence of KFC, Mc Donalds and Starbucks though.

Safe and pictoresque. Unlike so many other places I've gone on my travels, Cusco always felt safe. The plaza is always bustling and is really quite picturesque! So much to do in the immediate surroundings.

Amazing historical area.. Really enjoyed this part of Cusco. We stayed a block away and came here repeatedly. The Cathedral is spectacular, and the structures around the square are both historic, and well-preserved. Very discreetly, some of the buildings owned by the Catholic Church contain KFC, and McDonalds. The area is beautiful, and a pleasant place to sit and contemplate Peru's dramatic history.

Great people watching!. We stayed directly across the street from the plaza. The view at night was beautiful - with all the lights. During the day many people sit and enjoy the sun and people watching. We spend a few hours people watching and relaxing there. It is worth visiting. There are many stores and restaurants in the area.

Cusco - Center Stage. Most of the city attractions will be found her including the Cusco Cathedral. This is the center for nightlife in Cusco as well. However, most of the sights in the plaza are meant for tourists. If you want to see what the locals are doing - venture away from the plaza.
Beautiful Plaza. The plaza was very clean and safe. A great place to sit and people watch. The only down side was the local 'hawkers'. They were pretty persistent.

Wonderful at day and night. Very beautiful. During the day it is colorful and busy. At night almost festive and beautiful with the lighting of the churches. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Some of them are on the second floor, so look up when searching. Lots of vendors, none too aggresive, a firm and polite "no gracias" works if you are not interested.Odd fact - even though this is a world class site, you have to be careful not to get run over by taxis. Most (but not all) drivers here do not respect pedestrians and would not stop if you step out to cross.
Must see in Cusco. A must see in Cusco, the Plaza and the tours of the surrounding churches are entirely worth it. get a tour guide for a couple extra soles as it is worth it
Awesome. Wow...people are very friendly, polite and believe or not most of them speak English.

Great place. Many things to see and do. Thought overpriced most things...better buy in Lima. Restaurants, Travel agencies, Cathedrals, just incredible little side streets, markets (thought overpriced). Annoying art dealers, massage offerings and offering take pictures with alpaca and indians...just wrong and terribly annoying...and begging none stop...shocked me.

Gorgeous day and night. The plaza is a great place to sit and watch people, just be aware that as a tourist you are a target for the many vendors trying to sell you cheap, mass-produced "art," from cheap jewelry to clothing to cigarettes! The children are particularly persistent in trying to sell tourists souvenirs.

Quaint inca capital square. The architecture of the square that clearly shows the Spanish influence in the architecture as well the square itself take a seat on the plenty of benches and look around at all of the buildings then go into the church and marvel at the interior and think about how it must of been for a bunch of Spanish missionaries coming to the inca Capitol and converting the incas to Christianity. If you spend enough time inside you will see how the spa usher twisted their own beliefs to blend some local beliefs into a convincing story the incas would identify with and make it easier to accept the catholic beliefs. If you don't believe me just find the picture of the last supper and ask yourself have you ever seen the last supper consist of a guinea pig? There are many other items that will show you how they manipulated the incas to accept Christ over their own gods.the silver obtained from the incas was melted to build the main temple will place you in awe .do not miss the Irish pub across the street for some great nightlife.

A Hive of Activity. Enjoyed spending time in the Plaza which is surrounded by cafes shops and restaurants, many on the first floor with balconies overlooking the Plaza. Plenty of seating in the square and although you will be approached regularly by people selling all sorts of souvenirs of wanting to clean your shoes they are not pushy and a simple no thanks does the trick, although the shoe shine is well worth the 5 PEN!
Great!. While we were there a parade was taking place with all kinds of floats. We watched it from the balcony of Starbucks right on the plaza.

It's all happening here!!!. In June, this plaza is ALIVE!!!! So many celebrations, parades, and activities take place in this large square. In addition, there are lots of restaurants, cafes.........just a bundle of fun here!!

Great place day or night.. I wanted a hotel near the plaza and got lucky with El Virrey hotel which is right on the plaza. A great little hotel. Besides the constant asking to buy painting, its a very central and action packed place to be. Everything had been perserved well, interesting statue in the middle, great view of the city, churches, and cusco at its finest. Lots of resturants nearby, Mcdonalds/KFC/ Bebmos/ Pizza places right in the plaza, many shops, banks, historical sites around. There are a few stray dogs wondering around the plaza too, very friendly tho and keep to them selves. very safe area, lots of police and security everywhere. night time also has nice views of the city lights on the mountains. if your in cusco spend a hour or more walking around the area at least. And make sure your good at saying "no" to people selling things ha ha2 tips about money in the area:(1) All the ATM's in the area (about 20) run out of cash really fast at night, do not rely on them for cash, as you will be searching all of them getting small amounts here and there. (2) 3 or 4 doors down from my hotel (El Virrey) there is a money shop (not to be confused with all the cash exchange booths in the convinece stores) that will give you cash from your credit card over the counter. All you need is your card and your passport.
Nice place. good architecture, plenty of shops (but try the side streets, gets even better!), ignore the beggars/vendors that will approach you
Watch out for the kids. Cool place, very scenic and central to all the bars. Just watch out for the bar promoters and little kids trying to pick-pocket you.

June is celebration month!. There are 473 different groups that come to Cusco to celebrate during June. The celebration was amazing. It was something you could take you children to (in the daytime). A bit more 'lively' as the young foreigners joined in toward evening.
you have to see that but take care!. It's great, have to see that at day time and night time, but do take care! Try to get up early and have a look at it during dawn! Its mysterious!
Festival time!. Very crowded during our June visit. Streets closed to traffic making enjoying the sites difficult. Lots of energy!
Great views. This is a great place to sit and watch Cusco go by. Great views of the mountains from the park.
Really cool street market. See the market. You will have more fun looking at the interesting things there than anywhere else.
Alive! Alive! Alive!. Stayed in Cuzco during June's month of celebrations. Immersed in Peruvian culture.

Lively. There was always something going on in the Plaza, so it was a blast! We were there during the Feast of Corpus Christi, so every day people in native costumes were parading about and celebrating. There are several restaurants facing the plaza, and it was nice to sit up on their balconies, sipping a Cervesa and just people-watching. At night, the old churches and buildings a lit up and it is beautiful. Our only complaint about the Plaza - the hawkers are relentless, you can barely walk five feet without people constantly trying to sell you something.
The best location for city festivals!. All the festival parades, dances and religious activities occur here!
Great Hotel. Fun,lots of restaurants,parades due to solstice.All around nice place to be at.

Such an amazing place!!!. Just being in Cusco is such and amazing experience, and even better if you hang out in its "Plaza de armas". I really love Cusco, travelled there twice so far, but as I was saying being in the main square is magical, watching the people pass while you're chating with friends it's just a dream come true. Even though there are informal vendors trying to sell their stuff people should know that it's just a typical thing in Peru so get accostumed to it ;)Cusco main square rocks!

Great place,to spend the afternoons. A magnificent place to have a chat and eat some ice cream with your friends and talk to the localstake a picture with the backside of the cathedral is wonderful post card picture.Good atmosphere when you are travelling in cusco
Beautiful plaza with awesome view of the surroudings. Lots of activity going on with dances and many attractions nearby.
cusco the center. i will sugest you just take 3-4 hours to feel the city and the people very friendly and there is much mobvement there and very nice elegant shops

“Place for people watching .. Plaza de Armas, Cusco”. A classic Spanish influenced plaza is surrounded w/ collnades and churches. It's highlighted by the fountain w/ the Inca or king at it's center. Oh yeah, there a Starbucks and an Irish Pub where you can perch to watch the goings-on. But stay off the grass or you'll be hectored off by policia on an Segway!!!!

Great little hangout. Great at night. Eat somewhere different every night. Plenty of markets outside of the square, although you can get quite competitive prices if you are a skilled haggler. Dont buy the fake overpriced raybans. They can sell in smaller villiges for only 5 soles. Give your empty plastic bottles to the older women in the square, you will know who they are.Touts selling you massages, and printed paintings and food. Just beware the massages and the kids selling you paintings and women selling jewellery. The massages are not very good, they will get you to take of all your clothes quite unnecessarily. They are lovely people, and although everything is quite cheap, they are not as fortunate, so dont expect 5 star massage, beauty and travel advise. DO NOT BOOK TRAVEL THROUGH ANYONE ON PLAZA DE ARMAS. They are all rip offs.
Sunday is a good day. We arrived during the town celebrations of winter solstice, fantastic parades & street dancing, wonderful
Lovely Plaza. Beautiful park in the center with lots of cathedrals, restaurants, shops & banks.

A bustling center of culture and commerce. I enjoyed walking through the plaza...Sundays are always visually stimulating with parades and costumes. It is busy and you are constantly petitioned to purchase crafts...as long as you balance it with quieter neighborhoods it doesn't become too overwhelming.

Watch the world go by. The centre of Cusco with the likes Starbucks, KFC and McD's surrounding the plaza yet no obvious signage.Thank you city fathers for this. It took me several days to realise that McD was right next to the Cathedral. Loved sitting up in Starbucks, coffee in hand writing my blog and watching the world go by below me. Plenty of places to eat, drink, sit and relax.

Cusco's soul. The Plaza De Armas is where one can quite easily spend a couple of hours . It's around here that ancient palaces were built by Inca Kings, and later cathedrals by the Spanish. It stands on layers of history. The Cathedral and the Church of La Campania are two magnificent structures here.Then there are the lawns and benches where you can sit engrossed in a chat with a local artist(Cusco has many who paint its sights). The intricately carved and colourful wooden balconies on the buildings are another attraction. It's the place for processions and we were lucky to see one, that of alpalca rearers pass by with its music and dancing. There are cafe's and bars around. A night visit to the Plaza is a must. Lit up, it looks enchanting.

The Centre of the Tourist Area. The cathedral, church, restaurants, currency exchange, and shopping surrounded this square. It was fun to sit on a bench in the square amongst the flowers and people and just relax and take in the surroundings.
a great example of calonial building &architecture,. the buildings where magnificiant. very well kept &spotlessly clean.gardens 7FLOWERBED,S WEEL LOOKED AFTER

The heart and soul of Cusco. This is the nerve centre of the town and where most people gravitate to at some stage. This is a very historic place where back through history people who had fallen foul of the rulers, both Spanish and Incan where executed ( generally be headed). People realax on the seats around the square with the lovely fountain in the centre, people watching and feeding the pigeons. The restaurants in the area mostly have balcomies overlooking the square and they are a good place to spend an afternoon or evening. Cusco is a good place to try Cuy (guinea pig).

Transported back in time. There is some beautiful architecture dotted around this impressive square. Although there are plenty of shops and restaurants in the vicinity, signage is kept to a minimum. Many roads lead off from this square and each lead to another smaller square. Plenty to explore and photograph.

Lovely center. The center is pretty and nice to just sit and relax, the shopping is ok, not much directly on the square. Lots of people soliciting to sell their watercolors and massages (which was worth it though, you can get a hour massage for the equivalent of less than $20 USD)
Picturesque wi good restaurants. The central plaza was lively - church, cathedral, fountain, good restaurants and shops.

The place to go in Cusco. What a beautiful square! I loved the historical buildings, vibrant activity and tons and tons of restaurants and shops. The only downside is being hassled every 3 steps by someone selling paintings, jewelry, etc... but unlike other cities, they at least respect your wishes when you say, "no, gracias." The other downside is seeing McDonalds and Starbucks - boo! Can't these corporate giants leave some places alone?

Great Meeting place!. The Plaza de Arms is the center of the town of Cusco. Here you are centrally based to visit the cathedral, shops, and many restaurants. Every day you can witness the people enjoying a lovely time sitting and talking to friends and family members. What a great way to spend the afternoon. Enjoy!

Beautiful - have a coffee or bite to eat. There are several restaurants in the area that have 2nd floor balcony windows. Try and stop there for breakfast or coffee...take in the plaza. There will often be parades going on to honor different members which is fascinating to watch.

Beautiful area full of life. We went here on our first day in Cuzco. It was a nice place to visit, but the only annoying aspect was all the street vendors descending like vultures....other than that, it was nice.

Beautiful!. We saw the Plaza de Armas - beautiful setting, wonderful history, but be prepared for the street merchants haggling you at every turn! We had drinks at "Paddy's Pub" if you want an Irish flair, there is even a Starbucks for those who need their fix!

Start here when in Cusco. The Plaza de Armas is a great place to start when site seeing in Cusco. It is close to most hotels, there are several shops, restaurants and bars for food. Additionally, there are several beautiful churches and other sites very close to the area. All taxi drivers will know how to get here and if you are meeting friends or tour guides this is a great central location. The square is generally busy with locals and tourist; sometimes you can even catch a few street performers.

A focal point in the city of Cusco. This is a beautifully manicured garden area in downtown Cusco, near the Cathedral. It has beautiful plantings and offers amazing views of the mountains. There is a lovely fountain in the center and during the day you will find many people enjoying the plaza. The plaza is surrounded by several churches, stores and restaurants. It is a great place to people watch!

Beautiful plaza in Cusco!. Well, what can I say about it? You will be there if you go to Cusco, and it is gorgeous! Enjoy, take your time. Also, have some food in your pocket or purse for some hungry skinny dogs that wonder around (not just this plaza... anywhere in Cusco)...

Beautiful historic center of "the navel of the world". No trip to Cusco would be complete without at least a brief visit to the Plaza de Armas. The churches are rustic and beautiful and the square itself is a great place to shop, eat, and peoplewatch. Compared to Lima, Cusco's Plaza de Armas feels much more relaxed and tourist-friendly.
Everything there. The Plaza de Armas has everything at your fingertips. Restaurants, cafes, shops, attractions. It's definitely a must see to take some beautiful pictures of the beautiful city
Pefect place to people watch. You can find all the tourist places in this square
A very happening place. This is a great place to see the history in Cuzco but also a great place to go back to for dinner and shopping. On the weekends you will find a parade, wedding, or musicians.

Great location for people-watching.. The plaza is located in the heart of the city and is a busy and attractive place. The plaza has a beautiful setting surrounded by churches and historic buildings. My wife and I enjoyed sitting on a park bench and watching both locals and tourists.
love it. I loved Plaza de Armas. Choose a caffe and spend some free time wacthing life goes on.....
Beautiful. Liked the plaza with all the shopping and food choices. Did not find the lack of Spanish as a handicap

beautiful churches, but very touristy and busy. The square is very scenic with a mixture of the colonial churches and the remaining Inka walls. There are many street vendors trying to sell things, but they are not too persistent.
Great for people watching!. We walked through there almost daily to get around town. It it a beautiful plaza and a great place to sit and watch the crowds.

This place is a definite visit if in Cusco. A ton of restaurants and shops in this area. Restuarants will compete for your business too. The best part is on Sunday they have a military march in the morning around the plaza. Be aware that taxis will charge you more if you want to get picked up here, I would recommend getting a taxi outside the plaza because it will cost half as much! The landscape is awesome and be prepared to be asked to buy stuff but a quick no gracias will keep them moving. It is beautiful and full of options!
hang out and people watch. the plaza is a great place to sit with a coffee and relax and watch all the activity around you.

Historical, beautiful and busy. Be sure to visit the square on Sunday. The parade is amazing. A local display of military, professional schools and cultural dance and music. I felt so Lucky to sit on the cathedral steps with the local community watching the parade from 10am to 1pm. Almost depleted my flash card taking so many pictures.

You can spend days here!. Plaza de Armas is full of great people watching, cathedrals, pubs, markets, restaurants. You name it, its there and so un-American which we loved! Take a tour of the main Cathedral and hire a private guide. Make sure you see the Last Super that has a cuy in it!
Cusco. Beautiful square with cathedral, statues, collonaded shops, and incredible views of the surrounding mountains.

Beautiful visits every day. Lots of things to do. In Maizito in NW corner every day at 8:00 PM great music by some serious group. On the way to San Danse, just on the other side of the grand inca wall everybody takes picture of there is a little passage with a maker of music instruments, but not the ones for decoration, real ones.

Nice place to relax but touristy. The Plaza is a small park complex in the middle of Cusco. It's a nice place to sit and read a book. That said there are a lot of tourists and thereby a lot of vendors trying to push their goods on you.
This is where a the action is in this small city. The central hub of the historic district. It is where all but one of the restaurants we ate in were located.

Great plaza. Our favorite plaza in Peru! Good sampling of quality shops & restaurants surrounding the plaza. Tourism police always in plain view and very helpful in locating sites, etc. Always felt safe and comfortable here.

Walkers Paradise. A very pretty area. All the tourist type stuff is around the Plaza de Armas as well as little side streets that go off to lots of interesting places. Parades every couple of days and the Cathedral is here as well and McDonalds.
spectacular. the church's are amazing, must see. many little shop's and many picture taking spots

Delicious, just delicious. Upon returning home to the USA it took me a Month to start to like US food. The restaurants along the square here are to die for. They are the best food anywhere. BUT be careful do not order anything you are used to having in the USA. No banana splits, no apple or peach pie, no fries and especially avoid the coca cola at all costs. Get Inka Kola instead. Be sure to visit the establishments on the side streets as well. All of it was a great and wonderful experience.
Good resting place. Nice area to people watch, great ceromonies on Good Friday at Easter. Many restaurants to choose from.

Great place to get your bearings and people watch.. I had the good fortune to kill some time in the plaza while waiting for late afternoon flight to Lima. It was a Sunday and the locals were holding some kind of ceremony, speeches I did not understand by various military and civilian leaders, followed by a flag raising ceremony which was quite interesting followed by cultural events, with locals in native and Spanish influenced dress dancing to period music. Quite a scene really. On other days though it would mostly be a pleasant area to watch people, catch some sun, visit the Cathedral, have lunch at one of the restaurants lining the square, or perhaps get a Starbucks coffee. Well they had free WIFI. Okay. Give me a break would ya!
A pretty square in the center of town. A beautiful church, some lovely architecture, a pretty fountain - and... McDonald's. What is becoming of this world?
Great for people watching. Great vantage point to peruse the historical buildings around it. Good choice of small restaurants and cafes all around. Sit on a park bench and enjoy the sights.
Nice and large square. Nice size, offeres great views of the valley . This is the actual town center so restaurants and shops for visitors are all located nearby.

nice cozy plaza. 2 churches nearby - La catedral and La Compania. Liked the coziness of the place with people just sitting my the benches and taking it slow. Lots of vendors follow you. I just say "no, gracias" and move on. Lots of safety officers around. An art vendor speaking good English started chatting with my companion. Sensing a scam coming, I walked away and observed from afar. A safety officer talked to that vendor to leave my companion alone. Great view of churches, the park and houses on the surrounding mountains. Lots of restaurants around.
must visit in Cusco. Ambiance, history, nice shops, friendly shop owners, quality products, interesting cathedral
Resting in the Plaza de Armas. We found this a good place to rest in between visiting other attractions. We enjoyed sitting on the benches and watching the many locals and tourists go by. Felt safe.
Definitely worth the time if your in Cuzco. A beautiful plaza with lots of shops and ongoings. This plaza is a must see if you are in cuzco

Nice but no shade. It's a big pleasant park with a fountain. There are plenty of seats but no shade. The churches are fine, but somewhat boring in architectural variety, and most of the shops are tourist oriented souvenirs and tour providers.
Beautiful Plaza. Its a lovely safe plaza. We walked there every day we were in Cusco. Lots of parades.
simply beautiful. beautiful place in the sunshine as well as in the evening, with city lights on; awsome view around
No brainer. This is the main square in Cusco. You can't avoid it. A lot of nice shops around it.
Cool area and fountain. Thank goodness for a fairly flat space. My legs were worn out from up and down. Pretty little plaza though.
Cusco at its finest!. This is the place to see and be seen in cusco.. cant miss it!

Young vendors ambitious, not pushy. I found the young individual vendors ambitious, but not pushy or not too insistent when trying to make a sale. I learned a lot about the area from them. "Coosi" means "happy."
Nothing special here. Plaza de Armes is a typical Spanish styled square. Nothing special.

tourist attraction. the main square has a beautiful view of sorrounding hills and houses buiklt on mountain slopes. Various shops, cafes,money exchangers, churches and museums are at all four sides of the square.
Lots of Fun. This is a great area for sight seeing and people watching! Would definitely recommend

Pretty. If u r in Cusco, you have to go and sit ther for a while. Take some pictures, observe the movements of people.
Worth it!
Beautiful place with nice fountain. Great Spanish architecture around it. Nice statue of Inca Emperor & fountain.

don't step on the grass!. beautiful, quiet and central place to have a rest or meet a friend while in Cusco. Small enough that you can find the person you're looking for. Not too much shade, though; wear your hat and sunscreen if you're walking the city in the summer time! and do NOT try to find shade under the trees ... we were scolded for sitting on the grass.
well conserved colonial skyline. the central plaza is very well maintained. Except for the cars and electricity, you can feel just like 300 years ago
Perfect place for photos!. Staying here is like walking in the spanish times..

A Square is a Square until you learn the history.. Truly amazing history. I'm not one to travel with guide books but the history here is fascinating. I picked up a book in the hotel library (Ninos Hotel) and read about the Plaza. It's worth the time to look into. Once you have the back story you can see the plaza as so much more than a place to shop/exchange currency. You can even begin to read the imagery in the local tapestries.

Lovely Plaza. We enjoyed seeing the plaza, the fountain and the cathedrals and building that surround it. Very nice and worth a visit. Besides, to walk to most restaurants you're likely to cross through here anyway!

Lovely plaza. The plaza is beautiful, but along with that it's probably the most annoying point in Cusco.With every step you take, girls will try to sell you massages and at night dodgy guys will try to sell you drugs. But this is the centre, where everything happens :)Say no to happy ending... and I guess to the drugs as well :)

Such a special place !!!. Loved sitting on a bench looking at the Churches and local people living their everyday lives. Didn't like being harassed and pressured into buying something or getting your picture taken with someone every second that you were there. Way worse than any Mexican beach !!! But that's all part of the experience.....
The base point. Everything is near this point. All the banks, all the travel agencies, all the restaurants. If you´re looking for something at Cusco, you can find it here.
Nice place. Good and very beautiful place to stay, surrounded by nice restaurants.

Beautiful Plaza. The Plaza is beautiful. There are great historical sites and restaurants all around. You WILL get asked to buy 1 million different things, but you might also meet some friendly locals!

Annoying!. The plaza i beautiful, however I've never been offered more massages and trinkets in my life!!! You can't even sit to eat without these people bothering you. they don't seem to know what no means!

Plaza de Armas - go after dark. Doln't hide in your hotel room after the sun goes down. Go down to the plaza and anjoy the evening and especially the lights of the city spread out for you on the surrounding hills.
Breathtaking. Surrounded by the Cusco Cathedral, the Jesuits Church and several shops and restaurants, the Plaza de Armas has beautiful gardens, a fountain and is a very romantic place.

Beautiful plaza - too many touts. The plaza itself is stunning and has lovely colonial architecture with traces of Inca buildings in the later ones. It is quite a sight.However, the whole experience was slightly tainted by touts for tours, massages and restaurants. They are quite aggressive and are a total nuisance. There are also lots of kids (who should be in school) trying to sell you tat.Luckily, the plaza is nice enough to make up for the pests.

Touristy but the hub of Cusco. Bustling main squareof the histroic part of Cusco, dominated by the Cathedral and surrounded by bars, cafes and restaurants. Touristy but a great vibe and a good spot for coffee, lunch or evening drinking.

It's a beautiful plaza!. We were there in December 2011. This plaza has amazing view and it's beautiful both in day time and night time. There are 1000s of light as background at night and you will feel like watching 1000s of fireflies up in the mountains and that's just amazing! This plaza is a place where local people hang out and you will see a lot of tourists around the area . We feel very safe walking around at night. This is definitely a place not to be missed if you are in Cusco! Oh there are many shops and restaurants around the plaza so you don't need to worry about food, coffee or snack if you feel like having a bit.
Beautiful Square. This is a truly beautiful square, clean and landscaped beautifully....we were there during a festival and it was a magical place!

Christmas Eve market at the Plaza de Armas, one of the best I have been to.. We visited Cusco and the sacred valley for Christmas. I had read about the Christmas market held here on Christmas Eve but I had no idea that it would be such a memorable event. I knew something big was going down when campesinos were coming out of their villages and staying in the street at night. I think they were saving their spot at the market. Many people come from far away villages with moss covered branches, patches of moss , pine branches , ceramics of farm animals, just about everything a Cusqueno would need to build a Nativity scene in their home. Outfits for Baby Jesus like you never imagined, everything from knit booties, to little crowns.  Besides that there was an incredible selection of many types of artesanias and textiles as well as art. I bought an amazing painting of Archangel Michael done in the old colonial style for about $100.00. I had seen something similar here in the states for $2500.00. Also something I hadn't seen elsewhere in the sacred valley, hand carved wooden spoons super cheap. We spent the day , people watching , shopping and eating street food !
An average Plaza de Armas.. Beautiful, but standard. It feels very safe to walk around here, even with expensive equipment, but it is not necessarily stunning.

Good place to people watch. This is the heart of Cusco. Grab a drink and hang out on one of the balconies overlooking the square or sit on one of the benches and soak up the sunshine. There is always something going on and something new to see. Vendors will approach you, but be careful and they are most often not licensed and may be picked up by the police right in front of you.
Essential, but many more pleasant plazas nearby. Busy, commercial but essentially Cusco. If you're after something more tranquil, try plaza San Fancisco

Great plaza!. This is the center of Cuzco. If you're lucky enough to be there on Christmas Eve, there's a tremendous market surrounding the whole plaza with hundreds of booths and thousands of people. A great way to immerse yourself in Cuzco culture!
Beautiful Square. Centre of Cusco city tour and nightlife tour!!! This is the square where you will see it all happening. Great during festivals and parades in June and July.

Christmas eve visit. We were in the plaza on christmas eve this year 2011. There was a HUGE market in the plaza with probably a hundred thousand people walking, shopping, selling. It was am awesome site with all the color and the noise and the smells. The market goes late into the night and continued on Christmas day. There was a ton of people buying traditional Peruvian items. Even thought the plaza was crowded, there were a number of police around so it felt very safe. If you want to visit an open market, this would be the one to do. The plaza is surrounded by beautiful churches from the Spanish period.

Always something going on. This plaza is one of the more picturesque you will see on your Peruvian travels.A well-manicured park (don't walk on the grass or the Tourist Police will whistle up a storm!), surrounded by the imposing Cathedral and beautiful La Compania de Jesus.This plaza really changes character between night and day, and is beautiful at any time. A great place to people-watch if you can scare away the painting sellers.Definitely dine/breakfast in a second floor restaurant and watch the world of Cusco go by.

The Street Vendors Are Bad For Tourism. When you visit Cusco you will inevitably find your self walking through Cusco Plaza De Armas which could be a great place to relax and contemplate the complicated history of the interaction between the Incas culture and the Spanish, but it is not a place to contemplate anything because the street vendors, restaurant button holers, and touts drove me off in a bad mood and ruined my experience at the plaza. I'm sure it is not just me. They are bad for tourism.
Well set out. A lovely broad square, shops all around nice to walk through.

Traditional square with lots of bars and restaurants. The centre point of Cusco and where all the bars, restaurants and shops are located. The cathederal also sits in pride of place at the edge of the square - a must see when in Cusco.
Beautiful central spot. The plaza is lovely, if a little touristy. It is a great place to people watch but be prepared for massages, and anything else than can be sold.
A lot of hustle. Even though the vendors are non stop, it is not aggressive and we enjoyed walking around. So much history to understand. Nice to sit at a sidewalk cafe and just people watch.

Just hang out and take it in. As a photographer I spend hours just sitting in this plaza. There is always something going on. The first time I went to Cusco there was a parade every night in this main plaza. If you can't find someone or get lost, make your way back to the Plaza de Armas and it will only be a matter of time before you find the same people passing through again. There are tons of locals selling their craft. Beware of hats and woven things being dirty before you buy them. They are a great price if you don't mind cheap stuff, just don't ever put it in a dryer or it becomes Barbie size. Just inspect it first. These "vendors" are not legally allowed to be pedaling in the plaza so if you don't want to be bothered by them stand close to one of the police women in the plaza and they won't come near you. If you talk to one, you will soon be swarmed by many that assume you are a willing buyer. I enjoy talking with the vendor even though I rarely buy anything. There is great food to be had in this plaza also. My favorite is the a balcony resturant that faces the smaller church. The owner is Pedro. I got food poisoning at the Sumaq on the upper level. Don't advise it. There is also a KFC and McDonald's in the Plaza for those who insist on fast food. The lights in the Plaza come on at 6pm sharp.
Center square. Many restaurants and close to everything. Try to get your hotel near here.
BIG plaza.... all the touristic shops are here and also the cathedral which is very beautifull.

Easter Week. We arrived at the end of the Easter Celebration and were lucky enough to have the opportunity to view the procession returning Christ to the Cathedral. What a memorable site. We were there early enough to watch as people started to gather, we ran into a German couple we met at one of the Tambopata lodges...and we share a lovely bottle of wine and watched the procession...it was an amazing evening.

People watching paradise.. If anything goes down in Cuzco, its usually here. Surrounded by tourist shops, its where the locals meet to socialize and have afternoon drinks. The two churches are imposing and beautiful and the Inca fort can be seen on the hilltop. It really is the center of turismo Cuzco. For real Cuzco, head down the hill into the markets.
My Favorite!. Beautiful square! Beautiful cathedral and lots of nice restaurants in the area.

The Center, must visit. The Plaza is quite nice and everything is located around it. The Cathedral was beautiful, many restaurants were terrific, etc. Only downside is that there are many, many venders peddling their art and other misc items and they target tourists. It's not easy to just sit and relax in the park, you'll have to go to one of the smaller nearby parks if you're hoping not to get bothered.

The center of the universe. All roads led to Cusco during the reign of the Incas, and Plaza de Armas was at the center of it all. Although many of the surrounding buildings are now home to souvenir shops, the plaza still has history pulsing through it....
Beautiful Square. It was a rainy day when we visited. The square was beautiful in the rain at dusk. We walked the square to enjoy local restaurants and shopping.
Plaza de Armas. Great atmosphere to watch the world go by. Busy but pleasant
Nice main square. We liked the public events that take place every Sunday - definitely worth watching. It was also a nice place to just stroll around and take in the atmosphere.
Exciting. This is where it all happens-a great meeting place. Everyone congregates here-tourists & locals alike.

Beautiful main square. Lots of historical buildings surrounding the square, lots of nice restaurants like Inca grill, and just behind the plaza lots of interesting shops as well as some churches to visit.
Spanish Square. If it wasn't for the statue of Pachacuti, in the centre, this could be a square anywhere in Spain - bizarre. It's nice just to sit and watch the world go by.

Beautiful, but.... The Plaza is beautiful and well maintained. However, the street vendors seriously detract from an otherwise wonderful experience. They are such a pain in the side that you cannot enjoy the splendor and historical significance.
Interesting place.. Part of a great city tour with Ernesto, an outstanding guide. Good preparation for visit to Machu Picchu.

Great People Watching. I loved to sit in the square or on the cathedrial steps watching tourists and locals a like but beware of the ladies and children selling their goods. They are pretty pushy so be prepared to say no unless you really want to buy and if you buy from one they will all come bother you.
Great place to sit with a drink and pass a few hours. Clean and relaxing, great place to visit. Go down and sit outside and enjoy a beer watching everyone go by.

Best Plaza de Armas in South America. I like Cusco even more than Machu Picchu itself. Cusco is an extremely charming city and plaza de armas is one of the most beautiful spots: The Cathedral, the architecture, the cobblestone streets, the environment, the dim lights during the afternoon/night. The atmosphere is great even though tourists (like me) wander everywhere endlessly.
Downtown. Very nice place at night. Full of pubs and restaurants.

Where to eat?. As well as some great things to see, the Plaza is also surrounded by many eateries to choose from. We had some delicious meals from quite a few of them. More time in Cusco would have taken the stress out of choosing which one to eat at next!
The Plaza. Colorful and friendly area with lots of shops, restaurants and people watching.

The Heart of Cusco. Plaza de Armas is the center of Cusco. Here is where you'll see protest marches, parades, live performances, speeches, or anything else that matters in Cusco. The square is simply magnificent, surrounded by cathedrals, with a fountain in the middle. All around the outside are restaurants and bars (very touristy ones, mind you), most with a chance to sit on a small balcony overlooking the square. There is shopping and all your conveniences at the square too, and it is a very safe area, always patrolled. This is the one place in Cusco that pretty much every visitor has seen.The downside is you'll be hassled by street vendors selling you massages, paintings, hats, gloves, entry to museums, or whatever else. There are some beggars, but mostly people selling things, even if just to take a photo of them or their alpaca for 1 PEN. You'll also be hassled by restaurant greeters trying to get you into their restaurant. This is all typical of any tourist area in Latin America, so nothing to get worked up about. Relax and enjoy the beauty of the square, sit on the benches in the middle and just watch Cusco go by. Don't forget to check out inside the cathedrals, they are very nice.

Center of all that Cusco has to offer!. All roads lead to the Plaza Mayor, or the main Plaza. Most of the major hotels are within a couple of blocks of this Plaza. we were fortunate to watch, a huge parade of police and other security folks there. It was a pleasure to see it clean, and no beggars anywhere. Lots of art hawkers and women with sheep wanting money for getting their photographs taken.You can take a tram from there for a ride around town but it was a challenge to discover its timing, and we gave up! The cathedral has regular services but tourists are barred from it.Folks, the native peruvians are very poor, but they don't beg, so do be generous with your tips.

Cusco's main plaza. An historical old square, the nicest part of Cusco. They keep it clean and is patrolled by police. On one day there was a band and group of masked dancers. The police do their best to keep vendors away, but they will probably assault you with their wares. If you're not interested smile and firmly say "no, gracias". If you show any interest in what they have, you're sunk! If you ARE interested, my advice (I speak the language and did some intense bargaining):Don't buy from the first vendor; get a feel for what they're asking. Most sellers ask at least 1/3 more than what they'll settle for; I bought chullos (wool caps) for 6 soles, but most will ask 8-12 soles. Walk away if you don't like the deal, most will counter offer as you leave. Be polite and friendly, they're just trying to make a living.

Hassle Free. My husband and I had been travelling through Central America, Ecuador and Peru with Cusco our last stop. We had seen so many Inca sites along the way we didnt feel like seeing the ones in Cusco. We ended up spending most of our time in the Plaza De Armas. This was by far one of the nicest squares we came across on our travels. It was very clean and was patrolled by the police at all times. They stopped everyone from walking across the grass - which was always maintained. And they stopped people from trying to sell paintings, sunglasses and other general stuff. So it felt very safe. It is also towered by the beautiful cathedral and church along 2 sides of the square. The other 2 sides are full with tour agencies and souvenir shops.The Plaza De Armas is the center of Cusco with many events happening here. While we were here (a week in total before and after we did the Inca Trail) all the local school kids - from the ages of 3 up to university level dressed up and paraded around the streets with music and crazy costumes. At this time the square was extremely busy but always watched by the police. Definately worth a visit!I also agree with below, if you plan on doing the Inca Trail, make sure you book with Peru Treks! They are just the best!

Tourist Trap. My girlfriend and I just got back from a wonderful vacation in Latin America. We spent four days hiking the Inca Trail in Peru. I recommend that every able bodied person do this hike (and do it with Peru Trek). Cusco is the staging ground for Inca Trail hikes. Most companies require us "gringos" to be in Cusco at least two days prior to the hike to acclimate to the altitude. I wanted to stay in a hotel that was close to the center of action, which, based on reviews I read, I had deemed to be Plaza de Armas.I've traveled quite a bit (China, Japan, Europe, Australia, Costa Rica) and have lived abroad for several years. Plaza de Armas is a tourist trap by definition. A) the prices are equivalent to what one pays in the US for food/drink, and B) the local vendors see you coming a mile away and hard sell you on paintings, sun glasses, massages, hats and gloves. And they swarm on you every time you walk out of your hotel. My girlfriend had to leave the bench she was sitting on after a vendor refused to stop trying to sell her stuff after five minutes.My advice, stay in San Blas which is a 5 minute walk uphill from Plaza de Armas.

Lovely Area. We had a great time at the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. The views were lovely, lots of photo ops. And we did not feel at all harrassed by the shopkeepers and vendors, we did in a couple of other areas in Cusco but not here. A must see for Cusco.

Festival!. On our arrival to Cusco, our "angel" guide, took us to the parade and festival that was going on in town! I believe she said it was the last weekend for the Festival of the Three Crosses.What a wonderful country! The clothes, the music, the fireworks! We walked over to the plaza de Armas after the parade had ended, and took a closer look at the fountain. You can see Spanish influence all around the square. It was a wonderful afternoon, and our meal a couple of blocks away was great! If in Peru, try the Koi (Guinea Pig) with fresh potatoes!

A Lovely Square Ruined - What a Shame. Cusco's Plaza de Armas is a lovely square - at first glance, I thought it would be the perfect place to hang out, relax, and people watch under Cusco's sunny blue skies. Unfortunately it is plagued by hoardes of street vendors young and old, who constantly approach and pressure you to buy things. I've never been anywhere where this was more of a problem - it was so overwhelming and such a turnoff that we ended up not wanting to go there at all. It's a shame, because the cathedral is there, the Compañia de Jesus church is there, the fountain in its park-like setting, etc. The plaza is beautiful at night, too, when the fountain and churches are all lit up. The only thing I can recommend is going upstairs to one of the many restaurants or bars that ring the plaza , so you can enjoy the view from one of their balconies without having to put up with the hard sell of all the vendors.
